It costs 150 Baht and if you are 'late' for check in then you might want to use it but the access from the airport (basement) is slightly different. Note this.Do you research and read several reviews here as if you come unprepared, it is horrible to be lost when first in a new destination. Really you should have purchased a train map or downloaded something online as you need to know your station although we expect most of you will be heading to the city centre (Phayathai).You get a good view of the suburbs as the track is elevated, the system very modern, fast (say 25 minutes to the centre. Look out for the giant TV screen on the side of a building as you near the City Centre and treat this experience as an excursion to be enjoyed.Best Regards.Chris & AnnaPS In theory this transport system is wheelchair friendly but we have found on occasion that the lift is out of order and then you would be stuck. If this is your category arrange private transport.

Cheap, Convenient & Efficient. Took the airport rail link into the city this time round. Reached my hotel destination in under an hour, especially during the busy NYE period. Trip costed me a mere 100baht to Phaya Thai, while BTS to my hotel costed me about 30baht.Was caught in a very nasty BKK grid lock jam in the city which lasted for 6hours the last time I visited. Learnt my lesson, and took the Rail Link instead. On my return trip I took the cab though, as traffic seemed to clear up on the day I was returning. Cab ride took me 45mins, and costed me 500baht.
Bts fantastic. Basically the airport link is another part of the BTS network of sky trains, easy to use and it runs from Phaya Thai to Suvarnabhumi Airport

Perfect mass transport from Suvarnabhumi. For solo traveller, it is the best solution to reach the Bangkok Downtown. You could continue to your accomodation by BTS or MRT. Sometimes little bit fulled of people who carry a big luggage who need larger space than the backpack.
Sky train is fab. Clean, affordable, friendly what more can you wish for- great to see Bangkojk from the tenth floor up- and the link is now great as it can go straight to the airport- well done.
Accessible airport rail link. We took the Express train which is one stop to airport. Costs us 90 baht per head. Connection from Phaya Thai BTS exit.

This sure beats taxis. If you haven't tried this train, give it a go, make the effort to find your way to it, it is cheap, safe and easy. Take it to the nearest stop to your hotel ,then get a taxi if needed. We were delighted to discover the train system.
Convenient and cheap mode to Airport. It is indeed a cheap and convenient mode of transport to and from airport. Especially during rush hour.

take the train. we took the train into bankok for the first time normally taxis from the airport but this year decided everything would be changed travelled into the centre of bkk and changed to nana station a 10 minute walk with a suitcase works up an appetite for a beer

Quick and efficient, but can get crowded. Cheap and fast, it takes you into the bowels of BKK Airport. A peak flight times there are often hordes of tourists lugging their luggage onto the train. It can get packed.
Fast & convenient. Easy to access from airport, ticket machines are very user-friendly with clear instructions, trains are clean.
Great & Cheap. It is the best alternative to and from airport, even caring luggage. You only have to check the time table to plan better your trip, times are not so regular.
Slow Ride to BKK Airport. First time ever, we tried the train, never again. Express service is almost every hour and the city line is slow and cramped. Its better to take a cab.

fast and easy. Loved my first experience on the express train to the airport. The ticket from Praya Thani only costs 90THB per person and the trip takes only 15 minutes. The waiting area has comfy chairs as well. If you are leaving in the daytime, the view leaving the city is great as well. The trains are first class re standard-I'd highly recommend this option for getting to the main airport in Bangkok.

Xmas in Bangkok. A great & cheap alternative to a Taxi.Check the timing as the 'local' line runs more often and is cheaper than the Express.The transfer at Makkasan to the MRT isn't well sign posted but not too difficult to find & get to with baggage

Take it - it is so easy. The rail link is 45 Baht. It takes you right into the eastern part of the city in 20 minutes. It drops you at Praya Thai, where you pick up the MRT. You can go north or south from there for a few pence and the Sky train is so easy to use.The ticket machines are in English as well as Thai. You look on the map, press the station you want and a price comes up. put in the fare and a plastic credit card type ticket emerges. On the Airport Rail link you can slide in notes. On the MRT it is only coins. If you don't have enough, the ticket office will not issue a ticket, but will change notes for coins. It could not be simple and most of the main connections are just a short walk across platforms. Everything is brilliantly signed.

Fast and cost efficient!. I used take the Taxi from the airport to the Bangkok City area, but after the Airport Rail Link operated, have been taking this and never looked back. This is the fasteIf you are staying around pratunam area, take the airport rail link to Makassan station, then change to Ratchaparop BTS. It's about 10 miinutes walk to Baiyoke Sky hotelTaking a taxi can get you easily 400-500 baht, depending on traffic condition.

Only worth it if traffic is really bad.. There are in fact two train services. One is the "express" which runs non-stop to the dedicated airport express city terminal. This is not particularly conviniently located about 250m from Petchaburi Metro station. (the station is huge as it was clearly planned with airline check-in desks etc but none of that works). The "express" works but if there are two of you wont save you money and will probably take longer than a taxi of which there are many in BKK (tell them to use the meter and take the express-way). There is also the SRT train (State Railways of Thailand) train. This is a fraction of the price. It stops three or four times on the way into the city but this is more than made up for by the fact that the SRT train continues further into the city terminating at Phaya Thai sky-train station. if you want to save money then this is the option to go for.

Best Way to Get Into Bangkok. I was one of the happiest people going when they finally finished the Airport Rail Link in Bangkok. I hate traffic and the highways between the airport and the city of notoriously bad for traffic.There are two versions of the Rail Link. One is the fast train to Phaya Thai - this takes about 20 minutes and generally isn't very crowded. It is a bit more expensive than the second version which is the local version.The local Rail Link makes a number of stops along the way and is used by locals to commute on so can get rather crowded during rush hour. It takes a little over half an hour.Either route beats the traffic both on time and cost. When you get into town you can either connect to the MRT or else catch a taxi.
Fast. Fast link from the city to the airport that was comfortable and efficient but not much cheaper than a taxi.

Goes into the City and ENDS???. The Airport Rail Link goes into the City and Ends! Yes, there is NO connection! There are NO taxis waiting. You can walk and haul your suit cases for 20 minutes in the heat. Down Stairs. Across rail tracks, through traffic, UP stairs, down stairs and make it to an under ground system. Crazy but True!

Fast, convenient and cheap. I encountered this during my first trip to Thailand. This one is located at the basement of the Airport. My friend and I took this one to get to my hotel. The trip was fast, hassle free and the train itself was well maintained. It saved us a lot of time to get to our destination and we evaded those overpriced taxis at the airport.The Airport Rail Link offers a good view of the surroundings and since it was night time when we used it, we were treated to a nice view of the city lights. It was a nice prelude to my trip.

Cheaper than cab. I reached airport on 23rd December and if you follow the signs, you should be able to locate it. Due to the protest, there was traffic jams at city areas. Thus it is more convenient to take the Train. It is cheap and i was able to get seats on the train. You need to know the name of the stations which you are going and may need to transfer at certain stations, thus do your homework first or you can ask the helpful staff at the counter for directions.

Fast, comfortable, and economical. When your accomodation is close to any BTS station, I suggest you take this. You never be stucked in traffic, no hassle, and comfortable.From Suvarnabhumi (pronounced: su-wan-na-pum) International Airport, Take the Airport Rail Link (City Line) to Phaya Thai station (the other end of the City line). One-way ticket costs TH฿45 and the train operates from 06:00AM to 12:00 midnight.You can transfer from the Phaya Thai station of the Airport Link to the Phaya Thai station of the BTS to reach you destination of choice.Airport Rail Link and the BTS are interconnected with elevated walkway.
Super. Loved chao praya river boat, chinatown and is frenetic life around the clock, wat po disliked the smog and the noise

Quick and convenient. Does the job, it's quicker and cheaper than a taxi. If you are staying in the airport hotel and have a few hours time on your hands, i would recommend jumping on the rail link into Bangkok.

Not just right. Being a huge fan of the BTS and MRT in Bangkok I have been disappointed with the Airport link.Two people can take a cab for the vsame price and not have to walk miles to get to either end.Cannot use your usual train passesMain station is a disaster, badly located and difficult to get to.Go to the end of the line and the link to the BTS is difficult with cases.This was a great idea badly instigated. Give it to the operators of the BTS or MRT to get it right.Is worthwhile in peak traffic but use the normal commuter option not the express

Another wonderful BKK edition. The Airport Rail Link is a wonderful edition to the Bangkok transport system not only for traveling to and from Subvarnabhumi Airport but as a commuter link. Cheap and efficient, I found it very useful when staying near Ramkhamheng Station linking to MRT at Phetburi. Please note that there is a lot of stairs encounter when leaving a station, entering has up escalators.
Quick and excellent. Brilliant and cheap way of getting into the city of Bangkok. Trains run regularly and the connections are good.

City/airport Rail link is perfect.. This is the cheapest way by far and is quite simple.Go to the Bottom floor of the Airport (Follow indicators) and buy your ticket there. Price was 45 Bath into Bangkok. Then when you get to the station in Bangkok City, get a taxi to your hotel. This is a very good (condition) and reliable service and compare with any European and USA standards.Taxi charge around 500 - 900 Bath and is expensive.I would recommend this service from and to the airport from anyone of the three stations in Bangkok City.

1/5 the cost of a taxi. Way cheaper than a Taxi and will get you into BKK, as quick, if not quicker. Once in the city you can transfer to the MRT or subway. It's clean, safe and we've had no surprises.

Convenient. Crowded at rush hour. Connects well to other rail systems in the city. Not recommended for first-time visitors to Bangkok. The orienteer should have little difficulty, but the maps available do not prove totally accurate.

Great Value though crowded in peak hour. Tickets only 45 baht to the Airport. Very quick service and you avoid traffic jams in peak hour. There is now a walkway link from the main station at Makasan to the MRT. Train could be tricky if you have big bags or hotel is not linked to the MRT / BTS.

Only way to travel to/from the airport in rush hour. For one or two people, it makes sense to take the train over a cab when the expressways are backed up. Be sure to take the new escalator and skybridge from the Petchaburi MRT station if you are entering/exiting from the Asoke area.

easy airport access. the airport link is very good and cheap but I think you need to be travelling light. the downside when you really want to use it at late arrives it has stopped running and you are at the mercy of taxi trouts.

Take the City Line or a Cab. We visited Bangkok twice during this trip, taking a cab once, and the airport link city line the second time. The cab was at around 0630 in morn, no traffic and the ride right to Sukhumvit at the city center put us back by 330 Baht which include 75 Baht toll, and 50 Baht airport charge. I was told that even with day time traffic it wouldn't exceed 400 Baht. The airport express line link would have put us back by 135 baht * 2, and then additional fair from Makassan to Asoke station - just not worth the hassle. The second time we tried the airport city line - at 45 baht per person, and went farther to Phaya Thai. We then took the MRT 5 stations further to Mo Chit which put us back further by another 35 baht per person or so. The day we travelled was a Sunday so busy with tourists and moreover was a day when the democratic party had called for a rally. So the trains were considerably crowded. Nevertheless the ride was comfortable. The ticketing was easy, directions easy to follow and the overall experience very reasonable

Fast and cheap. As my hotel is baiyoke sky that is so easy to get to this rail link. It takes us just 17 minutes to get to the airport. The fare I paid is 90 baht for the fast one and it's cheaper if you take the ordinary one. This is the best way to avoid the heavy traffic in downtown especially, when bangkok has a rally that blocked many major city roads.
Much better than taxi. Easy to access via BTS and relatively cheap. Better than taking a taxi. What more can I say with at least fifty characters?

Quick & affordable & reliable. If you have to connect from Suvurnabhumi airport to Dom Airport or the main city then this is really a quick & affordable mode than taking a bus or cab. cab will have 2 tolls and will increase your costing. I used it while connecting Suvurnabhumi airport from city & back to dom airport.

Great airport transit!. With this direct train link from Suvurnabhumi airport to Phaya Thai station, navigating Bangkok from the airport is made easy. You don't have to hail a cab and pay inflated fare. The trip to the airport to Phaya Thai station is faster than getting a cab as well. It will just take more or less 20-30 minutes and it only costs 48 baht.

Best way in and out of Bangkok. Brilliant, cheap (about £1) , quick (about half a hour) takes you to the skytrain in Bangkok where you can link up to many places, get a hotel near a skytrain station like we did and save a fortune on taxi fares!
Fast, easy comfortable. Fast transport from airport to city. No traffic jam, cheap. A must way to travel in Bangkok. Only look for a hotel near the station.

Fast, cheap and easy. No jam , no waiting. Took the airport rail city line on a Sunday 10am. Rail service located at basement of airport and easily accessible with travelator. Cost 40 baht per person only !! ( as compared to taxi) .Waited for 5 minutes for the train, understand that train comes every 15 minutes interval. Plenty of space for luggage as it is the first stop, train can get crowded at next few stop. We reached ratcharapok (6 stations in 20 minutes) , we have no problem lugging the luggage out as Thai people are so orderly. ( train door also don't close automatically as they have an attendant to ensure all commuters had alighted. We walked 10 minutes to hotel centara watergate pavilion .

Cheap n very convenient .... I am regret I din take it from airport to city. Which I spend 450 Thai bath from airport to city. After checked with my hotel reception. From pratunam to airport only cost 40 bath... Omg.. It's very different a lot. But the end I save 400 bath which I can do an hour Thai massage at airport.

Straight forward cheap and fast. This is the way to go to the airport. It's clean,fast,and incredibly quick. But ever so cheap too. Even when travelling as a family as most taxi cannot carry more than 3 because of their small boot.I really enjoy taking the airport link it takes 40 mins or so but very reliable!!

Fast and efficient. Reasonably priced, with regular trains to downtown, this is the best was to avoid the traffic. From the end station, it is easy to connect to the BTS to get to most places in the city.

Efficient and tourist friendly. The airport link is designed to make Bangkok tourist happy. I took the MRT from my hotel to Petchaburi then transferred to Makkasan for the express line to suvarnabhumi airport. There is now a new walkway/skybridge for tourist to take from Petchaburi to Makassan so no more walking on the street and crossing the dangerous highway. There is even a lift for passengers with huge bags. Fare for express line is 90 baht. Its quite confusing first but if you ask people they will help you and direct you towards the right ticket counter and and were to go next.

Best way to get to the city. If you try taking a taxi from Suvarnabhumi into the city it will easily cost you in the range of ฿400-฿500. However, when you land at the airport you can get right in the train station located inside the airport, pay ฿45, and get into the city a little while later. The Airport Rail Link connects to the SkyTrain at the Phayathai station, and the SkyTrain can get you around to a lot of Bangkok. It's an incredibly easy system, and far cheaper than a taxi. I'd definitely recommend the train to anyone arriving at BKK.Do be careful though, the night's last Airport Rail Link leaving the airport gets you to Phayathai after the SkyTrain has stopped running for the night. This means you get deposited at the Phayathai station with no onward train travel, and there are throngs of taxi drivers there ready to take advantage of your travel-wearied state. As anywhere in Bangkok, always demand that a taxi driver uses the meter; if the driver tells you the meter is broken, or tries to negotiate a rate beforehand, it means he's a shady person. Your best bet is to talk away from the station to Phayathai Road and flag down one of the taxis driving by rather than dealing with any of the taxis waiting to prey on people.

Excellent and cheap way to travel from Airport to City!. Airport rail link is a medium speed train that runs between the Airport and the city with limited number of stops. The train starts right under the Airport (you can take a lift down to reach here) and goes upto Phaya Thai station. Considering the Suvarnabhumi Airport is far from the city centre, this train is very useful for most tourists. I was staying at Royal Ivory Nana Resort near Nana Sky Train Station. The taxi from our hotel to airport was costing around 700 Baht. I took the Skytrain from Nana Station to Phaya Thai Station for 40 Baht and then easily changed to the Airport Rail Link. The entire journey from Phaya Thai Station to Suvarnabhumi station costs 45 Baht and took 45 minutes. Totally I spent 95 Baht from the hotel to airport which would have otherwise cost me 700 Baht in a taxi. Having backpacks is much better when travelling in this train. Though I had one roller bag and it was fine. The train is clean. Runs at a decent speed. The ticket machines are user friendly and very simple to use. If you are confused there is a guard to help you out. If your hotel is close to any BTS station and if you believe in saving some money on travelling, take this airport rail link. If you are a big family the taxi and airport link cost would turn out to be similar.
Cheap and good. The service is cheap for the city line though the frequency is a little too slow and trains tend to be packed by the 2nd station.

I may never take a taxi from Suvarnabhumi again. If your arrival time at Suvarnabhumi airport is between 6AM and 11:30 PM, and your hotel is near one of the BTS Skytrain stations, you might want to consider taking the train instead of a taxi. Taxis from the airport cost anywhere from 500 to 600 THB depending on traffic and "other charges" (the driver explained that they charge extra between midnight and 6 AM - not sure if that is bogus or not). My latest experience: Flying back from Phuket to BKK, I arrived at 4 PM. I took the Airport Rail Link (the City Line) all the way to the last stop at Phaya Thai, fare = 45 THB. I walked over to the BTS Skytrain and hopped on the next train to Asok station, fare = around 40 THB. The Park Plaza Hotel Sukhumvit was less than a five minute walk from the station. I was checked in and relaxing in my room around 5 PM. I do not know how long it would have taken in a taxi fighting Bangkok rush hour traffic - and with a meter running, that might end up being quite pricey.The trains are very clean. The ticket vending machines are pretty user friendly. It also helps if the nice lady in line behind you explains the system. :o) Of course, having a backpack instead of bulky rolling luggage makes it easier to transfer stations. And like in the NY subway (or any metro train), just have your wits about you and watch your valuables. For perspective: Coming from Sukhumvit back to the airport, I took a taxi. It was 3 AM and the trip took less than a half hour. The meter read: 197 THB. Go figure. (I gave the driver 300 THB. He looked real happy.)
So easy. Quick, easy, clean, cheap. I dream of the day when major US airports have public transit options as good as this. Forget traffic, hop on the train.

Challenging transfer. We have used Airport Rail Link for our past two visits to Bangkok and we are generally satisfied.If you are transferring to BTS at Phaya Thai, do note that you have to take another lift to the linkway level "I". From there it is a short walk to the BTS station, no problem if you have bags as there is an escalator going up to the platform. The challenge would come when you reach the station you are alighting, as there is likely no elevator nor escalator serving the platform to the concourse. If you are a parent with big luggage and baby-stroller, it could be a challenge with the stairs.City Line operates at intervals of 15 minutes while Express Link is an hour.

We used it a lot. We stayed at a hotel at one of the stations so we used this a lot. It is important to know it is NOT part of the BTS Skytrain. Because others referred to it as Skytrain, we booked our hotel on this line. It was not a disaster but we probably would have stayed elsewhere had we realized itOne perk of this was that we were able to get the "elder" stored value card for the ARL which was about half fare which is only available to Thai Citizens on the BTS. (You can get an Adult stored value card called Rabbit Card on the BTS - no discount but still simplifies the process)These trains are clean and fast. Many places here tell you not to take the "local" ARL from the airport but we never took the express which did not stop at our hotel and never saw people with luggage problems. The local is called the City Line and runs much more often than the Express. The time saved and extra cost isn't worth it. City Line is Blue and Express is red. Otherwise you get both at the same station.which is lowest level of the airport. Just follow the signs which are in English and Thai. Stations are clearly announced and also show on a TV screen.My one BIG complaint was that at our station - Ramkhamhaeng - BOTH the elevator and escalator down were closed for work. We never saw anyone working on them. We were there t the end of Oct at the beginning of our trip and again a month later at the end and the closings remained with no work apparently being done.

Beat the jam!. Airport Rail Link is the best answer to beat the notorious Bangkok traffic jam. The company's website is very informative.The fare starts from THB15 to THB45, all the way to Phaya Thai. By comparison, the Airport Rail at Kuala Lumpur's airport is so expensive, you are better off with a taxi. The Rail Link at Suvarnabhumi is frequent and decent.Any city dwellers with experience with subway systems will find Bangkok rail system similar. The ticket machines are located near station office where you can change your notes to coin. Take note of certain machines that does not accept coins or those that accepts exact amount.Be aware though that in some parts of the downtown rail system, you will have to climb staircase.

Let the train take the strain. Used this both ways this time from the Airport in central Bangkok. 30 minute train ride to avoid the traffic jams then a very quick taxi ride to the hotel. Would use the train again.

A fast way to get Bangkog from the airport( Suvarnabhmi).. A very good way to get from the airport (Suvarnabhmi) to Bangkogs center. In Bangkog it tends to be quite long traffic jams. Airport link goes above the street and not stop in traffic jams. At the same time you can enjoy the view.It is also a cheap way to get to the center.

Cheapest fare you can get. After being told at the airport that it would cost 2200 baht for a taxi to my hotel close to MBK I decided to take the Airport Rail Link instead. I was surprised at how cheap it was approx 60 baht to my first stop and then transferring to the sky train and one more transfer until eventually my last stop National Stadium which is the very last stop. All up it cost 120 baht. The rail link is so good very quick to your destination you're guaranteed a seat at the airport. It's a cheap quick alternative. I had my backpack and a shoulder bag which were manageable. If you have a lot of luggage a taxi maybe the better option.

Fast, clean and cheap from the airport to Bangkok Center. Normally when we arrive in Bangkok or we have to go to the airport to return home, we take a limousine of the hotel. This limo cost a 1000 bath one way. So when we arrived in Bangkok in the beginning of november we ordered a limo to take us from the airport to the hotel.But when we left Bangkok a week later, we took the Airport Train Link to go to the airport. This is a very easy and cheap way to travel to the airport. We'll use this way of transport when we come back to Bangkok.

Quick and cheapr. Getting from BKK to town has long been a hassle, arguing with taxi drivers, alternately roaring along at mad speeds, then getting stuck in traffic. No more. The airport express whips you into the centre of town in about 20 minutes for 90 bhat.No more taxis for me!

Excellent, fast and cheap. Makkasan can be avoided. The Airport Rail Link is well connected to Bangkoks Sky Train system. Yes, the connection to the subway (MRT) at Makkasan is less than ideal, but I guess it is only 150 m, not nearly as far as some other commentators say. The last time I was in Bangko there was even a little bus - but I walked, it is so close.The price is almost ridiculously low (in contrast to a similar connection in Kuala Lumpur).

Fast, convenient, cheap . Use this to get to the city centre and vice versa. Change at mamaksan mrt in order to get to sukhumvit or lumpini. I found this rail which was operated by the State Railway of Thailand to be the best way to get to the airport. It was so convenient and the stations are all sheltered as well. It costs less than 100 baht if u choose this instead of the airport express.

Extremely convenient. Bangkok have got the airport transfer perfect. From the airport to Phaya Thai which makes it very easy to get on the BTS and MRT along the way. Very cheap (45baht) to the end of the line. All the staff are extremely helpful and the automatic ticketing system is very straight forward.

Great Just Great. No traffic jams. SHORT TIME And center of Bangkok.. was at the end of October. Connection in Bkk 7 hours. Had 2-3 full hours in Bangkok. Great value. Just fast train is one in 30 minutes.

Quick trip to centre of town. great if you have limited baggage and are staying close to the centre of town. I was impressed with how fast we travelled. also would highly recommend for backpackers or budget travellers that are staying further out of town as it connects to sky train which connects to MRT. So most places accesible

Closest and Friendliest access from airport to tourist destinations. This line is one of the inexpensive and easiest access from airport going to the tourist destinations at the heart of Bangkok. If you are travelling on a backpack, this is the recommended mode of transportation for you going to the city proper.The terminal is conveniently located at the basement of Suvarnabhumi Airport. The rail link has two lines: the Red and the Blue. The difference between the two links is that the Red is the express line where it doesn't have any stops from airport to Makkasan station. Fare is higher compared to the other line (around THB 150). The Blue is the regular train, with fare ranges from THB 15-45. Compared to taxi ride from airport to city proper, I highly recommend riding the Airport Link not only for convenience, but also to save your Baht for your other travelling needs :)

Highly recommended 9/10. Cheap and quickest way to get to Bangkok city centre. Tickets cost just 45 baht and the trains are very clean. You will find lots of signs to guide you to the train. Otherwise there is lots of helpful friendly staff. Only minus- Train can get very busy during rush hour!

Quick and cheap. The easiest and the cheapest way to travel to Central Bangkok is taking the Airport Rail from Suvarnabhoomi Airport. It takes about 30mins to reach and is definitely the fastest way to get to the city especially if you travelling in the peak hours of morning or evening, when the traffic jams can go for miles.

Easy to use. Can't believe more people don't use this easy mode of transport to access Bangkok from the airport. My husband and I visited recently and decided to use it. We have been to Bangkok many times and always used taxis with limited success because of the traffic. It is in the basement of the main airport. Tip - take the lift down. We went via the escalators as we didn't really know how far it was. The guards and train officers were most helpful making sure we knew where we going and what station to stand on. We had to change twice to get the sky train to our hotel but found it all pretty easy as our hotel was connected to the sky train - Eastin Grand- can also recommend.

Pretty horrible. Its only reasonably ok if you are a solo traveller, staying somewhere next to a BTS or MRT station and have no luggage. If not, then it's pretty worthless. Not sure what the previous reviewer was talking about but you'd have to travel pretty far to pay 300 / 500 baht for a taxi. Airport to main Sukhumvit area should be about 200 baht. If you have luggage (like any regular traveller) it's always much better to take a taxi (that takes you straight to your door or hotel). If the taxi from the airport tries to scam you and not use a meter, get out and take the next taxi. If anyone thinks 200 baht is expensive, try getting a taxi to town anywhere else in the world for about $6 US.

better than taxis. the minute you step out of the airport you can buy a ticket for the train which connected us to the hotel in sukhumvit.it was fast ,and better than the road journey ,where there are snarls .one has to change the train at one stop so better you do not have too much luggage

Best way to get from Airport. I have been to Bangkok four times and usually arrive in the evening and a taxi to Sukhumvit area was only 300B and little traffic. However of late prices have gone up of late and now the going rate is 500b. For about 40 baht or 90 baht express you can get the train to Phaya Thai or wherever it is you are going.Very cheap and quick to get from airport and run regularly. Can be a little crowded at times if you don't mind standing.If you are budgeting and don't mind having to switch trains to BTS once you arrive for your onward journey, possible standing up and then having to cart your luggage down stairs and through busy streets to your hotel (no lifts or escalators at BTS stations) then is the go.Would not recommend a taxi between the hours of 8am - 7pm but if you can get it cheaply or sharing with someone it is more convenient

Convenient, fast and cheap way of transport. The Airport Rail link is a very good way of travelling to and from the airport to the city. If you dont have much luggage to carry then it is the best and cheapest way to commute. You can also get connecting station to Sky train and MRT and you reach any place in Bangkok.
Quick and convenient. if all you have is a carry-on and you are headed for downtown, this is the fastest, cheapest and most efficient means to get to the center of town. Connects to the BTS.
No need for a taxi . Cheaper and faster than a taxi with a good air-con. Links onto many other rail/bus services. All clearly sign posted. 5*

Fast, convenient, cheap. The rail link to the airport is sensational as long as you don't have an excess of luggage. I was only travelling with cabin luggage and a computer and found this the best way of getting to my hotel. No traffic jams, less than 1/2 the price of a taxi and a comfotable seat all the way. You do have to make a train change to get to your hotel on Sukhumvit but again this is quick and easy. I would only say that I would only use the train if my Sukhumvit hotel was close to a sky train station

Hassle Free. This is a life saver of stress, for many years landing into Bangkok was a hassle dealing with queues of people waiting for taxies and then pay for all the toll fees on top of the taxi fare and they would still want to rip you off, and if you didn't want to wait you could get a taxi that was not on the taxi rank would refuse to turn on his meter and might try to rob you as well, the rail link from the Airport to city center is a god send you just use the interchange at Phaya Thai Station to where ever you want to go in the city, totally stress free and very cheap about 50 Bhat to city center if you can always you this transport system to the city.

Avoid the Traffic and Taxis. If you are arriving at Suvarṇabhumī airport and need to transit into central Bangkok then the airport rail link is the ONLY way to go. With a travel time of 30 - 35 minutes this can beat the taxi travel time by a significant amount outside peak hour and even more so during peak. In addition, the cost is considerably less (<50 Baht) and the train is air conditioned and comfortable. You can also transfer on the BTS rail system (skytrain) at Phaya Thai station for other destinations throughout Bangkok.

Not perfect, but so much safer than travelling by taxi.. I've been using the airport rail link since it opened. Before I travelled by taxi but now I always use the rail link. I travel from/to Phayathai/Airport and have not used any of the intermediate stations. At 45 Baht it is a bargain, neatly avoids the very real dangers of Bangkok taxi drivers and connects with the Bangkok Mass Transit Systems (Phayathai is also a Skytrain station). It runs every 10-20 minutes and takes something around 30 minutes.There is ample room on the train for baggage. There is also an "express" which costs a little more and runs on the same track, but seems to run less frequently. If you are in a rush then check which train leaves first - no point in paying extra for the "express" and then waiting half an hour before it departs.No trolleys for baggage - drag it or carry it.Lots of stairs. Escalators are up only.There is ONE elevator at Phayathai, but as with many such things in Bangkok, it's too small & too slow, and as far as I recall does not operate from street level (only between the intermediate level and the upper level) and so is more of a symbol than a practical facility.The timetable is here:http://bangkokairporttrain.com/time-table-route.html, but treat it as a rough guide only and don't depend on the last train to get you to the airport.Be aware: my last visit was Sep 2013 & the ticket machines could not take the latest Baht 20 notes.I've rated this 4 out of 5. I'd have given 5 if there had been better disabled access and better facilities for travelling with baggage.
Easiest and cheapest way. It is the best way to go to the city from or to the BKK airport. Comfortable and clean in about 30 minutes you can reach skytrain station in the center of Bangkok.

Quick and convenient. It was very easy to go to Bangkok. We took the express train from Airport station straight to Phaya Thai station, which we transfer to BTS straight to Phloen Chit Station. It is quick and convenient. So when we returned, we took the same route (to save on cab fare). We took the normal service which we need to stop for 6 stops before reaching the Airport station, still it was OK. I will take this service again for my next trip to Bangkok
Quick cheap and easy. The best way to get into city centre. 30 minute ride will get you to a skytrain station where you can get a connection to most areas.

beat the traffic. Bangkok airport to city express train to the city would be up with the best in any major city.Get off the plane, go through the usual 'checks and balances' jump on the express train to the centre of Bangkok, about 20 minutes travel time. Miss the traffic which can be horrendous. At the end of the express line, about a 200 m walk and catch the bts skytrain. Both the BTS skytrain and the MRT underground are great services to get around Bangkok. Maps of the system are available at most stations and easy to follow. Various passes are available for periods and cheap. Just be aware some skytrain stations only have stairs so can be a problem with baggage. Some have lifts but you have to find an attendant to operate them.

Very convenient. Quick and easy way to get into town from the airport as long as the line is close to your hotel. Taxis directly fro the airport are not much more than the taxis within the city if you are an obvious tourist.
Great choice. We used Airport rail link this time. It's not bed, even though we had a small problem to find the connection to BTS. Overall is excellent if your hotel is pretty close to the station.

Very fast and comfortable. Airport link is very fast and relatively cheap way to get to the international airport of Bangkok.
Higly recommended!

First Time. Normally use taxis to get to airport, but thought this time would try the Airport Link. Missed the express train so got on the slower train but this was still quicker and cheaper (about THB 40 each I think) and we were there within 15 minutes. Pleasantly surprised and will definitely use again.

very efficient, cheap and fast. Like the rest of the MRT, very efficient, cheap and fast way to get to the city center from the airport and vice-versa. Has connection to the train and to the Skytrain.
The bus would be cheapper but this is a quicker transport and a lot more comfortable.
Accessible to Pratunam area. The train is 30-35 minutes to Pratunam area. You can alight at the station before Phaya Thai. Else you can take express direct train to Makassan station.

Very good deal. I went from the airport to the Makkasan terminal and then changed on to the MRT system.Nobody on this service and yet it is super efficient and clean.If you have baggage or are aged this is not for you but if you can walk a bit this is the real deal.I saved a few hundred baht over the taxi fare and it was quiet ,cool and clean.If you are not bagged down or bagged out and can physically walk a bit this is a very good deal.The Thais were very friendly and helpful promoting this service.
Superfast journey. Saved a lot of time during our return journey towards Suvarbhumi Int'l Airport. Fast, Less crowd & no worries of traffic. Despite heavy baggage didn't have trouble due Escalator.

Connectivity and fastness at its core. Sky train is almost everywhere in Bangkok and the best ways to commute, if your hotel is near to the station. It takes enormous time getting down the stairs carrying your luggage. Please dont mistake and climb up or down on a manual steps, each station has an escalator. So find one for you. * Connectivity timings is amazing and you will not wait for a long time to get a train. * Train is superfast and dont have the issue of getting stuck in traffic, as via road is pretty tiresome, as traffic is heavy. The other best way of transport is Bell Services - http://www.belltravelservice.com/pages/PageHome.aspx which offers intra city and inter city transfers. Also refer to the FAQ: How to get from the AIRPORT to your HOTEL on tripadvisor http://www.tripadvisor.com/Travel-g293915-c116554/Thailand:From.Bangkok.Airport.To.Hotel.htmlThis would make your travel happy and planful. Happy Journey folks :)
Awesome metro, fast and clean!. I took the metro from Suvarnabhumi to Ramkhamhaeng and return. Its spacious, less crowded and very fast. I had no problems getting on and off with 2 luggages

Express Line 15-20 minutes to Airport. Express Line- Good for express service!!- shorten the time - avoid the traffic - price is okCity Line - too much people after office hours, most of office worker use for their transportation back home. To avoid lots of people, don't go after 6 PM. - 8 PM.Staff can advice about the time exactly!

Avoid the traffic. If you have a small luggage and the hotel you booked, is closed to skytrain, that is very convenient. But remember! you have the challenge is to carry a luggage up and down, between the station of ARL and BTS.

Need Improvement. I am Thai and I want to be straight with our guest.-The connection with BTS and MRT is not so good. -No escalator at Phayathai Station. -The train neither run on early morning nor late night. -Delay is quite common Type of train:1. Express Train- Pro: Stop only at Phayathai, Makkason and Airport- Cons: Do not come often.2. City Line:- Pro: Come rather often. 15 minutes is considered 'often' for this train. - Cons: Train stop at all stations. It take longer time to-from airport. It could be crowded even on weekend. Good News:1. They are working on connection with MRT. 2. They are adding escalator at Phayathai Station.

ARL Airport Express. Bought a ticket to Phaya Thai Station at THB45 upon arrival in Suvarnabhumi Airport and not many tourist utilise the express train. The rail is similar to MRT in Singapore except shorter cabin and there is a automatic door separating each cabin. The rail were clean and fast. It passes a few stations before reaching Phaya Thai where I need to be transferred onto the BTS towards Ratchathewee. The challenge is to carry/ drag the lugguage down the steps upon arrival at the platform at Phaya Thai Station. There is railing leading to the road where you need to walk some distance to Phaya Thai BTS station. Next is to carry/ drag the luggage up the stairs leading to the station and down the steps again when arriving at Ratchathewee station. I will only take the ARL Airport Express again if there is no big luggage to go up and down the steps at the different stations.

Convenient, good price. Pros: The most convenient way of getting to the town from the Suvarnabhumi airport if you are staying somewhere on Sukhumvit or Silom Road. No need to go outside of airport building, just few floors down. Easy to buy tickets using machines. There are always some officers offering help at info desk. Train is very modern, clean and air conditioned. Lots of space for baggage. Cons: you cannot buy one ticket from airport to Asok station for example. You have to buy one ticket to Phaya Thai station and then you have to buy another ticket to Asok. This can be improved. :: If you are staying on Khao San Road (near Grand Palace) then this option is not suitable for you.

very convenient and fast. in my opinion, it is the fastest, easiest and most convenient way from the airport to the city. Especially at peak traffic time. You can change at two different locations in the BTS (the elevated train) and passes so fast and cool (air conditioning) in different Areas of the city. Not really cheap - the public bus is the cheapest alternative, but compared to the taxis have to struggle through the traffic much, much better! And quickly at every time too...

Convenient and Cheap if have small luggage. We used the airport rail link between Phutunam and Suvarnabhumi International Airport (BKK). Compare to the taxi, this is cheapest and fastest way to Suvarnabhumi International Airport. It avoid traffic jam which alway happen in the Bangkok. Me and my wife use only 80 baht (40baht/pax) for one way to our hotel. Very much recommended to use this to travel to and back from the airport. However, the station is not suitable use for large and heavy luggage, due to you have carry the luagage a bit because the elevator not available.

Convenient that any other option/if have small luggage. It is in the basement of Suvarnabhumi airport BKK. Just go downstairs through escalator or lift in the basement you will find the station just pick the ticket and you are in train for journey. Choose the Blue line it is cheap only 35bath from APT to city payathai here you can change with BTS Skytrain to the major city. Other option is red line that is expensive and connect APT to Makassan direct and here you may choose taxi for onwards or MRT line which is far beyond and you may not carry your big luggage still then.

Super mode of transport from airport. Used the airport rail link to get to Sukhumvit for the first time and found it to be cheap and very comfortable. Very much recommended to use this to travel to and back from the airport.

Fast Cheap and Safe. This is the eastiest way to reach down town of Bangkok from Suvarnabhumi airport...which is easy connected to Bts Sky train station..also Mrt in Makkasan Station...but you gotta walk about 5 minuites to Mrt...still convenient. If you are not much hurry better take city line, cuz it is very cheap only 45 baht compare to taxi.. And in the station area is quite clean and safe. Recommend for every traveler.

Thank heavens for airport link!. I like its location just few minutes from my apartment very convenient, affordable and best of all by riding on it you will avoid traffic jams in the way to and from the airport. You can predict the time you will arrive. What I don't like is the link closes at 12 midnight. Usually my flights arrives at 12 so I cannot catch the last train. I hope they will extend the time to 1am.

good but expensive. The Airport Link skytrain is by far the cheapest, quickest and easiest way to get to the airport.It's quite expensive though, so don't use it to get around the city, a taxi will be cheaper.

Forget the 200baht taxi ride use this!. I wish it was 24/7 but it stops running around 1am but if you need to get into or out of Bkk then this is the fastest way without worrying about the traffic in Bang Kapi. It ends at Phraya Thai and that stop is in between Victory monument and Siam Paragon.

What a mess!. Still has paper signs all over the stations, how many years after it was finished?
No cover from rain at the link between Makkasan station and Petchburi MRT so if it's raining you get drenched and near run over crossing a major road.
I think Tarzan and his apes designed this mass transit system

Perfect! No reason to take the cab if your hotel is nearby a station. Best possible standard. No problems. Airconditioned. The Thais have invested in transportation. Not just the Airport Rail Link, but also the Skytrain and the Metro are all top-notch. Much better, in fact, than in some European cities.

Very efficient and reliable way to move. I wish there was an Airport Rail link from our other international airport (DMK) here in Bangkok because some times I just book a flight from BKK because of the Rail Link being so convenient to get in or out of town. Not only is it cheap, but at rush hour, when you see the taxis just crawling, you are zipping by in a nice A/C train without any worries about missing your flight. Coming from BKK the link is also very convenient because it links you to the BTS, which in turns also links you to the MRT so you have pretty much the whole city at your disposal.

my preferred transport from the airport. easy, fast and cheap way of going to the city from the airport! my friends and i have our baggage with us but the airport link is still the fastest and most comfortable option for us to go to our hotel in sukhumvit. compared to a normal travel time of 1hr with taxi ride and fare of 300 baht, the 60baht airport link plus bts trip of 45mins is certainly the best deal.
easy to go to APT and express. good option to use APT Rail Link there have express train and normal train to go to APT and Siam Area and many hotel around platform

Empty. At 10:00 am I was the sole occupant of the airport express 100 THB from Suv. airport to Makkasan terminal. Carried my luggage with me. Very comfortable train with separate luggage racks. At Makassan the huge station was almost deserted. A couple of thai youths followed me. Came to the bottom level and asked for a cab. No cabs around. One cab asked for THB 150 to go to nearby Pratunam. When I insisted on meter he drove away. Next cab after 5 min also flat price, then went by meter cost THB 60 only.

Stress free transport to the city. We liked nearly everything about this service - speed, cleanliness, price, excellent assistance by transport police & ticket personnel & the easy transfer to the BTS (sky train). We have been to Bangkok many times & after long flights from somewhere else have been frustrated by the extra time added to our journey by sitting in a taxi or airport bus for up to an hour getting to our hotel.This new link is excellent & we highly recommend it.

Excellent. Fantastic what a simple way to get to the airport, 90thb takes about 20 mins. Air-con & very nice, much better sitting in a taxi with drivers that doing know where there going & much cheaper.

Not "Express" if you must wait an hour. The last time I tried taking the Express Train I was told that it would be an hour until the next train was leaving, and this was around 11:30 a.m. on a weekday. I walked over to the city line and saw that it would be a 20 minute wait for that train so I ended up taking a taxi to the airport.Now I will only use the train from the airport, not to the airport. When arriving at the airport in Bangkok there are so many taxi drivers that try to cheat you so I will take the train instead. If you go downstairs to the official taxi line there is a good chance you will get a taxi with a turbo meter. After the third time this happened I stopped using the taxi line and will only take a taxi from the arrivals area that I see dropping off a passenger. If you do take a taxi from the arrivals area be sure not to take one of the taxis that's already sitting there. Those drivers are part of the taxi mafia and have paid off the police in order to park there, and they will then rip you off. But if you see a driver dropping off a passenger you should take that taxi. Those drivers are usually very happy to have a customer for their drive back to the city and shouldn't try to rip you off.When in Bangkok you will never want to take a taxi that is parked. They are always the ones that will rip you off. Always flag down a moving taxi and you will have much better luck.

Leave extra time. It's great, fast, and convenient to get to the airport using the Rail Link and way cheaper than a taxi, but doesn't always come as often as claimed. make sure to leave extra time so you don't miss your flight!

Save Some Money & Time. I visited Bangkok many times, always used taxi form airport to reach city center and paid 400~600 THB for one way, also waste a lot of time, normally more than 1 hour to reach to siam square, where I normally stay.This time just followed sign boards at airport and reach to railway station of airport rail link, important points as below1. just keep going down using escalators to bottom level2. walk to the ticking machine and use 35THB coins/notes3. wait for train, which I think come after each 15 mins4. last stop is PAYATHAI, leave this train & change to upper level for next train5. buy another ticket, for where you want to go, around 10~15 THB & enjoy Total time form airport to siam square, was 35 mins, including the time to wait for train, and change of trains, its extremely convenient and cheaper than taxiI love to travel in bangkok sky train, even I saw many tourist families traveling in this train.

A fast and safe way to get to your destination. I loved the link because the Express train takes only 17 minutes from the airport to PhayaThai station and then one can take the BTS. The Express train runs every 30 minutes, so if you have bad luck you may have to wait quite some time. Further, from the PhayaThai station to the BTS platform, the walk is a bit long and you must go down stairs (not great if you have heavy luggage. However, I prefer the Express tain in combination with the BTS system over taking a taxi, mainly because the taxi drivers drive extremely fast on the freeway, no seat belts are available and the heavy traffic once you reach the city.

Not only cheaper but much FASTER than taxi. Traffic can be appalling in Bangkok, so the most reliable way to go is using the Airport Rail Link. You can get a express ticket, or regular - I've only taken the regular. Combined BTS and link, leaving from the Sukhumvit area, takes less than an hour. Note: the BTS and link involve stairs and a little bit of a walk between each other, so if you're not up for that, best go for an early taxi (in which you ALWAYS ask for meter on, and take highway, if they hesitate to put meter on, get out)

Easy and quick way to travel.. This is the best way to travel into central Bangkok when you arrive, or when you are returning to the airport after your holiday. Very cheap and safe. Don't get ripped off by taxis.

Clean, safe, fast.... Highly recommended even for the first express trip to BKK from airport. Just follow airport signage to the airport-rail-link [ARL] to city. Get the free official airport map from the tourist desk at airport, it's real helpful. Express ARL trains run about every 15 minutes. Approx 17-20 minutes express to city [Makkasan station] which is most convenient if you are staying in the Sukhumvit area nearby. Then hop on taxi to hotel. No more 45 - 50 minute stressful rides in taxi to city in traffic jams, heat and no more 900 - 1200Thb fares to hotel from Suvarnabhumi airport. ARL suitable for families too. Safe. Clean. Fast. Cheap [about 35Thb pp, one way express].

Convenient, fast, accessible. Pity about the punctuality.. Great way to head to town from the airport. Fast, clean and cheap. Travelled with family lugging a huge suitcase and realised that it is rather difficult as the Phaya Thai train station connection to the BTS involved walking up and down staircases.Suggestion is to take the express train to Phaya Thai as it easily connects to the BTS. Just a pity that it wasn't punctual as I was waiting for the 1200hrs train and in the end, it left the airport at 1247 hrs.

Ideal way into the city. Having used taxis from both Don Mueang and now Suvanarbhumi, this is a great way into the city.Trains are clean and frequent - about every 15 mins - and amazingly cheap if using the slower City Line. Each time I've used it, the train has been very busy which is a bit of a nuisance with luggage, but go with it and adopt the Thai attitude of "sabai, sabai". I always use the Makkasan terminal which, as another reviewer has pointed out is near, but not next to, the Phetchaburi MRT station, which requires travellers to make their way across a road and a railway track to reach it, though it appears that a connecting bridge is being built. (This is Thailand - don't expect UK / US style joined up thinking!!)Makassan itself is a strange bard like place, not easy to find your way around, but there are people to ask.Cheaper and quicker than a taxi, I'll continue to use this.

Convenient and cheap!. This is a fantastic way to get from the international airport to Phaya Thai (center of town),There you can either transfer to the BTS or hop in a taxi. If you don't have much luggage it is very easy to navigate the airport rail link and BTS.

Inexplicably bad management of the service. Makkasan city air terminal in Bangkok is a disgrace. A huge cathedral of a building that is obviously built for future passenger projections, at the moment it is an empty cavern. It signage is hopelessly inadequate - obviously no manager has ever tried to follow the signs and see if they make sense. However, what is worst of all is that Makkasan is situated amid an already crumbling external infrastructure - the paving/walkway is in a shocking condition considering it is so new, with uneven and loose paving slabs ready to trip you up. There IS an MRT (underground) station nearby, but at the time of writing, the only way to get there is to lug your bags over the uneven paving and across a busy road junction (in a poorly lit area at night). There WILL be a footbridge connecting the two stations at some point - it looks as if it is nearing completion, but the fact that it has taken three years since Makkasan was opened is a joke.As the Express trains are less frequent than the stopping city trains, you will be directed to City Line trains some times - and if you have luggage, it will be a nightmare as these trains are very crowded. If you are able to get an Airport Express service, these trains have nicer seats and room for your bags.If you are coming FROM Bangkok Suvernabhumi Airport, good luck finding the entrance to the Express line. All the signs will direct you to the City Line (stopping train entrance) and if you don't know about the Express line you probably won't find it.Be sure you know which Express service you are going to take - either the one to Makkasan's city air terminal, or the one to Phayathai. Get on the wrong one and life will be even more complicated.At the moment, my best advice would be to get an AOT limo when you arrive at the airport. For a relatively low fee you will get to Bangkok in comfort.

Use it!. The airport rail link is one of the best piece of infrastructure built. The rail provides a direct link from airport to the city centre. You can choose either the Express service (THB90 per person) which is exclusive and one-stop, or use the City service (THB45) which operates like any rail service and makes about 8-9 stops along the way. Overall, use it and forget the taxis.

Easy way to central of Bangkok. When you arrive bangkok with your bag just only one and not too much bags, the airport rail link is the best way to take you from Suwnnaphumi Airport to Center of Bangkok.Just only 15 minutes by express train to Phayathai station ang 30 mins by normal train. On ground floor at Suwannaphumi airport with cheap ticket that you can buy fom ticket box to take you to cnter.

So convenient and cheap. If your hotel is close to the train line from the airport do itCost me 40 baht $1.35au instead of 300 baht $10.50au via TaxiGo to level 2 and DO IT! ( if you get through before midnight)Open 6am-midnight

Saves a lot of time and effort.. Road travel in Bangkok can be tiring. The traffic is bad, specially in peak hours. I believe, that the ARL, BTS and MRT, along with the Water Taxi's make Bangkok a city with great public transportation.The ARL is great way to get into the city from Suvarnabhumi Airport. Take the city train to Phayathai, and then change over to the interconnecting BTS (Sukhumvit Line). Its also very good to get to areas like Pratunam or Ramkhamhaeng, if you are staying on Sukhumvit Road, or Silom, as the BTS interchanges with the ARL at Phayathai, and the MRT at Makassan.Its fairly reasonable, and the ticketing staff, though they don't speak very good English, try to help. Even the security guards help, and the entire experience of the Airport Rail Link is easy, smooth, convenient and pretty comfortable too.

It's good. This is a nice simple option to get I and out of Suvaranbhumi if you don't have luggage. Be aware it doesn't go to Don Muang where Air Asia flights & some other International flights leave.If the taxis make you nervous I would recommend it. However you may need to get a taxi to your final destination.Clean, safe & efficient.Separately for the adventurous, Don Muang can be reached by mainline train. From Hualamphong to Donmuang can take as little as 45 minutes. However, if you are in a rush then avoid it.All trains on the Northern branch stop there, then it is a walk to the terminal, through the airport hotel. Current fare 5b and a fascinating journey through the back of Bangkok.

The only way. This is the only sensible way to the airport if you stay along the BTS skytrain line. You get on the airport rail link from one of the BTS stations - Phayathai. At this moment, the non-stop express train to the airport has been terminated and only the city link, which makes several stops and carries largely city commuters, is available. It is crowded and uncomfortable as it has just long steel benches for seats. But it is cheap - at just 45 baht (US$1.50, but expensive for daily office workers). The journey takes half-an-hour point to point. At the station (Phayathai), there are only escalators going up but not down. So if you arrive from the airport, you'd have to take the stairs down dragging your luggage. There are no facilities for travelers as it seems to be built for commuters.

Nice transportation into the city. You can take the express or the city train. Express is faster but sometimes it's on an hourly schedule. City train is about twice as long (45 mins I think) but runs more frequently. TIP: check the schedule before you buy a token to see how long until the next express train.First trip, i hopped a cab at Makkasan and went right to my hotel. Second trip however, when I got to Makkasan station, it was rush hour and there were no cabs.I had to hoof it a few blocks to the MRT station and take the MRT to Soi 24 where I walked to my hotel pulling my bad. A local suggested going a station or two beyond Makkasan (I think Phaya Thai) to catch a cab.Otherwise this is much better than fighting Bangkok traffic all the way to your destination in a taxi.

Superb and convenient service. Liked :Relatively easy to find on the lowest level. If in doubt, ask any airport staff.Inexpensive and speedy, frequent service to Bangkok.Disliked :Lack of signage and inconvenient distance and location of Phetchaburi Underground station, from Makkasan airport rail link station. Solution : Ask pleasant cheerful station staff.

Easy to use, but not much better than just taking MRT. Ont our return to the airport, we decided to just take the MRT to the airport. It was cheaper and did not arrive much later than the 'Airport Express.' I did not really see the advantage to taking a special Airport train. Of course, it's much better than playing games with Bangkok traffic.

Simple travel. I liked the fact that I no longer have to dice with traffic, taxis or AOT limos to get between airport and the city centre. I disliked the fact that the train is as basic as the MRT or BTS - those plastic seats are horribly uncomfortable after 45 minutes. And the train is often packed, with many passengers travelling between stations on the line, or being staff at the airport. Most of the air passengers I saw seemed to be the more budget travellers. Still, fastest way into town - and out of town. The connection with MRT at Makkasan/Phetchaburi is awful though. While signposted, still have to drag suitcase a long way, across a rail way crossing, and down a very badly broken street. Next time I went to the end of the line at Phaya Thai, and used BTS instead.

On time, no long queus comfortable ride, traffic jam avoider. For the distance they bring you, it is cheap and comfortable. Avoiding the traffic jam is its best feature and time spend in travelling minimal.

Convenient yet economy. I would say it's the most convenient yet economy way for you to go town if you are getting down at suvarnabhumi airport. Although it's not a non stop train direct to town, as long as you just get down from the last stop and you will find there is a BTS station connected to this train.

Take the train.. Although it only operates every half hour, the train into town (Phaya Thai station) is cheap and fast. It helps you to avoid the horrible traffic at rush hour, and connects easily to the BTS. Use the Makkasan station if you want to connect to the metro.

Convenient and easy. Been to many airports and I think this is one of the easier connection to catch. There are signs to point you to the airport rail link. Girl at info counter was not very helpful but there were very friendly people around to help you out.We took the slower connection with quite a number of stops along the way. Not a problem since we were on holiday. However as the train approaches the city centre, it got more crowded, so if you have more than one luggage or a big luggage, maybe clumsy. At the last stop we hopped into the sky train to our hotel. Do note that there are stairs to climb so not for those with heavy luggages. Will take train again if travelling light.
Excellent train system. There were announcements in Thai language and also English.Very useful and helpful for tourists.The ticket counter was very smiley too.

Easy to find, easy to use. Easy to find, easy to use, research your hotel location before you go, this could easily be your best option to get into town. We caught the normal city line as it was ready when we arrived downstairs, there is an info booth which will let you know whether the express platform of the city platform are the go at that minute. City line stops at about 8 or so stations before reaching Phaya thai, the end of the line.
15 minutes to town!. Beat all traffic jams! But note that the MRT at Makkasan is out of the station and across the road on the left.

Very thankful to have the Airport Rail Link system. The female staff at ARL Phaya Thai station is a gem, and so thankful for her help with our heavy luggages. The system is a breeze, efficient and really economical, from Suvarnabhumi Airport to city center and vice versa, is less than 30mins per route!So glad to have this transport system, in a city where it is famous for bad traffic.

CONFUSING. We could not figure out where to get out to best connect to a taxi to our hotel - directions were all in Thai, and the map is not shown over a map of the city so you don't know where you are when first using it.
Fast and easy. Its quick and airconditioned, and avoids the express way traffic.If you are travelling reasonably light this is a great way to get into town.
Bangkok Subway. This is a very good mode of tranportation for those who just arrived in Bangkok. It's just a couple of minutes of ride to the other linked trains going around the city proper.

easy access to & from the centre of BKK. So much easier than getting a taxi. A pleasant ride right to the airport. Trains run on time and are clean and comfortable.
Not available to Don Muang airport though.

The best option to travel to airport. No jams like the taxis are always stuck in jam, particularly in wee office hours. Better to board the Airport link and in 20 minutes you can reach the destination without jam and moreover you can look around the Bangkok.
Quick and easy. Cheapest way to get in and out Bangkok. Stroller friendly too. Highly recommend over a cab or bus. Air con too.
Excellent. For a few pounds you can get straight into Bangkok and the surrounding area very easy on this air conditioned train
Perfect. Really easy and cheap (50 bath). Very quick and easy to use if you have to go near a skytrain station.

cheapest and convenient way to reach city. i use airport rail link : city line ( cheaper compare to express ine) from suvarnabnhumi airport to bangkok. its a 30 minutes smooth ride, only cost me 45baht ( express line is 150 baht). city line stops at 7 or 8 station along the way...it gives me time to enjoy the ride. the route easy to undestand, you can choose where to stop ( the nearest station to your hotel). you must try it.

The better option to arrive in downtown Bangkok. With Bangkok being busy anytime during the day, the airport Rail Link is the better option to commute to and from Suvarnabhumi Airport. Its fast, its cheap, it has frequent departures and its comfortable leaving from inside the airport terminal.Its too bad that it does not connect to Don Muang Airport.A tip: remember to purchase the round-trip ticket for a good discount.

Very impressed. Very impressed with the airport rail link. Was prompt, clean, quiet, well sign-posted, quite cheap and gave a very nice welcoming view into Bangkok.If you a little adventurous or just want to save the hassle and cost (and traffic!) of getting a taxi from the airport, try the airport rail link for sure.Great way to get back TO the airport from the city too.

Our first transport at Bangkok. Actually we were quite worried before our Bangkok trip. How to go to Bangkok hotel from airport? How to get out from airport? Taxi? Bus? Rental car? Rail?Finally we have chosen Airport rail link. Never thought only THB45 can enjoy in the 5-stars railway system. Took about 30-40minutes to reach the last station- Phaya Thai. And our hotel just 5-10min walking distance from the stationVery happy with the Bangkok transportation system which connecting airport and city!

The perfect way to airport. Either you are in a rush or not,still airport link is the fastest way to airport.By the way there is only few station that serves this route so you have to chose from which station in the city.

Good IF you are on your own with no bags. Although the express service from Makkasan takes less than 15 minutes to the airport, the terminal, frankly, is a bit of a joke. The idea was good, but the location and infrastructure is so poor that very few people use it. Go, instead, from Paya Thai station, which joins the BTS. Express trains only run every 30 minutes. Fares keep changing, depending on the various promotions, but are around 100 baht. Carrying a heavy suitcase would be difficult. Bottom line: good if you can get to the station easily and are on your own with only light luggage. Otherwise, take a taxi.
Cheap and easy. Very cheap and easy way to travel to Bangkok from the airport. Convenient and fast, no more sitting in traffic!

Fast in and out from Bangkok. This is the fastest way and considering the service should be the most preferred transport to travel from down town to airport and vice versa. Hardly took 30 minute for me to reach airport very convenient way to travel. Crowed free, traffic free and also give you chance to look around the city and surrounding. Try must for once if you are in Bangkok, its worth travelling in the county backbone of transport.
Easy as a taxi. Most places in Bangkok centre are near a Skytrain rail station or BTS station and it takes you quickly and safely into the city

Fastest way to go to city from Airport Suvarnabhumi. This is the fastest way and considering the service should be the most ergonomic way to travel between airport and city center. Closest exit to City Center is BTS station Phayathai.One way travel should take you about 30 mnts.Take this if you traveling between 1-2 pax and without big luggages.

Best way to get into Bangkok. The airport rail link is easy to find from the baggage hall and trains are regular. It cost about £1 to get into Bangkok and took about 20 - 30 mins.The trains are clean and were uncrowded when we were travelling around midday.We are going back in February 2014 and we'll be using the rail link again.

Beats the taxi to Sukhumvit every time. Whether it is the Express Line (every 30 minutes and 90 baht) or the City Line (every 15 minutes and 45 baht) you will sail past the queues on the Highway going to Silom and Sukhumvit, particularly if you are travelling near the rush hour times. I take the Express to Phrya Thai (end of the line) if one is going soon, otherwise it is the stopping service of the City Line. At your destination there is an easy switch to the BTS Skytrain (there is a lift if you have heavy bags) and then frequent trains to Siam and beyond. Try it and you will love travelling with the locals and sweeping past the queues on the Highway
Best way to get around is either a train or the sky train.. I used the train several times to get around because its cheap, ontime and clean. Quite safe too I never had any issues at all.

Cheaper and Faster For Lone travellers. I have used this several times when travelling by myself. If you happen to arrive during peak rush hours this is a good alternative to get to the City. You can get off at major points like Sukhumvit and Sathorn if your hotel is located in those areas. At 90 baht per person to Makkasan or Phaya Thai it is cheaper than a taxi of around 300 baht if you are by yourself and only have a small luggage. THe only downside is it is still NOT physically connected to the BTS in Makkasan you need to get out of the building cross the railroad tracks. I have seen too many tourists get confused as to how to get to the BTS as the Makkasan station is huge and not enough signage.

Quick and efficient way to get to central Bangkok. There are two metro lines from the Main international airport (Suvarnabhumi) to central Bangkok. In my experience unless you have a lot of luggage - more than one 20Kg case - it is better and cheaper than the Taxi.The two lines from the Aiport are, SA Express and SA City line. Later makes a lot of stops but will get you there under an hour.More info here;http://www.bangkokmetro.co.th/index.aspx?Lang=En

Best way to city center. Don't bother with a taxi, take the train! It is a fraction of the cost of a taxi and you won't get stuck in traffic. Its cool, clean, comfortable, and fast. If you get off at makasan station you can walk to the MRT subway station and get to about any place in the city from there (but if you have a lot of luggage it's better just to get a taxi from the station)

unbeatable. After usually taking taxi's and limo's from the airport to city I thought I would give the train ago. Wow it was so nice to be in the city in about 20 minutes compared to at least an hour if not more depending on traffic. Plenty of tuk tuks and taxis at stations ready to take you to hotel. or walk.Price is around $1 compared to $ 20 for a taxi upto $ 40 for limo
Efficient. Best way to travel into Bangkok from the Airport. It is cheap, reliable and you avoid the notorious Bangkok traffic jams!
great. in few minutes (or more if you want to spend less) it covers the distance between the airport and downtown.Very comfortable, absolutely silent, it looks like to fly.
Gets you were you need to go. This is absolutely the best way to get around Bangkok and very cheap stops at all the popular venues interesting just to go for a bit of a look around the city

Way to go into Bangkok. We took the rail link from Airport to Phaya Thai station. The travel was slower than expected but we have no complaints especially when a trip with the taxi would have taken us longer to reach our hotel.
This is brilliant. You can either get the express which is 90baht or the train that stops everywhere for 40baht. I recommend the 90baht as it is so good.
Slow way. It's not so fast. They may have better way.May be good for ones who would like to see Bangkok first.
Efficient. The airport stop is in the bottom floor of Suvarnabhumi Airport. There are two lines: Express (in red) and City (in blue). The ride into Bangkok is comfortable and very efficient.
Very good. Fast and reliable, in about 20min you can reach the centre from airport and only for 90thb, much better then taxi ,no traffic and very comfortable

Fast, Efficient, Affordable .... and Bizarre!!. What a strange, bizarre experience it is to take the Express Airport Rail Link from Makkasan Station to Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi Airport. First of all, there is no easy way to get to Makkasan Station. I was told to take the MRT to Phetchaburi Station, and then walk over to Makkasan. Sounded easy enough, except that there is a total lack of signage pointing you in the right direction, and no exit from the MRT that takes you directly to the rail link station. The exit takes you to a busy sidewalk, where I had to gaze around until I spotted the overhead railroad a few hundred meters distant. The I had to drag my suitcase and carry my packpack a good half a kilometer to reach the station, having to cross a busy side-street in the process. Once in Makkasan Station it gets really spooky. This place is HUGE!! Its terminal is bigger then most small airports, and everything is clean and shiny. The only problem is, that it is completely devoid of people! Noone uses is, likely because noone knows where it is. Your steps echo hollowly on the tiled floors as you follow signs directing you to the train. Staff are few and far between, but there was a helpful lady who told me where to buy my ticket and where to wait for the train. Once on the train, it was lovely, with comfy highbacked seats. The trip is amazing, shoooting by the scenery non-stop at highspeed, reaching BKK's main terminal in just 15 minutes! All for just 90 baht. I sat on an empty train, however, with all the seats around me empty at 2pm! Why is this service not being used by everybody? Well, when I returned the same way to Makkasan on my return trip, there were no taxis to be found at Makkasan, so there I was dragging my suitcase over to the MRT again. On a second occasion, I tried to take a taxi from my hotel to Makkasan and the driver had no idea where it was, and ended up dropping me off at the regular, slower rail terminal of Ratchaprarop. I said, "No, I wanted Makkasan", but he said, "This Makkasan." So a world class facility sits idle because of the difficulty in connecting with it. It should be the busiest transportation hub in Bangkok, but because of poor planning it sits like a multi-million dollar ghost town. I direct link between the MRT Station of Phetchaburi, likely by an underground access tunnel, is absolutely essential to make this a meaningful addition to Bangkok's world-class transportation system.

Awesome, cheap and easily accessible. The Airport rail link made our life a lot easier. This was the first time i was travelling with my sister to Bangkok.After i had been warned time and again about tuk tuk drivers and taxi drivers charging insanely ridiculous prices at the airport, the rail link was a sigh of relief. This is undoubtedly the fastest way to get into the city. The trains have enough space for those carrying loads of luggage. Every station as elevator facilities. You can get to Phaya Thai (last stop) which will connect you to the BTS sky train. The rail link is closed from midnight till 6 in the morning. All announcements are made in English too, so there's no chance of missing out on your station. The cost of tickets are from 15 baht up to 45 baht for the city line. (Much better than the 500 bhat taxi ride to the city) Overall i loved the system. It was easy to travel, cheap and as comfortable as possible!

Why Can't We Do It This Well. This is a great way to get from the airport to any hotels. If you are unsure just ask one of the very helpful Thai's. They will salute you and in good English they will help you find your way. Why can't Australia do it this well?

Efficiancy with safety and low stress.
