In Bangkok, one is treated to the world's only four self-sustaining and profitable mass transit systems: the MRT subway, the BTS skytrain, the amazing bus system and the Airport Rail Link. The rail link is not available to you if you arrive at Suvarnabhumi after midnight or before 6:00am, and this might be its only drawback. Should you be arriving or departing during operating hours, it is foolish not to take it. Even if your destination is not on the mas transit routes, you will be well-served to take your taxi from the terminus of the route when coming in to town. You'll save forty-five minutes (or more) coming in, and an hour (or more) going out, not to mention saving on cab fare and hassle. If you are going from town to the airport and have luggage, just check it in at Makhassan Station (yes, you can do an airport check-in right at the rail link!! I've done it several times and no lost luggage) and forget it...all hassles solved. If you have no luggage, leave town from the Phaya Thai station, where there is less congestion. The link is cheap, fast, hassle free, safe at all hours, clean, family friendly and the only smart way to go.. a must-do
fast and cheap. it's really cheap and easy to access even with a lot of luggage ( mine was a really big one) compare to Malaysia's.

Fastest way from and to the airport. The airport express link is a very quick and efficient, but getting in and out of the main terminal at Makkasan is a real headache. Sathorn road and Ratchadaphisek is quite busy all day and if you have to take it during rush hour, I would recommend getting on/off at the Phaya Thai terminal.

Always Take This To Avoid Traffic. Whenever I visited Bangkok, I always take airport rail link to avoid the traffic and their taxi drivers. It is much more efficient and much faster.Tip: Always take the City Line. It is much faster than the Express Line. The City Line's frequency is much higher. It comes in a few minutes. Whereas, the Express Line's frequency comes once in 30 minutes.

Very convenient and cheap. If you are comfortable with travelling by public transport then go with the airport link over taxi. It is quick and efficient. AND VERY CHEAP.It is however not great if you have lots of baggage and you will often be standing up.I recommend if you are going short haul flight and just have one bag and especially if going at peak traffic times.

Quick efficient way to the city but beware reduced train frequency to airport. The airport expresss link to the city is an efficient, clean way into Bangkok starting at 6am with the timetable published on their website, maybe every 30min for a 17min ride to the city. There were probably only 5 people on our train at 6.30am. We then caught a taxi (make sure it's a metered taxi) from level 3 (there are signs). The return express train to the airport only happens every 60min on the hour (reduced services since Jan 2013). We didn't realize this and had the catch thr regular commuter train (? 90 baht), which takes about 30min and it's standing room only (maybe because we got on at Makassan). Luckily we had enough time to spare. Still it was cheaper than the 400 baht taxi we were quoted from our hotel

Love it, my only qualm about it is that it isn't well signed and can be a bit confusing.. Also the express line only runs every hour, so you may end up waiting a long time. The other line runs every 15 minutes I think. The only difference is that the regular line stops at every station, whereas the express goes straight to Makkasan station. If you are travelling solo it's cheaper to go by the rail to the MRT/BTS link. If you in a group it is cheaper to take a taxi.

Inaugural Opening. I happened to travel through Suvarnabhumi Airport on the day this rail line opened. For a very reasonable fare the train whisks travels and luggage at high speeds into Central Bangkok. Depending on where you're staying and how much you're traveling with, this may be your perfect ride into town.
Easy, quick and inexpensive. My title pretty well sums it up. Make sure you check the times of daily operation as it's not 24 hours a day.
clean and quick. great way to get to the main airport, cheap, clean and fast, only 3 stops and halves the time and cost of a taxi...

Gets you into town without sitting in the heavy traffic. The rail link is efficient to get into town. Simple to find, On time and clean. train communication good as messages are displayed and tannoy speaker messages of the details of the next station.Can get very busy though. However if travelling into Sukhumvit where most of the hotels are you have can go the long way around via Phaya Thai (end of Line) and change to the BTS line or..The quicker route is to get off at Makkasan and walk to the MRT Phetchaburi underground where you can travel to sukhumvit station. However note that Bangkok rail system stations do not link very well with each other. (bad design of station positions).This means that you have to walk +-500m through busy traffic packed streets dogging traffic and shopping stalls to find the MRT. It is not difficult to follow this route as you just follow the other 50 + people doing the same thing.

Good connection. It's difficult to drop in Bangkok, being scary from the taxis and their incredible prices. Fortunately you can reach the city in 30mn with this shuttle, with air con, and for a few baht. You'll be then drop at a Skytrain station, really useful to reach your place then

Fast and cheap.. It's a really good, cheap, fast and efficient rail link from Bangkok's main airport to the heart of the modern centre, just make sure you know where you are going if you arrive at night.

Excellent to use but then what next?. The Airport rail link is easy and cheap to use at 45 Baht. It is a good way to avoid the traffic but once to get to Phaya Thai that is where the problem starts. I got to the place where I was meant to get a taxi and was directed to a point across the the street which meant me walking across a road with busy traffic. The first taxi driver refuse to take me to my destination even though I was going to the famous Koh San Road. An elderly tuk tuk driver took pity on me and took we there for 150 Baht. Had the taxi rank been clearly marked I would not have had to go through what I had gone through.Overall the Airport Rail Link is: clean, easy and cheap

Convenient and comfortable!. We used the Airport Rail Link to get to the airport from Bangkok Loft Inn and thought it was brilliant. After our journey on the BTS, we bought a new ticket for 40/45 Baht each to get to the airport. We must have just missed one train, so got onto the next one. There was about a 15 minute wait, which seems reasonable for a train that gets very busy. If you're not one of the first few to get onto the train, you will find yourself standing as it is a very popular train. Once at the airport, it is really easy to find you way to Departures.
Modern, fast and inexpensive1. Clean, fast and very convenient. Signs should be improved from the Metro since you've to walk about 200 m outside.

Soooooo Easy!. This is excellent if you are travelling light. The link is sooooo easy to use & access from almost anywhere in central Bangkok. It can be a little annoying when you get all the 'cheapskates' who have loads of luggage travelling on the link because they are too tight to pay for a cab to the airport but I don't think the Airport Link can be blamed for these cheapskates!

A real pity. The airport link itself is great. The accessibility from the airport could be better as it is quite a search but that is all surmountable. So when your are in it is is great. But then trying to reach a decent tourist destination in Bangkok with this link is a complete disaster. The connection with any existing public transport in Bangkok is the worst of all. When you do have heavy luggage going into Bangkok stay as far away from this link as possible and just get you a taxi that will drive you into bangkok for THB 350 on average instead of carrying your luggage over a number of stairs. This is the worst thought off latest investment in Bangkok ever. .

A great way to get to and from the airport. The last 3 times I have been to Bangkok I have used the airport link sky train and its been great.Sometimes it can be a bit crowded but nothing too bad.And its great value at 45 Baht and you know how long it will take as you are not stuck in a taxi in a crazy Bangkok traffic jam.I almost missed a flight about a year ago because of the weather and the traffic, the taxi took more then twice as long as normal to get me there and I just made it,That was it for me and no more crazy taxi drivers and mad Bangkok traffic anymore, the sky train is the only way to get to the airport for me now.

Suvarnabhumi rail simplicity. Easy to find, easy to use, research your hotel location before you go, this could easily be your best option to get into town. We caught the normal city line as it was ready when we arrived downstairs, there is an info booth which will let you know whether the express platform of the city platform are the go at that minute. City line stops at about 8 or so stations before reaching Phaya thai, the end of the line. Quick comfortable trip, jump off and grab the BTS sky train which can extend your reach to even more areas quickly and comfortably.

Fast and Cheap, Less Good with Luggage. On a recent visit, went into town by taxi and went back by train. Taxi took 1 hour and cost 450 baht including tolls. Train took 17 minutes and cost 90 baht (OK, 30 minutes and 105 baht including the Skytrain to get there).So the train is the clear winner--but only (!) if one travels light, precisely for the reasons mentioned in other reviews (few elevators and escalators).Ticket vending machines were not working, but things moved fairly speedily at the ticket booth.
Taxi. hi could anyone tell me where do i get a taxi for 400bht. from the airport to centre, every time i go it cost me 1200bht.

Airport Rail Link needs to be improved. There are few areas of improvements required:- Service Timings for both CityLine and ExpressLine need to be expanded and increased.- Transfers to MRT / BTS Sky Train need to be expanded, and not limit to Makkasan and Phaya Thai only.CityLine train needs to have more carriages and also space to put luggages.I recommend to have all-in fares and fare cards between Airport Rail Link, MRT and BTS Skytrain and not having 1 fare card for each type of transport for convenience.I also recommend to have visitor's / tourist's pass for all three types of transports for easy access, cost savings and convenience for tourists.

Great if you're heading into the Phaya Thai area of the city. The Rail Link is quiet under-utilised but I've used it on several occasions and it's been reliable, relatively quiet and cheaper than taking a taxi. If you have more than 1 person in your party splitting a cab would work out about the same cost, but if you need to go somewhere near the sky train station in Phaya Thai it might be worth checking out.

Fast and Cheap connection. Long waited for, and finally open - we tried the airport link and where satisfied. It is reliable, not over crowded and reasonably priced, comparing with taxis or limousine services.

Convenient and cheap. It costs only a small percentage of what a cab or a bus would cost, and its safer and faster. It is very modern and geting tickets is very easy and simple and it takes you to the center of bangkok.I wish all airports had such a simple way of transport to town.

Better than taxi. The train is very smooth and quick, so I'll usually take it rather than a taxi, if I'm staying near a BTS station. It's especially nice during rush hour.It's only 90 baht one way or 150 baht round-trip for the express, and 45 baht by city line (stops at each station, not much room for luggage, and 50% chance you have to stand). Note that the savings aren't great if you have 2 passengers, though it's still nice to avoid traffic and hassling with taxi drivers. I believe it starts at 6 AM and stops at midnight. They seem to be leaving less frequently these days, so check in advance.When I might take a taxi: 1) staying away from a BTS station2) with more than two people travelling together3) with two people and it's not rush here (say, after 9 PM or on weekends)4) if I have a lot of luggage (there are some places where you have to walk a few hundred meters, and existing the BTS you'll probably need to carry your luggage down some stairs)5) it won't work if you arrive after midnight, or your flight departs before 8 AM

Cheap clean and reliable.. An efficient cheap and easy trip to and from the airport. Having travelled by car in previous trips the traffic adds easily an hour or so which can be a headache in itself.The train is clean and offers room for your luggage and runs on regular intervals. There is a few stops with this service as apposed to the express service. But this service runs more often. For the price you pay it's well worth the money. Connects easily to the BTS. I wouldn't travel any other way now.

Excellent for fit people with small luggage. Its not the best way for eldery or with children to go to airport however for a quick ride for backpackers and or small luggage its OK. Train is superb fast and cost 35 Bhat if its a 30 minutes ride and fast non stop 16 minutes @ Bhat 100. However a taxi ride on an average is around 400 bhats so if you are 3 or 4 person its best to take a taxi.

Must do. One of the better introductions to the transport system. Express service magnificent, felt like a pioneer as the only passenger on the last nightly service. Pleasantly surprised surprised to find taxi waiting at exit.
Awesome connection. Amazing connection, very fast and right on time high 5 for the service. higly recomend you guys if you wana go to city in quick time period

Very efficient. This train service is great as it means you avoid the traffic from and to the airport. When arriving it isn't clear that you can buy tickets for the express or the local stopping train. We wanted the express but got the other. The problem with the express service is that it only runs hourly. The trains themselves are clean, modern and air conditioned!

quickest and safest way to the city. Its very convenient because the station is just below the airport and it will connect you to Phaya Thai (in 30 mins) where it interchanges with Skytrain. Express Line, i think, has trains stopping only at Makkasan and others only Phaya Thai. Regular train or the City line will have 6 stops before reaching Phaya Thai. We took the city line because we're getting off at Ratchaprarop. We paid THB40, pretty much cheap compared to cabs.The stations are clean and huge-- you can play hide and seek if you want.

saves time but check if its actually working. The quickest way to get into the city from bangkok's suvarnabhumi airport is this airport rail link. It starts from the level 1 of the airport gets you Phaya thai station where you can exchange to the BTS ( bangkok skytrain service) to come back to sukhumvit or move just about anywhere along the tourist tracks of bangkok. It saves you the head-ache of the road traffic which nearly takes 90 minutes to get to sukhumvit road"9 main street of bangkok) Theres only one annoying issue ..... sometimes this service is shut down and the hapless tourist is forced to use the airport shuttle bus or take a cab. The ticket is fair similar to the airport shuttle but this service gets you into the city in 30-45 mins.

Useful with some poor oversights. Good connection at the bottom of Suvarnabhumi Airport (BKK). Disappointing the express only runs per hour... It is FAR better, has real seating aisles and better for big luggage. Tourists carrying cases on the city line need to be careful... City line has very bad and cheap plastic seating by the window sides, no chairs facing forward or back :( Poor planning at Makkasan, commuters have to walk 3 minutes in the heat to reach the MRT underground. Also, why is this station so big when there is nothing in it? Phyathai terminal recommended for good connection to BTS sky train.Finally, another fault at Ramkhamhaeng as travelers booked at the Nasa Vegas have to haul their luggage over a very busy road to get to the 'convenient' hotel. Fast and smooth train journey, best when wanting to avoid rush hour traffic on Rama 9, again the plastic seating is a cheap letdown, never mind lol

Efficient, reliable, safe and clean. The airport train is the best way to get to and from the airport. Apart from being environmentally appropraite to use public transport, it provides a very reliable way to get to the airport and cost effective, compared to braving Bangkok's traffic
very good. great to airport to avoid horrible BKK traffic. However, if you have luggage and are more than one person. Taxi may be better, depending on time of day.

Great for most people, for most of the time. There are a lot of very good reviews below, full of pertinent information. My own advice having used this service several times would be:Don't bother with the express.If you are burdened with masses of luggage, or are travelling with young children, then consider taking a taxi. As many have said it doesn't quite always join up in terms of stairs and being as close to BTS as it might present itself to be.If you are arriving very late at night and minutes are important to you, or your hotel is nowhere near the BTS, consider taking a taxi. It is probably a little quicker.However, as long as you can manage your lugage, if you are arriving anywhere near the rush hour, take the train. Being in a vehicle in Bangkok rush hour is no fun whatsoever. If your hotel is very close to the BTS, take the train whatever the time is - cheaper and more pleasant.If you have little or no luggage, take the train - it's just a better experience. Echo the person who made the point about great views as you come in.If you are on your own, take the train - better value and greener than hiring a whole taxi just for yourself.Tip: If you have the option of arriving with some coins, it will speed your journey a little at the ticket kiosks. It's currently 45Bt to Phaya Thai, and a further 35Bt to Asoke for example (the expressway tolls on their own are 70Bt on the way into town in a taxi).Once you've used it once, you will use it again.

You'd be crazy not to use this............. so simple to use, you don't get caught in traffic, get great first views of Bangkok when you come in....why wouldn't you use this service? And those other reviews are right, don't bother with the express service....
Perfect transport. Perfect transport to and from the airport. We strongly recommend it. Fast nice and clean. Womderful aircondition.

Express probably not worth the extra money over stopping city service. When we left Bangkok on 13th February, the Express services had been reduced to one an hour, so there is even less reason to choose them over the City link, which only takes about 10 minutes longer. As the previous reviewer states, there is a bit of a walk (and flights of steps) to connect to/from the BTS at Paya Thai, so it would depend how much luggage you had whether this would be a good means of connection for you. As our accomodation in Bangkok was very handy to a BTS station, and we had packs rather than suitcases, it was a good choice for us. Trains both on arrival and departure were uncrowded, so plenty of room for luggage, and the journey was not affected by the frequent traffic congestion. BTS on arrival in late afternoon was VERY busy though.

Rot Fai Fah Sanam Bin (Sky Train Airport). A very sensible idea implemented with Thai wisdom, so therefore rendered virtually useless.2 services, City Line and Express, both use the same track, so you can see a problem from the start. If you want to use the Express, it goes at 20 minute intervals, whereas the City Line is at around 5 minute intervals, by the time you have waited for an Express you could have been there on the City Line for half the fare.The idea was to be able to take your luggage with you, there is sufficient space, but Makkasan Station has no taxis waiting and is not as close to the subway as they suggest, so if you go there you have to lug your bags to the road and try and get a taxi there. If you go all the way to Phaya Thai station, there is a fair walk to the Sky Train, and you need to open your luggage for a security check.Best not to bother.On arrival the cheapest taxi s are at DEPARTURES make sure they use the meter and pay about 200 - 300 Baht right to your hotel.Airport Rail Link TO the airport could have been good, I think they were copying the one in Hong Kong where you can check your bags in at the station, then just travel to the airport. Sadly as this is Thailand, none of the airport check-in desks are ever occupied except Thai, and if you want to check in you MUST use the Express.Having said that, if you are just meeting someone at the airport, it can't be beaten, but for its intended use - it is a complete failure.

connection to the city. the airport rail link has 2 types trains, one is the express one and stops directly at the makassan and further to paya thai station in the city , these trains are very new and nice and have some more luggage storage options.. the 2nd type of rail link is the regular one which stops at the 4 stations before makkasan as well and terminates at paya thai.. note: the train at times wait for 10-15 mins before departing , train can take less time, but at times taking taxi is wise, depending on your luggage, the final destination station and also depends on the time of the day you arrive (during rush hours, taxi can take more time)... the rail link offers a 2 way pass if you are sure about your return in 2 weeks, u can use that pass , it saves some bahts , not much though...

Great connection. I traveled with the Airport Rail Link in january 2013 and it worked perfectly. It's on the lower ground of the airport and I just got a oneway ticket at the ticketbooth. I went on the 'slow' train which takes 30 minutes to Phraya Thai. Great way to Bangkok.

Impressed by the efficiency. I used the Express line on both ways between the Suvarnabhumi Airport and the Makkasan Airport Rail Link station because my hotel was near Asok BTS station.Express trains from the airport depart every 25 mins past the hour while trains from Makkasan station depart on every start of the hour. The whole trip takes around 19 minutes.The trains were puctual and fast. Staff were helpful to answer questions and give directions. I am surprised that not many people are using it yet.The only thing is that there is a short walk in the open from the Makkasan Airport Rail Link station to the Phetchaburi MRT station. If you have heavy luggage on the way back, you can take a taxi directly to the Makkasan station to avoid the hassle.

a must if you have Small Luggage. I did this once with a lot of Luggage thought I was going to die, but have learnt this is the only way in to the Heart of BKK takes only 30 minutes, then get a taxi to your hotel or connect with Sky rail beats sitting in a Taxi at 500 baht for sometimes up to 2 hours in Traffic the fare is only small but well worth it, no more long waits in taxis for me either way into or out of BKK

Save on cab fare to Platinum Mall!. We had a few hours in BKK before we head to Koh Tao. So we took the airport rail link to Ratchaprarop station (Which is nearest to Platinum Mall!) and found our way to the shopping paradise. The best part of it was walking past my favourite stall that sells beef kway tiao soup! Getting down from the station, turn to the right and walk straight down. That will lead to Platinum Mall. Btw, the beef kway tiao stall is one of the first stalls you past by when you turn right from the station. Its kinda like a shophouse. You can smell the fragrant soup smell when walking by!

Can get there ! On time.. This the best way to go to Suvanaphomi Airport not Donmuang Airport. Don't forget just Suvanaphomi Airport. If you go by skytrain or BTS can connect to Airport Rail Link at "Phraya Thai Station" Notice: If you did not take a nap, not lost the way because every stop will anounce in Thai and English.* From Phraya Thai Station just 45 Baht for City Line stop every station spent about 25 min.* And Express Line 100 Baht just 15 min.Notice: Express Line you can get on the train just Phraya Thai Station only.
great connectivity. Traveled in this link. the great connectivity and the punctuality is tremendous. people are frendly and helpful in guiding.

Get a map. Take a shawl because it can get relly chilly in the skytrain. And find out where you want to go and which station is closer, because Bangkok is HOT to walk in. Skytrain is quick, cheap, clean and easy when you are on your own, but remember the taxi is almost always cheaper if you are with more than two.
very convenient!. my first time taking train from airport to city area. very convenient. and not crowded at all. so much better than taking cab and got stuck in jam! cheap and convenient.

sometime a taxi is just a lot easier !. A great service no doubt and we used it with the intention of saving some cash and possibly time.However, after a huge flight we arrived in Bangkok feeling terrible and just wanted to get to our hotel and lie down. Keep in mind that if you take the rail link, you have to worry :- about buying tickets, which can be confusing at the vending machines and with a language barrier via the attendants - having the right change to buy the tickets- getting off a the right train station (worrying about where you are)- finding a seat on the train (you may well have to stand up during the journey as the train is always busy)- then you at your train stop you still have to get a taxi or tuk tuk to your actual hotel which means a chance of potential rip off for newbies to Bangkok in addition to explaining where your hotel is to a local cab driver.In hindsight it would have been better just to hop into a taxi and the airport, sit down, relax and let the driver take us direct to the hotel doorstep (we did use a taxi the next time). Airport taxis are controlled at a departure point and are all metered so you will not get ripped off.Unless you are on a really tight budget or are feeling fresh and ready to go, I would recommend taking a taxi if you are a situation like we were. For the sake of a few bucks more, the convenience and lack of hassle is worth it.Nothing beats the ease of 'door to door' transport when you arrive in a strange city and are feeling destroyed after a long flight.ps. as far as time goes I dont think we saved any time using the rail link compared to the taxi which took the express motorway anyway. But sure, in times of bad traffic congestion you would indeed save time on the rail link.

Great way to beat Bangkok traffic jam. It's just wonderful not to ride a cab and go through Bangkok's notorious traffic jam. There are 2 types of airport links, one is the express one and the other is the cityline. If you take this train for going to the airport, please well-calculate your travel time.
Quick cheap easy. The new airport link is a great way to get from the city to the ap. If you are a solo traveller it is cheap however if you are a group it's cheaper to catch a taxi. 100 baht

Fast & Convenient. If you do not wish to spend around 250 - 300 baht to cab from the airpot to the city area, the airpot rail link is the best alternative. It cost only 35 baht/ pax to reach Ratchaprarop Station and just a 5 - 7 mins to Baiyoke.

Convenient and punctual. Though it is true that it does not have good connection from Makkasan station, it has it at Phaya Thai .... and when the traffic can be heavy because of Friday afternoon or rain! it really makes a difference to use it!

Quick and comfortable.. A direct link to airport, no hassles. Airport Rail Link, BTS and MRT are all great for travel. Not expensive and each offers a nice experience and gets you to your destination quickly and comfortably.
Door to door. Brilliant, clean, airconditioned, regular, fast link to the city. links to subway and brt systems make it an easy way to get where you need to be in the city.

Wash the windows please!!!!!. The ride to/from BKK into the city (Phaya Thai station) is really quite pleasant and quick (20 minutes). The scenery along the way is somewhat interesting, but the windows seriously need washing on this express train.Cost as of January 2, 2013 is 90 baht one way, and a savings if you can buy the round trip ticket (150?).City Line is also a nice way to get to/from, but if you are travelling with luggage there isn't really much room, and the train seems more crowded than the Express.

Great, cheap way to get to BKK. I use this about 3 times a month. Gets me back to BKK quickly. I use the Makkassen station to get to the MTS. Be nice if they could merge the Skytrain/BTS/MTS onto one fare card

For that quick trip to airport!!. We were staying at Park Plaza in the Sukhumvit Soi 18 area (BTS: Asoke). Our flight was at 9:10am. Our tour guide suggested for us to leave at 5:30 by taxi to Makkasan station where the connection for ARL is located. This would eliminate the transfer between BTS and ARL. It was a 55 THB taxi trip ($1.60) right to Makkasan. The ARL opens at 6am. There was a friendly security worker at the door who lead us to a seat to wait for the opening at 5:50am. We followed another young man who was also going to the airport....so easy !! We went to the 3rd floor( I think--the security will tell you); walked to the ticket agent; paid 45 THB ($1.50) for the express (20 THB for city link--30 minutes) and was in the airport in 17 minutes !! We remember paying $60 (yes, $60) for a taxi to our hotel two years ago in our first trip to Bangkok. NEVER AGAIN !!!
About time!. This link should have been operational when the new airport was opened. Never the less it is now and finally we have some transport that can get us into the city in less then an hour!

Perfect connection. Fast and easy is the best solution to go in Bangkok town in the high traffic times. No traffic jam not stop minutes to the traffic light. Direct connection with BTS SkyTrain ready to go everywhere. Very cheap price.

A good, cheap, and fast way to get to the airport from Sukhumvit.. It's ~45 baht ($1.50) to get from Phayathai BTS Station to Suvarnabhumi airport, which is a cheaper option than taxi if you are a solo traveller. It takes about 45 minutes by normal airport rail link. But be aware that the airport rail link leaves Phayathai station only every 15 minutes or so... so try to plan accordingly! By contrast, a taxi from Sukhumvit will cost you around 250-300 including tolls, and can take you anywhere from 45-90 minutes depending on traffic.

Efficient and convenient. A welcome addition to the system and very attractive if you plan a hotel along the stops, do some homework on the website on timings, location etc. It was possible to take a late night 2250 flight into BKK, catch the last train (2337 on the city multistop line, not the express) and check into our hotel just after midnight. A direct escalator or lift would have been better than having to walk round to get to street level, but is a minor peeve. For Dec 2012 this month, promotional 20 Baht train ticket to any station, so outbound to the airport was ridiculously cheap. We did not try the City terminal airport checkin (at Makkassan) which would have allowed more shopping time. The ride itself is like what we expect from most modern transit (but just a notch less luxurious than say, Hong Kong or the Maglev in Shanghai), with local young people out and about to and from the airport for the ride.
Efficient. The airport train is cheap and very efficient .i liked it.It was timely it can save time as opposed being stuck on traffic jam

Fast and easy. The only negative thing i have to say is where are the DOWN escalators? Also, you can't use your BTS prepaid card on this line........
Easy to connect to the BTS sky train
If going to Asok, transfer to the MRT it's a short cut and an easier transfer.

Good idea, cheap but executed badly. I've used this a few times and find it has good and bad elements. The positives first: It is clean, fast, cheap, runs fairly frequently, directions are clear and the staff are very helpful. You can choose the 'express' which stops once or twice or the slower one that stops more frequently.The negatives: It is not well integrated into any other infrastructure. You will need to haul your luggage from the destination station to the BTS or even (sometimes) to the main road to find a taxi. Sometimes taxis are waiting at the exit ... sometimes not. I am sure this will improve but, for now, it is a pain. It is also unreliable in my experience. Twice, I have had to change plans because the trains were not running. Again, this may be due to teething problems?

Excellent transport to BKK city center. Visiting Bangkok in 2011 Airport Rail Link hasn’t operated yet , so this time 2012 trying for the first time Airport Rail link is excellent, efficient and fast transport mode from Suvarnabhumi airport to BKK city center, for beating traffic jam. I take Airport Rail Link Blue line from Suvarnabhumi (basement) to Phaya Thai Station (45THB) (35minutes), and from there we take taxi (meter) from taxi stand below Phaya Thai station. When we get off at terminus Phaya Thai station, follow direction to taxi stand below. We take taxi from Phaya Thai station taxi stand in afternoon to soi Rambuttri ,near Khao San Rd (65THB). When we back to Suvarnabhumi , we get on Airport Rail Link (Blue line) depart at 6:14 in the morning (the first airport rail link depart 6:02) for catching flight at 9:10, before 7 a.m we have “landed” in Suvarnabhumi . For Sure, we would take Airport Rail Link again and again and again when we are in BKK.

Hassle free to get down town Bangkok. Follow. the signs at arrivals for the train. Buy the City line for 45 baht takes 30 minutes or 150B for a 15 minute Express train to Makasan station(you can get onto the MRT under-ground from here) or Paya Thai (you can get onto the sky-train from here) if your hotel is near the MRT or Sky-train. If you get in at night better to take a taxi from the airport which will cost about 300Baht otherwise the taxis at Makasan or Paya Thai will try rip u off to your hotel unless you insist on a metered fare only. Do not take an un-metered taxi at anytime.
Never be late for flight again with traffic jam in bangkok. Beats the traffic and feel safe that you will be in time for the flight .. Well linked to sky train at phaya thai. :)

The best way to city. Instead of looking for cabs or limo,this is a better way to get to the city from the airport. The only thing is you might need to wait for at least 15-20 minutes if you had missed one of the trains but you will get into the city of Bangkok in no time maybe 15 mins max. Fast,reliable and cheap only cost 90 baht compared to taxis overcharged between 400 to 600 or 700 baht, So it is smart way to take airport link instead

Best kept secret in Bangkok. It's an excellent concept. The train is fast, clean, uncrowded and always on time. There's plenty of space for your luggage and plenty of time to get on and off the train. Only criticism is that there aren't a lot of taxis at the arrivals area of Makassan station at certain times of the day so you may have to go out on the street to flag one down.
Taxi is better. If there are two or more people in your group, better to get a metre taxi. It will work out cheaper than the train. It will also take you directly to your hotel, the train does not.

The best a cheapest way to get to the airport in Bangkok. You pick this train up from the BTS you pay 40 baht and the ride takes about 45 mins. On arrival you walk straight from the train into the airport terminal building. Check timetables before travel as the train stops for a couple of hours through the night.
Useful connection to the airport. Don't miss your plane anymore with the airport link. Great connection from the city centre to the airport. Fast cheap, safe, reliable, on time...

Hastily hobbled together. How about better access, car parking, signs etc? This really was a mess when it opened, with tourists having to cross motorways with suitcases in tow, crappy signage and clueless staff though it seems to have improved. I doubt many tourists use it but they really should as it is a better option than the stinky and irritating airport taxis. I think the Thais use this more than tourists.
stress free!. Every time I visited Bangkok, I always use the airport link. It's hassle free and stress free with the fact the fare is reasonable. I will recommend this especially for tourist!

It all depends........ what time of the day you arrive into Bangkok International airport, whether you travel light and whether your hotel in Bangkok is right next to a BTS (skytrain) or MTR station, all this factored in whether you should opt for the airport train or a taxi. I yield to taking the Bangkok airport train, travel light (only with a trolley) and to find a hotel right next to a BTS station (which I did on this trip). It makes your travel in and out of Bangkok so much less stressing (traffic in Bangkok can be a notoriously dreadful experience). What a positive surprise this new airport train is. Located down in the basement of the airport, it has 3 lines, one slow cityline and two non-stop express lines. I toook the express line into Praya Thai station which connected straight to the Skytrain. No hassels here with both elevators and escalators. It is only when you board the Skytrain you are in for overcrowded cars, and when arriving at the final destination, lots of stairs taking you down to the street level. Thus not very convenient with heavy suitcases. The airport train is clean and fast, only 17 mins from Praya Thai to the airport, runs every 30 mins (00 and 30 from Praya Thai) and is very inexpensive. From the moment I left the lobby at my hotel (Novotel Ploenchit) and to my arrival at the airport, only a total ca. 45 mins including Skytrain, connection time and travel on the airport train, and a ca. THB 50 spent on this journey. Will use again, 'cause as the saying goes: "If any sight in Bangkok cannot be reached by neither train nor boat, then it is probably not worth visiting!".
Everyday. I take it every morning to work, and its very convenient, and crowded but also fast and cold!! They even let you bring your bike onboard!
the immigration was going fast and smooth. very good the access to the trian to the city easy to travel and it is congested at times many people using it

Not much of a convenience!!!!. I will be the few ones to give a poor rating to this service - the reasons are many. I will lest them in no particular order.- Bangkok severely needs to expand its mass transit system for its growing urban population. Instead of building this airport link they could have used that money to expand its three existing lines or added a fourth one connecting to northern suburbs like Rangist or eastern suburb like Pinklao . Occasional tourists on the other hand can always take taxis and there are better off taking it anyway which I will expand below.-Even for tourists this railway link really doesn’t offer much convenience or time savings. Because Bangkok is big and not all the suburbs and hotels are connected with subway or sky train link. One may end up of taking taxi after getting of this railway link anyway. And most of the traffic jam is within the heart of the city so this railway link really doesn’t same that much time. Getting to heart of Bangkok from airport on this airport link vs. taking a taxi is about the same duration if you consider the time to wait for the train, getting on and getting off.- This airport link seem to be best suited for business travelers with hardly any luggage and who live near the link routes or sky train or subway lines.- While most of skytrain have escalators around Bangkok not this airport link. Which beats me. You would think that they would have designed this with tourists in mind that travel with more luggage than the daily mass transit people and would add escalators on every station. When you get off at Phaya Thai station it’s a zoo. The walkway beside the track on the station is not wide enough and usually there is a huge jam between people trying to get off and trying to get on the train. And again people getting off have to carry the luggage down the stairs. - If you get off at Makkasan station you have to come down to the street level and walk almost a city block with all your luggage to connect to the subway train.- All the stations along this route look like horse barns – dark and featureless with no windows or glasses – a far cry from glitzy Bangkok.

Fast and Cheap!. First time using Airport link from Airport. We arrive in the morning, there are promotion for offpeak only 20 baht for all stations.Wait about 7mins, board the train to Ratcha Prarop station, 20 mins reach. Very Fast!We use the Airport link to the Airport cost 45 baht, it is full of tourist, student and other worker, very full same as Singapore mrt peak hour.Use ARL if you carry light luggage. Mostly stairs. I saw 1 old man carry 2 big luggages through all the stairs, so dangerous.

DEPENDABLE!. It's cheap, always on time, not packed like a sardine can and not subject to the horrendous Bangkok traffic! It takes me 1 hours and 75 Baht to go from my door in Thong Lo to the Airport. The relaxing, hassle free way to go!

Bangkok's Rail Link-not perfect, but improved. Bangkok finally has an efficient and inexpensive high speed rail link from the airport into the city. The Express train costs 90 baht and took 16 minutes from the airport to Piya Thai, where I was able to get on the BTS Skytrain to get to my hotel. The City Line costs 45 baht and takes about 10-15 minutes longer. A taxi normally costs around 300 baht, and takes about 30 minutes depending on traffic. It stops (for a minute) at a dozen stations on the way to Piya Thai.If you have a lot of luggage, a taxi may still be the way to go, as there are a limited number of escalators from the airport link exits down to the street level for taxi service to your hotel. The same can be said for the BTS, where you have to carry your bags down several flights of stairs at most stations (except Asoke). All in all, the rail link is a great savings in time and money. it can be improved with more down elevators and more trains during peak hours. I will use the Airport link, which runs from 6:00 AM-midnight, on my future trips to Bangkok. I can only hope that some of the improvements mentioned will be addressed.

Make sure you get the express ticket. This is a brilliant option compared to the alternatives. The ticketing at the airport can be a little confusing for first time users, and I ended up on the all stations train, which became crowded. Not fun with a big suitcase. I got the right train on the way back, much better.

fast comfort. It's very convenient if you can get where you're going from the station, which is quite near the Monument of Victory. The speed is well worth it if you plan in advance for your airport transit

Fantastic but ... only if you travel with light luggage. You would not want to carry your heavy equipment to escalators and over stairs or to taxis if you are not travelling light. So I also tend to use taxis as you have to get to/from Phaya tai or Makassan anyway. So if you got luggage and can afford a 300 Baht extra get a taxi. In case of huge traffic jams along the highway to the airport the Airport Link is a good option, just talk to your taxi driver, he will know about the traffic situation. If drivers are hard to convince to go to the airport, the Airport Link maybe the better option.

Fast and efficient way for airport transfer. The ARL is the most convenient airport transfer in Bangkok. From ARL you can transfer to BTS at Phaya Thai. Moreover, it is cheap, u can have return transfer for less than 100baht. Imagine taking taxi for a trip to city, surely will be more 3 or 4 times more. Even with big lugguage, there is room to place them in ARL trains.

A cheap option to reach Bangkok from the airport. As other reviewers have pointed out, there are two services over this line: a non-stop express service to Makkasan station (which may or may not be convenient for your destination) taking 15 minutes and the City Line service making a number of stops before Makkasan then continuing to Phaya Thai station where there is an interchange with the BTS Skytrain. Currently the single fare from the airport to Phaya Thai on the stopping service is 45 Baht and the journey takes 30 minutes.Both services leave from the Basement level of Suvarnabhumi airport. City Line trains leave every 15 minutes and it was just my luck to get a train leaving at a very busy time around 5pm. The trains are quite short and we had half the population of South East Asia in ours. However, the trains are air conditioned, smooth and comfortable.At Phaya Thai there is a direct connection to the Skytrain but there's quite a bit of walking and taking lifts/flights of stairs involved. By the time I'd done this with my suitcase then taken the Skytrain, I was quite hot and sticky. Not a problem, as I could have a shower as soon as I got to the hotel, but I chose to get a taxi back to the airport. The taxi fare was 400 Baht including the tolls on the expressway.

Fast and easy. Taking the red and blue lines is basically the same - just a price difference, so if you're not in a huge rush just take the cheaper route. It drops you right at the airport so it's a super convenient way to leave/enter the city.

Fast, Efficient and Comfortable Ride. We used the express train to Phaya Thai.If you do not have huge baggages/luggages with you this definitely the way to travel. It is on time (just check out the schedule so you can plan the time you should get there especially if you are going to the airport for your departure flight) and really fast. Also, since this is not patronized yet by most travelers there is not much passengers and you actually have the choice where you want to sit.If you have huge luggage, the travel itself is wonderful. comfy and roomy seats with enough space for your luggage. However, upon disembarkation be prepared to lug your luggages as you trek the stairs or the elevator or wait patiently at a very narrow elevator. My sister I have only hand carried luggages so this is not a proble for us but I have to admit I do pitied the other tourist who had large baggages with them....
Super transport & cheap. I use this Rail Link many times.Quick and save time.You can al;so use this Rail Link to shopping in the center of Bangkok

Watch your change. I have used this railway a couple of times. The direct one, that links the airport to the BTS station in Bangkok cost 90 Bath for a trip. I asked for 2 tickets last saturday and paid with a 1.000 Bath note. The girl gave me my money back very quicly, without really counting it, so I decided to check it on the spot. I found out that she gave me 100 bath too less. I gave her the whole bunch of banknotes back (only 100 notes) and she did not even really checked them. She handed me again my change, but now in one 500 bath note and the remaing ones in 100 bath ones. Why she didnot do so the first time?????Arriving on Phaya Tai, the electric escalators where not working and we had to use the far away stairs. Poor guys carrying all their heavy luggage. Bad service, both of the cashier as from the maintenance staff.
It was ok. The airport rail link is an easy access and less hassle transportation mode going to the airport from one of the hotel in the Siam area. Nice view and fast one. :) Very cheap too!
Cheap and good. For those on budget, this is the one you should take. They have 2 types...the Express and non Express at different price.

Fast and convenient way to get to central Bangkok. The fast service - every 15-20 min. gets you to Makkasan in 15 min (currently 90 Baht). Perfect and certainly preferable to any taxi that will be definitely much slower and much more expensive (given the terrible traffic jams in that city). The company running the AirportRail link service should definitely do more to popularize it. I'm glad I found out a/t it before I went to Bangkok. Used it 4 times (as we went to Krabi & back via Suvarnabhumi airport). Every time infalliable. Not sure what the previous reviewer is taking about - every 40 min - !? - perhaps the other branch - the regular service...The fast service I took from Makkasan express operated every 15-20 max.

Be Aware!. Fast, efficient and easy service to the airport - but be aware - the airport link is only running every 40 minutes at the moment - so make sure you are leaving in plenty of time to get to the airport (especially if you are departing). The seats are comfortable, there's plenty of room for you and your suitcases. Great way to beat the traffic!

Great. The Airport Rail link was excellent for us as we picked a hotel right at a station. During the day the rail link comes every few minutes in both directions and at night you maybe have to wait 5 minutes. It is very quick and easy to the airport, although our starting station had a million stairs and the escalator was only going up!The link takes you in to Phaya Thai skytrain station, which then takes you on to other destinations. The link is very cheap, clean and spacious.
Fun to ride. Easy access to airport. However, some station don't have elevator. Beware. Express train takes every 20 minutes from one place to BKK airport. Check map first.
Fantastic. Great way to reach Bangkok city from the airport. Probably the fastest I have every reached the Bangkok city from the airport. Cheap and 100% on time.
express rail. easy ,fast, brilliant very clean what ever did we do before?if the route is what you need then wouldnt ever get a taxi again

Super fast and Reliable. This is absolutely the very best choice to get in and out of Bangkok if using "swampy", also known as Suvarnabhumi Airport. Reliable, cheap and comfortable. It takes about 15 minutes to complete the journey if using the express service and about 25 minutes if using the normal service.

A bit disjointed. Not very well thought out in most regards, too crowded at peak times, not enough trains, the links do not connect so you have to walk from one station over the road to another........dis jointed deal.

Needs later hours, but otherwise VERY convenient. BKK's airport is pretty far from center city + traffic is horrendous at all hours of the day + if you've never been here before and don't speak Thai chances are that your taxi ride will be much more expensive than it should be. It's ILLEGAL for taxi drivers to quote you a price- ask for the meter if you don't want to take the rail link... but if you do take the rail link it brings you right to the city's public transportation systems for much cheaper than a cab. Note that if you are staying on Khao San Road the BTS does not go there and you will still need to take a cab or tuk tuk- so you're probably better off taking a cab from the airport and skipping the rail link altogether.

Quick fast and convenient. The title says it all, quick, fast and convenient from or two the airport. Inexpensive also. There are two trains, one that does make a few stops along the way and costs slightly less and the express train which stops only once and cost a little more. The express train generally is not as crosed as the more local train, the express is your best bet.

Fast but Flawed. Bangkok's new Airport Link makes it possible to zip from the center of the city to Suvarnabhuymi Airport in about twenty minutes. It's great if you have only carry-on luggage. But if you have a lot of checked luggage, forget it. Some stations in the city do not have escalators when you exit them. Trains stop running at around 11 P.M. Too bad they do not run all night. Airport Link is popular with commuters in both directions, including a lot of airport staff, so seats will be scarce during morning and evening commute periods.

Very easy, cheap, clean and safe. I remember from a long time ago that the rail link out to the airport was in development, or still on the cards, and the date of completion always seemed to be far in the future. By all accounts, the Airport Rail Link has been operating for a few years now, and it is excellent.  Despite being half asleep after a dreadful red-eye flight, I was able to a; find the train station at Suvarnabhumi Airport and b; work out the ticket machines and get myself a little ticket/token. I had done a little research beforehand so I knew what I was doing, but the ticket machines are easy to understand. There is a ticket counter and staff were lingering near the machines if you need help, but it was a pretty standard system – select your destination, number of passengers then feed the money into the machine.  The trip was comfortable and the trains were noticeably clean and free of clutter. Coming from Melbourne it was nice to see a train that was not covered in graffiti and rubbish – you cannot eat or drink on the Airport Rail Link and that makes a difference to the state of the train. It took about 25 minutes from the airport to Phaya Thai station. The transfer from the Rail Link to the BTS was very smooth and well marked at that station. The Airport Rail Link is cheap (25THB) and a quick and efficient way to get into town. The system is easy to use, well staffed, and clean and comfortable. A highly recommended way to get to and from the airport.

Great quick way out to the airport.. I would suggest taking the Airport Rail Link if you are a solo traveler or traveling during rush hour in Bangkok. The train system is very efficient and drops you right off at the airports lower level. You can wave to all the people sitting in traffic on the highway out to the airport too!
10th wonder of the world.. Okay. Not really. But this is the best addition to Bangkok since the traditional Thai massage. No traffic. Relaxing. Good stuff.

Very Useful & Reliable. While it was meant to primarily shift large numbers of (preferably affluent!) tourists into downtown Bangkok, the City Line (the non-express line) has become a very useful commuter line for those living towards Minburi/Nong Jork. The downside is that it is very difficult to get a seat nowadays during the rush hours of about 7-9 am and 5-7 pm. Aside from the annoying announcements that 'a train is approaching ...' (hell NO!), there isn't really much to complain about, although it is about time the frequency was increased. Perhaps a few more carriages could be added? If you're traveling from the airport into Bangkok during non-peak hours, the difference in journey time is only about 15 minutes, so the City Line (with a cheaper fare) might suffice.

Slow with unfriendly ticket saler staff. The ticket saler staff at the Suvarnabhumi airport was totally unfriendly like she did not want to work.The express train is actually not that fast because it does not run all the time. Sometimes you could get to the city faster with normal trains (which has many stop) which could depart like 20 minutes before the express ones.

Not frequent enough. I arrived on a Friday night at around 11pm, have to wait for around 30 mins for the train, but it takes another 30 mins to arrive at my destination - Phaya Thai.When I went back to the airport from the city, I spent 300Baht from Phaya Thai to Airport. Traffic was not bad.
Slow. i will rather traveller to get a cab or some other transport to the city or any place you wanna go . However during a traffic jam , The rail link is the most useful transport.
Airport - to Bkk city. Clean, fast, not really expensive is the right solution if you don't want to stak on the terrible bangkok traffic...
speed without trouble matters. it is convenient to reach the airport and no pollution or rush hour and real quick less risk than a cape, clean, incognito means no questioning why and where from

A good start... I used this service just a few months after its official launching.. there're two types, local and express.. I took the express one.. it's clean and brand new.. also with extra compartment for big luggage.. It costed 150 bath (if I am not mistaken) and only took 15 minutes from the airport to the last station where to change to the subway.. The only disadvantage that time was the station was not integrated with neither the subway nor the skyline.. I had to get out from the station, pull my luggage (luckily only one) a few hundred meters and get into the subway station.. can't imagine if traveling with small kids and a lot of luggage.. Hope they have solved this problem.. certainly it's incomparable to the system in Japan or Europe.. but at least it's a good start for Thailand and Bangkok to provide a better transport..

Express.... I used the Airport Rail Link Express and it costs 150 Baht Round trip. If you are time-conscious, then the express lane is the better option. It is a non-stop journey from the airport. You choose to drop off either Makkasan or Phaya Thai station, your choice, no stops at all. It is approximately 18 minutes from the airport to Phaya Thai station.The only down:1. Toilet in the Express lane is not functioning on both trips I had.

Needs more escalators. It's a wonder why the architects and the engineers for the airport rail link failed to provide for more escalators, especially going down the platform (there is none, by the way). It's really hard going down the stairs with the luggage. There's an elevator but its so small that i doubt 5 people can comfortably fit into it with luggage. Such an inconvenience!

A great idea with poor integration into the environment. I always want rail connections to airports worldwide. But this one is an indication of why many Thai projects stumble. "Poor megaplanning." Connections to the local elevated trains and subway are poor with little thought about luggage. Changing to and from taxis often requires navigating congested streets lacking traffic signals. I wish I could recommend this but that will have to wait until they install more escalator connections and other amenities. Taxis are low cost and they use compressed natural gas-- so at least they are low contributors to hydrocarbon pollution. One day this rail link will be a complete implementation.

The best way to town. This is a fantastic rail link that was just opened. There are two trains with the express going straight to a Skytrain hook-up. The other train stops at every station for locals and only goes as far as Makasson Station. From there follow the crowd to the subway.

Too much hassle. This was an experience not to be repeated, way too much hassle. I have been to many cities where the airport link really works but here it doesn't, maybe it is not really finished or something.

Very easy transport to the city. Very easy, comfortable, quick and also cheap transportation option from airport to the city center. Only one note - it would be more better if they will build one more stop more close to the historical city center - somewhere around democracy monument.

Link to.. where?. Ok, you saved some 250 bath or so worth of taxi... an you get to Paya Thai BTS station. Here you can choose: either you continue with the BTS (and you carry your own bags down the stairs: look for the only, small, and hidden lift if your luggage is heavy, or you have kids) or you take a taxi from here: make no mistakes, the few taxies waiting for you here will NOT use the meter for tourists: and you might find yourself paying back what you saved, plus you are likely to get stuck in a horrible traffic jam ( Paya Thai is a very busy place).Honestly. unless you final destination is right in front of a BTS station, it is much more convenient to take a taxi-meter in the airport and hit the highway. This unless you are arriving on a Friday afternoon: in this case the rail might save an hour or so of your time.

Great way to shuttle between Airport and City. The train from Suvarnabhumi International airport to city centre is a big boon for travellers. We really made full use of the service while travelling from our Baiyoke Hotel to Airport.
30mins frequency. Be prepared to wait as it is so infrequent.Better way of mode of transportation as timing more reliable than taxi.Cheap but can be very crowded.

What the heck?. I love the Hong Kong airport link. The bangkokian one is a sad affair comparatively. The checking in should be done more than 3 hours prior to departure. What a joke! Non stop links are every 20mn supposedly.

Convenient and clean. The trains, stations and platforms were clean. Buying a ticket was convenient and easy enough. The airport rail link probably requires a lot more room for luggages/backpacks though.

Easy transportation to the city. I found the ARL really help me. The best transportation if you arrive in Survanabhumi and want to continue to the city. Suitable for backpaker and anyone who travel lite. It's connected withe several BTS and MRT station, so you can easily transfer to BTS or MRT and explore Bangkok city.
Operation hour: 6.00 - 24.00.
Location: basement floor

Simple, easy and cheap if you're traveling light. This train, which has express and local variants, is an easy way to get into Bangkok from the airport and is a great idea, especially during peak traffic times. We took the local for 45THB each, which is a great value compared with taxis. It runs every 15 minutes or so. But there's nowhere to store luggage and the stations in the city have lots of steps and no one (at least no one legitimate) to help with luggage. We were fine, as we had backpacks, but this is not a good mode of transportation for those with 2 large bags per person.My understanding is that the express trains have luggage areas on board. But at 150THB per person, I'm not sure I would prefer the express over a taxi, unless I were staying right next to Makkasan or Phaya Thai.
Take if you are travelling light.. Very convenient if you want to connect to BTS or MRT. Luggage handling and taxis are a problem once you arrive at stations.

Quick and easy. I found that the Airport rail link was an easy way to get from the airport to my hotel and back. Thecost was reasonable and the service efficient. It was a little difficult to connect with the subway at one of the main stations as you had to leave the station and walk a block and a half to the subway and the signage was poor, but you just follow the others and have faith, and lo and behold, there it is, the subway. If you have a lot of luggage it would be challenging, but otherwise it was very easy. Cabs are pricy and the traffic is absurd so this is a great option

Too many stairs!!. Finally we get a public form of transport and what we get is several thousand stairs to climb. Does anyone ever consider the effort required for old people to climb all those stairs.Waiting patiently for escalators.

Easy airport connection to the MRT of BTS. There are 3 different unique train lines that leave from the airport, make sure you are getting on the right one.1) Makkasan Express - Non-stop that connects to the MRT2) Phaya Thai City Line - Stops at multiple places on the way to the Phaya Thai BTS3) Phaya Thai Express - Non-stop that connects to the BTSI took the Phaya Thai City Line at 45 Bhat from the Airport to the Phaya Thai BTS, it was relatively comfortable but felt like a normal innercity train (plastic seats, no place for luggage, etc.)I then took the Phaya Thai Express to the Airport at 90 Bhat (150 Bhat for a Roundtrip Ticket), this train had luggage storage, was non-stop, very smooth, very fast, and had comfortable seats. This felt like a long-distance train.I highly recommend using the airport link as it is fast and will likely save you money. However the airport link is not a good idea under the following circumstances, a) if you are a group bigger than 2, a taxi is likely better value, b) If your hotel is not near to the BTS and you have luggage, Bangkok is hot! c) you have large luggage, there are a lot of stairs, small gates for the BTS, walking...If you just have a carry-on/bag, your hotel is right next to a BTS stop, and you are 2 people or less, the Phaya Thai Express (non-stop) is a great way to get to/from the airport and the city. Also remember that the Express runs every 30 minutes (on the half hour and hour when leaving Phaya Thai).

Life is made much easier. Great way to travel from BKK airport to the city.Despite weird logics of placing the terminal (Asoke) out of nowhere, without (real) connection to BTS or MRT, they have significantly improved quality of life for locals and foreigners alike. Good that government realized and changed the hub to Phayathai where you can easily connect to BTS SKytrain Phayathai station.Now look at the grand infrastructure at Asoke, it is such a shame that it was built without long-term plan.Anyway, def a great infrastructure BKK has.

highs and lows of rail link. at first i have always commended the airport rail link but after traveling to bkk airport from pattaya at an early evening time to find signs up saying BEWARE unofficial taxis but no official taxis allowed on site i was a bit disappointed in the mentality of the operators of this facility ,i know my way around a bit but what of the traveler who has just flown in ,no help is offered ,this just reeks of thai incompetence again come on sort it out,

Cheap but useless. Getting a taxi to or from the airport and most places in the city centre is less hassle and takes a similar time, and only costs a little bit more. I think they desperately need to sort the station at Makkasan out; at the moment it lacks onward connectivity.

go where?!. Yes, you can get on it at the airport. It is more a case where you can get off. I know, I just wrote not to go to Kao San, well, this 'link' won't take you there. Or to Sukhumvit. If you try to get there by public transport you have to drag your bags three times of and on a train, bus or metro. And yes, they are very full! It was a very good idea to get the airport linked to the city, but unfortunally the thai left it at the idea as such. It won't take you anywhere usefull. Sorry. I hate to be on the negatve all the time, I live here and love the city/country for wht it is, but these kiond of thing......they just don't have a clue! Take a taxi, yes more expensive, but better dragging your luggage up and down three stairs, four times in 37 degrees, just to get to your hotel. And what did you save? 30 bath! Nonsence!

This isn't a sight so much as a practical way for a traveler to get to and from the airport. This modem of transport to and from the airport is particularly useful when traveling solo or with 2 people. Otherwise, I think a taxi starts becoming cost competitive without the hassles of the express link. For what it is I find it extremely utilitarian. It gets me from a BTS or Metro (the metro connection is not as good) to the airport and vice versa for 90 Baht with no stops. I recall paying 150 Baht in March 2011, so it's nice try dropped the price (likely because it was empty back then). Is it the most comfortable train? No, but who cares for 20 minutes. It's not painful or anything. Is getting luggage through BTS and particularly the Metro a pain in the hiney? Yes, but if you want it done easily than spring for the cab and stop complaining. In summary i would describe the airport link as: Cheap, simple, relatively easy to use airport link that is especially worthwhile for 1 or 2 travelers. More than 2 get a cab that uses the meter. Walk to Departures level to find one already going back to Bangkok and more likely to use meter since its more cash than driving backto the city alone.

Bad design and service. WIth some bad luck you just missed the train and have to wait 15 to 20min for the next one to leave. Then exit & entrance is at the same side of the train, very nice with your suite-case in hand! No straight easy connections to any other public transport. Platform at end-station is much too small and has much to small exits.

Quite a decent Airport Rail Link. Facts (from my tired brain at 2 in the morning):---------------------------------------------------------Cost: 45 baht from Airport to the very end of the line. It's slightly less if you stop at one the in between stops.Duration: About 30 minutes (I think) from Airport to the very end of the line.The Good:-------------1) Cheap and hassle free! This train is a direct train from the Bangkok Airport to the middle of Bangkok city. I've used it twice. Prior to that, I used to take the taxi from the airport, which used to mean running the gauntlet of taxi tauts and paying about 400-600 baht, depending on who you settled with and how much energy you were willing to spend bargaining.I hate the taxi tauts.2) Fast!Approximately half an hour by train, or up to an hour longer if you take a taxi and get caught during peak hour traffic.3) Convenient! Actually goes where it's supposed to!Unlike some airport-city links, this one actually goes the to the city and actually links to stations of the existing train line...ok, at the very end, you have to walk about 50-100 metres from the Airport platform to the BTS one, but I mean, thats not too bad for 45 baht! Think of it as exercise and part of the holiday experience ! :-)Compare this to the Shanghai high speed express- does end near the existing train line, but very far from city centre; and the Hong Kong Aiport Express where at some stops you need mini buses or taxis afterwards.4) Connects to the existing train line. Just check the map to see which station to alight, and, if necessary, transfer.5) You'll see locals!Most of the passengers appear to be Thai so you'll be getting the full Thai experience the moment you step from the airport.The Bad:-----------1) No luggage racks in trains. The trains seem to be regular passenger carriages so you just keep them next to you. Not a biggie.2) There's no escalator or lift at the platforms.All above ground stations in Bangkok seem to only have stairs between the ticketing level and the train level (there are 3 levels- street--> ticketing--> train) This makes it inconvenient to lug around suitcases, especially while the crowd is surging around you at the stairs. Still, everyone seems to survive. Again, part of the experience!3) Taxis.This next point isn't directly related to the Airport link, since you'll have probably transferred to the regular train line, BTS, etc, but it still is since it's a consequence of taking the Airport Link.You still have to get to you hotel, right?If it's nearby to a station, you just walk to it.If it's still a bit of a distance, or it's the middle of the day and it's Bl****y hot and even 100 metres seems too far, then you're going to have to queue at the road and flag down a taxi or tuk tuk.Depending on the time of day or night, this may take some time. This is the one advantage of taking a taxi- driver goes directly to the hotel (assuming they know the hotel- so many new ones have been built in the last few years I've found it common for them not to know it. Still, I consider it to be part of the experience :-)Gosh, I didn't think I'd write so much for a train line! Thanks for reading!!!!
Get a taxi!!!. Waste of space & money. For two people or more it's cheaper in a standard airport taxi & door-to-door
great & quicker. great & quicker than taxi & cheaper no tolls to pay no traffic drops you straght at the airport wouldnt go any other way now

Clean and efficient way to leave the airport. I've used the extension of the BTS system a couple of times. It connects the airport with the Sukhumvit area of Bangkok via the existing BTS skytrain. When I have used it, it hasn't been the fastest service in he world, stopping at several stations along the way and taking around 30 minutes from terminus to terminus. But it is clean and comfortable and very cheap. Only a few bahts. So it has its uses, but I still use a taxi when I arrive in Bangkok. Why? A taxi can take only 40 minutes to Sukhumvit on a good day out of rush hour. I don't have to lug cases around and its a airport to hotel door service. A taxi may cost 300B to Sukhumvit but you can relax and just let the driver do all the hard work. If you are travelling kight or backpacking where travelling between stations on foot isn't a problem, then the airport link will be for you.

alarming White Elephant. what should be a jewel in the crown is a sad and cruel joke as it is impossibly dysfunctional and hard to get in and out of- looks like it was designed and planned by 16 opposing committees.

First Rate travel. Of all the airports that we have visited on our six week trip I have to say that the airport in Bangkok was by far the best coming into the country and leaving was so easy ( Vietnam please note ) that it was a pleasure to go through it as it is very easy to get about with helpful staff. We had heard so much about Dubai but this airport was by far better than it.

Best way to reach airport. Airport rail link is best way to and from the airport if you have luggage. We took the link from Phaya Thai station for 90baht per person and reached airport in 15mins. The frequency is every 30mins. There are no stops and there is enough space for luggage. It is definitely more convenient than taking the BTS as BTS would have people getting down at every station, which makes it difficult with luggage.

Good direction from the staff. I used the Airport Rail Link for the first time from Rajprarob station to Phayathai station. I have to walk up the stairs from the road to the station. It cost 15 Baht for one station. The staff is very helpful and give me the direction to the station by elevator.

Dear Tourists... We love tourists...but please please please avoid taking the city line during rush hour ( m-f 7am-9am and 5pm-8pm),,if you dont want to suffocate....the express train costs a little more but it is MUCH MUCH more convenient...oh..and when you arrive at phayathai station with big/multiple luggages,, please use the elevator at the far right of the platform...i dont like to hear people cussing/complaining about it, nor to see someone falls dowm those stairs...

Perfect For Getting From BKK Airport to Most Of Bangkok. Quick, simple, direct -- I recommend the express train straight from BKK to Phaya Thai BTS station. From there, you can get to much of the city. The train is quiet, clean, and fast enough. Not much else to say here; it's a city train that you will spend less than 15 minutes on!

Fastest mode to reach airport. I would say this is one of the fastest way to reach Bangkok International Airport. Costs about 90 Bahts (at least when I was there last October) per trip. Starting from Phaya Thai, this non-stop rail link reaches airport in about 15-20 mins. However frequency is not so great running one every 30 mins. Still a great, hassle free mode to reach airport
no escalator. We need escalator or at least easy walk way not stairs. Everyone from Airport have big luggages. R U CRAZY!!! Thailand ONLY!!!
Short, Direct trip to the City. Was a simple, direct, and cheap transportation to the city. I only wished that the line operated later than Midnight

An excellent way to travel from Suvarnabhumi to Downtown Bangkok!. Since the introduction of the Airport Rail Link I have made use of only this mode of transport from the airport to downtown Bangkok and back. It is an excellent way to travel (in my opinion) for a number of reasons. There are no traffic jams to contend with. It gets you to the Pratunam area in approximately 30 minutes or so. It is extremely competitively priced. Comparitively speaking it is much cheaper than the airport links in Hong Kong, Kuala Lumpur, Johannesburg and the the Metro Rail in Dubai.

Fast and cheap. Unless you got a bunch of luggage and/or are far from where the stations are, this is a great way to get to the city from the airport. It's only 45 Baht to take it from the airport to the end of the line and it takes only 30 minutes to do it in a nice air conditioned train with no traffic anywhere. Taxi from airport to the Patpong area is about 350 Baht give or take depending on traffic and how long you sit around in it. The rail link and the BTS cost me like 65 Baht and it was a nice ride. Had to walk to my hotel instead of getting dropped off at the front door but still worth saving about 2-3 beers worth of Baht.If you get off at Makkasan Station it's a bit of a walk to the metro station but one you get there it's 4-5 stops to Silom. Take it to the end at PhayaThai-near MBK, and it's only four stops on the BTS to Sala Daeng station(Silom) near where I was staying.

Choose the express line to Phyathai Station. When you come and want to travel to the center of Bangkok, please choose the espress line direct to Phyathai station and you can go straight to the center of BKK such as Sukhimvit, Rajprasong and Silom by the BTS. It would be a bit confused, please follow the sign to the BTS, do not get off and walk downstairs to the road yet, just walk through the BTS!

Fast, but not necessairly more convenient. There are two express lines from the airport: one going nonstop to Makkasan Station, where there is in walking distance an underground subway line, and the other line going to Phaya Thai station, where the Airport Rail Link easily connects with the elevated Skytrain. My suggestion, either way, is to take the Airport Rail Link to either station, then just get in an inexpensive taxi to your hotel. Most hotels will be closer to Makkasan Station rather than Phaya Thai station. It's very fast and comfortable and cheap, but if two or more people are traveling together, a taxi from the airport is probably going to be easier and only about 100 baht more total. Eventually, they will build some hotels adjacent to the stations.

Fast and economical. If you don't have much luggage with you, skytrain should be your mode of transport to or from airport. There is an express line from airport for 90 baht per person that doesn't stops anywhere in between. There is another one for 45 baht that stops at some 5-6 stations. We took just 20 minutes to travel to the city whereas it takes about 1 hour in normal traffic conditions if you travel by road. Moreover, you will have to shell out atleast 350 baht for one way transfer via cab.

Fast and cheap transportation. Easy access and direct connection to the Skytrain System, will avoid traffic jam, not too good with a lot of heavy luggage, good service to guide you to the trains, fast

Take this to avoid the hassle of traffic. If your house or hotel is not far from the rail link, the BTS or the subway, use this if you don't have a lot of luggage to avoid travelling via taxi during rush hour traffic. I used it once and I will use it again during peak traffic hours. It was a fun ride the first time, though there was not that much to see, and I liked the idea that I would get home at a set time rather than take a risk of wasting money, sitting in an expensive airport taxi or limo.

Such a handy, fast and cheap way to get to the airport!. For only 35TBH, you get from Makkasan to the airport in about 20min.
