No need to worry about the traffic or whether the taxi driver is bringing you on a little tour before bringing you to the airport, the airport link is probably the cheapest and most reliable way to go to or from the airport.Little tip when you take it from the airport: Staff from the train company might offer you to take the fast airport link (90TBH instead of 35TBH) which is not so much faster and not frequent, so refuse and say you want to take the "normal train". Otherwise you might wait longer for the train so it is not so fast in the end!!

Very useful, especially for the solo traveller heading into town.. Prices are currently 45 Baht for the City Line and 90 Baht for the Express Line. Very good and useful addition to Bangkok's transport infrastructure.

Like a hop. It's quick and convenience but the express' schedule is not that easy. It's is every 30 min between 6am til midnight. That means early-morning-departure passengers and late-night-arrival passengers can not access the service. Last time, I have to run to the train from arrival area with 20+ kg dragging luggage and 7+ kg carry-on to catch the last train.

Easy Airport - City Access. Cheap fast way to get to/from the airport to downtown. The only downfall is if you have lots of luggage, it is difficult when you have to interchange from the Airport Rail Link to the BTS SkyTrain at Phaya Thai Station.

Fast and Convenient. From the airport, I decided to try Suvarnabhumi Airport Rail Link. There are two options available, take the express line (red line) which gets you to the city in 15 mins or the normal line (thin blue line) which makes a few stops and gets you to the city in 30 mins.I asked the staff there and was advised to just take the city line since the express train isn't scheduled to depart in another 30 mins. I paid about 45 baht (S$2). I ended up waiting for 15 mins before the city train arrived.The trip was quite fast and I alighted in Phaya Thai station, this is connected to the main train stations particularly the BTS. As you can see from the map below, Phaya Thai is already near the main tourist destinations such as Siam and Victory Monument.It can be quite troublesome if you have a big luggage with you since you have to go down a flight of stairs and then climb back up to get to the main railway.I was staying at Sanam Pao station, just two more stops so my entire experience was fairly convenient and fast. It's also cheap as a normal cab fare would set me back about 10 times what I paid for.Check out the photos here: http://bauerfan.blogspot.com/2012/04/suvarnabhumi-airport-rail-link.html

Could not be worse. Ok they cut the fare to 45/90 for city line/express lane respectively, but :The trains are uncomfortableThe stations are virtually inaccessibleThere is no handling facility for luggage.Makassan station is the only place in Bangkok where there is no taxi, I had to wait 20 minutes to see the first one coming and he refused to take me. I had to walk to Petchburi to find a taxi, with my two suitcases across Asoke and SRT lines , being dressed for winter weather when outdoor temperature was nearing 40.Combined time of various transportation (walk form airport exit to station, train, wait for taxi plus taxi) is longer than taking directly a taxi from airport.Cost is marginally lower.From Airport to Sathorn: 90+45(expressway)+70 taxi = 205Taxi from airport to Sathorn = 240+50+45+25= 360, for faster door to door service.The train frequency is too long, 15 minutes for city line and 30 minutes for airport express.The stations are located in nightmarish locations, speaking of traffic jam. Paya Thai, Ratchaparop and Makassan can be virtually inaccessible at peak hours.The only positive is the staff which is helpful when we can find them.

Very Easy. Often when travelling i find i tend to shy away from public transport systems and opt for the "easy" taxi. This system really couldnt be easier and has re-written the rule book for me.In March I visited Bangkok twice. The first time i did just that.... Took a taxi. Immediately had the battle of getting the driver to use the meter, endured some dangerous driving in an old car with no seatbelts and bad air con. Had to figure out how much the toll fees were and in the end the driver couldnt find the hotel - even though i had the address in thai. Second time round i opted for the airport link. Finding it is easy as it is in the basement of the airport and well signed. No danger of getting the wrong train as the only route is to the city. I was staying in Chit Lom, which is on the BTS skytrain route, so got the airport link all the way to Phaya Thai station. The system is easy, buy token from machine ( in english) and walk on. The train is extremely clean and there are no crazy people. the service is very efficient and fast. I wouldnt recommend this if you have a large amount of luggage however as there just isnt the space to put it. 1 medium to large case per person is manageable. Once at Phaya Thai it is a short and well signed walk to the BTS Skytrain network which is similarly effective. Well signed, very clean and safe. A few stops and $1 later I am practically outside my hotel. No stress of dealing with taxi drivers, dangerous driving and air con that doesnt work. There is absolutely no reason to take a taxi if you are staying anywhere near a BTS station. I cant recommend this enough, it is THE way to get around Bangkok.
fast and good value. very fast and good value, plus you dont have to go through the hassle of a taxi trying to bump up the fair
Excellent. Hassle free, easy to use... what more do I need to say.

Bangkok City Airport Link a Poor Service. While either the express train or the local stopping train takes you directly to the airport in 20 or 35 minutes respectively there are long waits for the trains. The airport link express train leaves only every 30 minutes with a similar schedule for the city link stopping train. On the city link there is no room for storing luggage and even the airport link has limited storage capacity in the carriages. A promised luggage car in which luggage would be stored and transported to the airport has not materialised.The connection to the BTS Phyathai station while easy to navigate the BTS Skytrains are designed and intended for people carriage only. So bulky cases cause a nuisance to other passengers on the often very full Skytrains. One then has to negotiate the few escalators and steps to the pavement level.The Airport link station at Makasan does not connect to any other transport system, not buses, underground trains nor the Skytrain and one either has to tramp across some pretty rough ground and a four-lane road or railway line to get to Petchburi Road metro station or get one of the few taxis from the Makasan terminal.The terminal itself is large and mainly empty because it is underused. There is a flight check in area but only one airline uses the facility, even though it was designed for many more airlines. This again is underused and hardly worth the bother. From the ground concourse level to the platform there are only one or two escalators and lift(s) meaning that most people will carry heavy luggage up three flights of stairs to the platforms.All in all this facility is not worth using because of its inconvenient location and dearth of facilities. The last time I used it the one-way fare from the airport was 150 baht and the taxi to Silom Road in the centre of Bangkok was another 100+ baht. A taxi from the airport to my home would get me there in about the same time and cost a similar amount.A very poor, badly planned facility for a busy city like Bangkok.

It works well. There have been many complaints about the airport rail link in the past, but it takes you right from the lower level of the airport to Paya Thai BTS station, in the heart of BKK in 15 minutes (if you take the express) and about half an hour if you take the regular train. At 90 or 45 baht, it is a bargain--and less stressful than having to deal with BKK taxi drivers.

Quick and easy. I had read reviews about the airport rail link taking a long time... And being a little exensive. I found both of these points to be false. On the way back to he airport from Bangkok I took a taxi that cost me 450 baht where as the airport link rail was a mere 150baht and didn't depend on traffic. I found it pretty simple to find... Just keep going down towards the metro signs and eventually I found people ready to guide all of us jetlagged people to the right place.There are three lines on the airport link... All of them take different amount of times and stop in different places to help cover all areas of town. I was going to hualangmanphu train station so I took the yellow express line all the way the penchenaburi stop, walked outside for about 5 min across the street (sign posted) to the MRT station that then took me all the way to my destination. I am not saying the system is foolproof, and I did have to ask for directions but it is a normal form of transport and safe. The transport from airport to train station took about a half hour. Was on an international flight and had just under 2 hours for all of the customs, picking up my bag and transport and I still made my train with time to spare!

Taxi is the much better and cheaper option. I don't know what they were thinking when they built this train.Poorly connected to subway and skytrain, Uncomfortable stations, trains (except express train) overcrowded during rush hours, etc etc etc. The list is long. Take a taxi, door to door, no hauling of luggage in 40 degrees heat. Taxi from the airport downtown Bangkok is 10 USD, train plus skytrain and/or subway is 5 USD.
Easy way to travel. This is a great and affordable way to get to and from the airport 45 Baht each way. However during peak time the express train, while a costing a bit more is worth it.

A good addition to Bangkok public transport network. The trains are new and work well. It is really great to have this option to bypass traffic jams when traveling to the airport or neighborhoods around the stations. Bangkok residents already make the City Line trains pretty crowded. The main drawback is that there are multi-floor staircases to navigate when exiting the stations. This makes using the train difficult for incoming passengers who have arrived at the airport, since those stairs are no fun with heavy luggage. Getting to the airport is easier, since the stations have escalators and the Suvarnabhumi station provides them also for getting to the departure floor.
Best way to get out of the airport and into the heart of Bangkok. And cheap!. Best way to get out of the airport and into the heart of Bangkok. And cheap!

Fast and cheap.. Easily reach once you are out from the customs. 45B all the to Phaya Thai station and transfer to the BTS line depending where your hotel is located. Trains are big and comfortable. Best way to get into city area as Bangkok is famous for traffic jams.
cheap and convenient. its close to where i live and i can always fetch and go to the airport with no hassle

Fast and inconvenient.. I am a bit torn about this review. The Airport Rail Link express lines are super fast, clean and comfortable, never crowded. 17 minutes to the airport from Phaya Thai BTS, 15 from the Makkasan station.BUT:Makkasan: getting to Makkasan station is a horror. You can walk from Asoke BTS (far) or Phetchburi MRT (not so far), if you don't have much to carry and don't care about getting hot. But Makkasan is located in a morass of one-way streets. Bangkok taxi drivers are so far expressing unwillingness to go there, if they even know where it is. And while it is getting easier to get proper, licensed taxis when leaving, it is by no means a sure thing, which means it is fairly useless if you have luggage.Phaya Thai: Is just fine but again, difficult if you have a lot of stuff. I find myself on ARL thinking "This is great, if only 'they' had thought things through!".

Fast, but not for people with luggage. The train itself is nice: clean & fast. The problem is that if you're travelling with suitcases, getting up & down from the platform on the Phayathai end is not easy. Nor is it very easy to get taxis from there. Recommended for those who are travelling light and are staying somewhere along the BTS Skytrain.

Fast ride into town. I took the express train to Makassan. Cost was 90 baht and took 15 minutes. Clean, safe and air conditioned. Train was almost empty so lots of space. At the airport, go to the lowest level and follow the signs.At Makassan, I was able to walk to my hotel but there were taxis there waiting. If it is raining and your hotel is far from the station, you may be better to take the local train and connect to the skytrain or just take a taxi the whole way from the airport. Andrew

Good way to get from airport to down town bangkok. The rail link is very good if you are alone and not have much luggage and also your hotel is near the skytrain. The fare from the airport is B 45( A $ 1.45), then depending on what skytrain station you go to from Phayathai( terminal station) from airport.If there are more than one person in your party and you have to travel far from a BTS station then take a taxi around A$ 8-10 to downtown bangkok( taxi metre).

Convenient from airport to Sukhimvit. If you're looking to get into town quickly without spending time in the traffic, the airport link is for you. It is usually packed and you sometimes have to wait up to 15 minutes for a train. The only difference is that its a lot cheaper than a taxi.

Fast and efficient but.... This service is fast and efficient. The trains and the station are spotless and you will definitely be on time to catch your flight BUT when returning from the airport to Makassan station, it was impossible to find a taxi and we ended up dragging suitcases along Petchaburi Road in the rain trying to hail a taxi. Admittedly, this was only the one time and it was raining (which in Bangkok makes it difficult to get a taxi anywhere) but it was very frustrating! On other occasions, we have been more successful in getting a taxi.

The Best & cheapest way to travel from Airport. Saved myself many Baht travelling to & from the airport to Phaya Thai. Only 45B to Phaya Thai then another 40B on the BTS to Wongwian Yai so total paid would be 85B. On the taxi from the airport you would be 350B plus tolls and that is if you are lucky. Many taxi drivers at the airport prey on jetlagged tired tourists and dont use the meters. They will charge a set fee 500-700B to get to your destinationOnce you have gone through immigration & got your suitcases keep going down and down to the basement of the airport.I would recommend you catch the slower airport train only 45B that stops at every stop. It only takes 28 minutes to Phaya Thai and being first on the train you should be guarenteed a seat. These trains run every 15 minutes so they are quite regular and all have aircon. I see no point paying 150B for the express that takes 15 minutes to reach its destinationOnce at Phraya Thai I would use the lift to take you down a level. It is a bit of a trek across the platforms. Depending on where you are staying in Bangkok you may wish to take a taxi from Phaya Thai if your hotel is not near a BTS stop. Because Phaya Thai is in the heart of the city a cab journey to anywhere should not exceed 100B.The ARL is cheap quick & convenient no traffic jams no tolls no levies. Dont forget it does not run between midnight and 6am

fast but not regular. when the non stop trains come they are great but outside peak hours they dont come that often. if there are more than 2 of you and you have luggage a taxi is still better and cheaper. the regular non stop train gets very busy with commuters.

Best way to travel to City. The airport link has two lines to the city, and Express and City Line, both with frequent services. The City line has 7 stops, takes 24 minutes and runs a Metro stye train (side seating). The Express only goes to Makkasan station (close to city) takes 13 minutes and runs a suburban style train (proper seating and luggage areas). The Siemens trains travel up to 160 Km/h and are smooth running on the elevated tracks. The City line stations are not particularly designed for travellers with luggage but link up with other city rail transport including BTS (SkyTrain) and MRT (subway/Metro). The Express line ends at Makkasan station, which is a large terminal style building (almost deserted on my visit), is designed for travellers with lifts and waiting areas, although strangely no seats on the platform and the station has nothing useful nearby, but only a few Km from hotels. Tickets are cheap, and cheaper than a taxi even with a few travellers. Makkasan also offers check in for Thai Airlines only (not tried), and is apparently close to Metro station (not used). There were limit number of Taxi waiting and we Taxi didn't like to take you there, obviously preferring to take you to the Airport themselves. So be very clear in the instructions that it is Airport Link Makkasan and not the Airport itself. Overall a fast (given Bangkok traffic) and safe way to the city compared to a crazy (often high speed) taxi ride with no seatbelts. The official site with timetable and current fares is http://airportraillink.railway.co.th/en/index.html

Not just to get to the airport.. If you think of this just for getting to the airport, you may be missing its best use. Actually, if you're with a group with luggate, a taxi may be more economical and convenient to use.But the City Line local service makes 6 intermediate stops between termini at Suvarnabhumi Airport and Phaya Thai SkyTrain Station. It's the most convenient access to a wide swath of the eastern part of the city. Beyond that, it's also good for some of the main downtown between Phaya Thai and Rachadapisek Roads.
It works. The train line works as intended and is pretty comfy.

The fastest & cheapest way to Suvarnabhumi Intl. Airport. It only takes 17mn to go from Makassan station downtown to Bangkok International Airport. One way ticket costs 90 Baht and RT 150 Baht. This is only valid from the area of Siam Square. However, there exists another line, which functions like the Skytrain and stops at several stations on the way. The Express Link is smooth and comfortable. It also offers a great view over Bangkok skyline.

Good alternative for tuk-tuks. If you want to rest from the noisy tuk-tuks and other ways of road transportation in Bangkok, water trams are a good alternative. Reasonable rate per "ride" makes the journey pleasant. Better to take the boat for longer distances, as the rate is the same, no matter how many stops you pass. Nice option to have a look at the city from riverside.
great service. We used this service for visiting the Vat Pho and Vat Arun. Service is basic, quick and a bit crowded. But this is the best way to visit the river front monuments

My favorite transport in BKK. Whether I am heading across the River( Chao Praya) to visit the medical curiosity museum in Thonburi,catching the local train to Kanchanaburi,going to Wat Pho or Wat Arun or wanting t use the BTS I always opt for these boats.The ones with no flag stop at every "port of call" so cannot be rightly called the EXPRESS boat are my usual choice because they are less than 20 baht and ,Ithink,come more often.The express boats have several different color flags for different stops & you can ALWAYS hop onto any boat without a ticket as they will happily sell you one on the boat. I also like the coolness of the wind on the river,watching the long-tailed boats,going under the big bridges,watching the locals goo to work and play...and the fact that I can hop off spontaneously at any of the 20+ stops & just explore a new part of Bangkok.What's not to like!
Convenient and fast. The river provides eaay access to a great number of locations. It is a very scenic way to travel with god views of the city and many of the wats.

Easy and fun way to get around Bangkok. The local express boats are a cheap, easy and fun way to get around Bangkok. A great way to beat traffic, and it's lovely to be on the water and see Bangkok from a different perspective.

Top. The perfect way to go from A to B or spend some time sightseeing on the river. When at the ferries near the royal palace, they will often target you for 500 THB klong tours. These trips last 30 -45 minutes and are total rip-off. You can go from the ferry near Khao san road or the palace all the way up north to Pak Kred and back for about 70-80 THB, And that's almost a 2 hour round trip. More bang for buck you're not going to get in BKK.
A great way to see the city. This is a wonderful and very fast way of seeing Bangkok or simply to get from point A to B and thus to avoid the congested streets.

The boat itself is great, a real taste of Bangkok life but the queueing and buying tickets was a little more confusing. Great way to explore the city, we got one way ticket for 40BT, they don't have much change so make sure you have some small notes as it took them ages to change a 1000TB note. We got on the orange flag express boat from Sathorn (central pier) at 5.30pm to watch the sun go down on the river. There is another tourist boat on the river as the orange express is also a commuter boat, but i found that we got to see everything we wanted and if you have red any of the main travel guides, you'll already know the Grand Palace and main temples etc. We hopped off and walked to Khao San Road (to very quickly tick a box - it wasn't great, very tacky) and then headed into China Town for a fantastic meal. you can buy a pass for the river boats which means you can hop on and off all day for 150BT which would be a nice way to get around as a lot of the main attractions (The Grand Palace, the flower market, Asiatique market etc are on this route)

Off Season. Went in the off season but it was still crowded and it's interesting to see what people are selling on the street to get to the boat. The boat however was exciting and you really get to see the surrounding wonders.
Exciting shuttle service. A fun and entertaining way to cross the river and visit the temple. The boats pack quite a punch so the acceleration can be breath taking on occasion.

A Punctual Transportation. If you have heard about the traffic jam in Bangkok. after using each public transportation in Bangkok you can answer immediately which is more on time. One of the punctual public transportation in Bangkok is Chao Phraya Express Boat. If you don't want to waste your time with waiting a bus you had better take this one. ;-)
The most enjoyable form of mass transit in Bangkok. No traffic jams, seasonal breezes, lovely views, super cheap fares, efficient movement to any place along the river. My favorite!
Current under rennovation - no need to visit. Not worth a visit at this time as the entire place is under rennovation. Unless you like to take pics with scafffolding. :)
River Ferry to Sanam Luang. Took the boat from Sapan Thaksin to the pier next to the Navy Club leaving us within easy distance of the que for Sanam Luang. Better than fighting traffic.

Great WET but FUN experience. I really enjoyed again my 10+ trip on the river. It's a nice way to discover BKK on an untraditionnal way, for tourists it's fun, wrt sometimes if you sit at the relling. For the locals it's another easy, fast and cheap way to travel within this huge city. Mingle with locals on these fast and safe boats and have an unforgettable experience. DO NOT MISS A RIDE ON THE CHAO PRAYA YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT!
Fast. Fast way to travel, just take some earplugs to avoid damage of ear drum by the whistle of the staff making noise on every platform

Bus circulate in the river. You can move through different stops on these boats like a bus. Price about 0.35 €. You pay more expensive if boarding a ship tourist, I recommend the local boat. It is fast comfortable and great views. It allows you to move around Bangkok and change zone.I recommend you to travel cheap and will enjoy the trip
Amazing ride. So cheap. Staff is very cool. Lots of temples to be seen from the boat. A taste of Bangkok like no other
Another fun water ride. Seeing Bangkok is so much easier from the water!! no traffic jams and quite a view!!!!! Loved it and it's very cheap!!!!!!!!

good and cheap service. Quite comfortable to reach Palace and temple. Cheap at 40 THB one way. Remember to check when the ferry service will stop. There were guides on board who used a mike and kept explaining where to get down to see what.
Majestic Cruise.. A must experience cruise ship ride.....enjoy food and drinks onboard during nighttime enjoying beautiful surroundings....A very romantic experience for the couples.

Great value but beware of scams. A must do and excellent value for 14B a ticket. But beware, we got off at exit 1 following the sign but got to the jetty on the right hand side. Here they sell you tickets for 100B each telling you whatever lie. I gave back the tickets when I realized these were too expensive, and went to the jetty on the left hand side to take the public transport boat. 10 mins later the guys came after me telling me I did not return 200B change, which was clearly a lie. They got other people involved to 'mediate'. Anyway, just don't give in and experience the theatre they put up to try and rip off just 200B. They'll give up after a few minutes. The boat is great value and a must do.

A "Harried - Relaxed - WET" experience NOT TO BE MISSED !. Plying the Chao Praya river on the Express Boat is an experience not to be missed ! Depending on the day, time of day, and the weather, of course--- this experience can be quite relaxing, extremely harried, and even quite WET ! Most of the boats do have plastic splash guards in place especially for the seats in the front, to protect against getting splashed, especially during windy or stormy times! There are also usually plastic 'curtains' to unroll for really rainy+windy times! The ticket ladies stroll through the boat collecting fares, seeming to remember who's boarded since her last time 'round-- and is quickly abke to give change. They will also tell you how many stops to where you want to go, and frequently will alert you when approaching your stop !  The river boat express definitely provides that extra link in the transportation scheme of Bangkok, as well as giving one fresh air, a chance to see the sights along the river, many foto opportunities, and occasionally the sight of a large lizard-tyoe creature, living among the growing river-plants, near the docks (they are far enough away to do no harm!) For those folks with plenty of time, there are also the TOUR BOATS of the Chao Praya, with a guide spouting information as the boat cruises along.. Also plying the river are the Sunset-Dinner-Cruise Boats, fully decked-out in lights ! Remember to check out the Canal Boats, for a whole other experience!!

Dinner cruise. Very interesting and an enjoyable ride with good food. In m opinion, the buffet is unreachable to some as thee is no sufficient space arroung it. The spread is good but is a colosal task to reach the food. We thoroughly enjoyed the ride and the sweet music. The presenters were really good and we danced all the way back to base. Thee was a group of Kuwaitis who enjoyed with us.

Interesting trip. It is interesting when you stay at the boat and throw the bread pieces for the fishes, many big fishes. It was great experience. You can see many pagodas and temples stay along the river with the unique architecture.

Great way to see the river. The Chao Phraya Expess Boats are cheap, fast and never get stuck in traffic.On top of that, they are a wonderful way of seeing life on the river.At low fares, an absolute must!Check out, there are different lines having different colours, depending on the stops they make,No boattraffic after sunset, so plan your trip carefully in the afternoon!The same line also operates tourist boats which offer explanations and are more expensive. Neither boats can be accessed on wheelchairs, they make very short stops only.

Scenic Ride!. We took the Express Boat from the Sathorn Pier having got here via BTS to Saphan Taksin station on our visit to the Grand Palace and we were glad we did this. We did not have to wait long to get on the next boat. This is a much more relaxing, scenic and enjoyable ride than other means of transport. We sat at the back as I wanted to take photos. The boat does roll a bit and there is an occasional smell of diesel fumes but the ride is worth it!
nice city view. Beautiful city tour with chao phraya express boat we enjoyed alot nice food servie on boat beautiful night view.

Its a decent service but the tourist Blue boat is useless. Pl. avoid the BLUE tourist boat at all cost. Its not worth. You can buy the 1 way ticket, still good. DO NOT buy the whole day pass for 150THB. Its worthless. the boat only cover half the distance of the river anyways. There are only 2 major stops that you can do. The best way is to take a 1 WAY TICKET TO Maharaj per where the grand palace and wat pho is. Do those on foot. If its hot you get screwed.From there hire a tuk tuk and they they in 2 hrs show you around all the other points. Much much better. even in hot weather you will have better exp.EVEN better is to book the orange boat ticket thats just 15 BHT. It gets you to all the points you want. and you can also book an eve. ticket after 6.30. Get to see the light on chao priya river. And you wont need to spend a lot of money on doing expensive cruises. Most of the picture that that they show of night are only in particular period. When we visited no special lighting.

One of the BEST and cheapest things to do in Bangkok! :). First: Avoid the TOURIST BOAT (BLUE FLAG)! It does not stop at every stop, its expensive (compared with the regular line- ORANGE FLAG :) ) and the lady talking sounds like the same lady who does the British rail announcements! Almost incomprehensible and gradually becomes annoying. Anyway the regular ORANGE flag boat is great and worth paying a dozen times for the amazing view you get BUT I would say out of respect for the locals who use this to get to work, try to avoid rush hours, early morning till 9am and evening 5pm on. Otherwise I would say this is a MUST DO thing in Bangkok :) If possible get off and book dinner opposite Wat Arun (Arun Temple) and watch the sunset and beautiful temple views, truly majestic and unforgettable :) Note: The very last stop doesn't have much, except for a local temple and a few shops, 7-11, so no need to spend time looking for a hidden treasure, there are non there :)
Speedy boat and very cheap one set price of bht13.. Always use this boat as it is hetic, fast noisy and exciting whilst you speed up the river to the named/numbered piers, dont be afraid to try it .

long trips with beautyful line. After your shared pickup from your Bangkok hotel, head to the docks where your boat awaits to whisk you down the Chao Phraya River. Whether you choose to enjoy this trip solo, with a loved one, friends, or your family, it is a perfect fit.
city view through boat. you can watch the city and the many tourist spots by travelling on the express boat. Pier is connected to the metro stations
Fast and inexpensive. Though not very safe, it's a fast and inexpensive way to travel in Bangkok. Almost all the tourist attractions are served.

Great way to see the old city and Temples. The boat service is fast and efficient. Good for tourists and cheap. This is a good way to see the old temples. It is also a good way to get from the BTS station at Sapan Taksin to many of the Temples and other sights in Thonburi and the old city.
A nice way to see the river. This is a lovely way to see the river, but its much cheaper if you have the time to take the local ferries and go at a slower pace...depends on how much time you have!
Great way to see the river.. Really cheap to buy an all day hop on hop off pass at 150 thb. You can spend all day cruising the river and the various stops.

Simple, cheat and effective transport in BKK!. The river boats are a great way to explore BKK. They run up and down the river all day, with a range of stops along the way. It costs next to nothing, but may not be for the faint hearted or those afraid of somewhat primitive maritime equitment.

Great, cheap way to get around. This is an easy mode of transport around Bangkok. You can get a daily ticket for 150 Baht and this allows to to travel along the river for the whole day. It stops near several torurist attractions so you can get to see lots in one day if you start in the morning. It wasnt too busy when I was on there but there were some people standing. I felt confortable using this mode of transport and would definitely use it again.

Speedy transport if you are not afraid of crowds . The Chao Phraya express boat is good to avoid any traffic jam on the road (and during rush hour, traffic is chaotic). However, bear in mind that you are not the only smart person in the world having this idea! And although Thai people are genuinely friendly, it's challenging to be stuffed with a bunch of humans on a boat that's speeding down the river against the current = waves and splashes included. But its a fun and not too expensive way to discover Bangkok from a different angle and due to the wind, for once you will not feel sweaty.
nice views. I guess is better to see the all the spots from the boat before steeping down and trying to go to them by foot

Great for sightseeing or to transfer to your next location. Super cheap and super handy, this is a brilliant experience for your Bangkok trip. We like to stop off at the hotel and have tea, shop a bit, get back on and go to the temples, and then finish off at the market and Chinatown.

Alternative Way to view Bangkok Attraction. If you are tired of bargaining with the Tuk-Tuk and taxi driver who refused to use meter. You can go to the Saphan Taksin BTS station and get a unlimited one day pass ride on the Chao Phraya Express Boat costing THB150. You will have unlimited ride on the tourist boat on the same day and also hope I to express boat belong to the same company to see the different attractions of Bangkok.

A must-do in Bangkok!. During rush hour, this boat is by far the best way to get to a lot of major tourist sites like the Royal Palace and Chinatown. The wait can sometimes be long but it is much better than sitting in a bus or taxi for hours. A quintessential Bangkok experience.

Great to see Bangkok from riverside view. When you're in Bangkok it's a must to take a tour on Chao Phraya River, and it's a good way to get around and to see Bangkok with riverside view. Go for the express one day and a longtail boat the other day.

Prefer this if want to use public transportation. Many tourist places can be visited by this boat as places are around the piers. There are many boats running for different piers and places. It's cheap and fun way to reach places. We used orange boat for Wat Pho, Grand Palace, Wat Arun and Wat Traimit, Khao San Road. Ticket: Price 15 TBH one way. Buy on the boat.

Express boat - Chao Phraya River. If you want to take a river tour in Bangkok, you can take an express boat (normal public transportation) or an expressboat for tourists. The normal expressboat costs only 16 Baht (USD 0.50) and for the tourists costs about USD1. You can take the boat from Sathorn pier and stay on the boat till Phra Arthit pier or freely get on and off. The Sathorn pier is adjacent to Saphan Taksin BTS station. This tourist boat takes you to 8 different piers: Sathorn, Oriental, Si Phraya, Rachawong, Tha Tien, Maharaj, Wanglang and Phra Athit. At each pier, you will find famous attractions of history and culture.

Exhilarating!. When one stays on a river, one should travel by river, and boy, did we ever! The Chao Phraya River was our main route to the big sights, such as the Royal Palace, Chinatown, Wat Pho. One boards at various locations and gets packed into a ferry boat, stuffed with people from all over the world. There are several docks, and, armed with a map, you soon learn where you need to disembark. At one point, the boat was loaded to slightly over capacity, and they had to ask some people to get off. Bullhorns were brought out, and, to some passengers' dismay, used loudly for crowd control. All part of the experience, as far as we were concerned!Please travel by express at least once while in Bangkok, and also take a trip on a longtailed boat. It is worth it!

Easy Way To Get Around The River. The Express Boats plies up and down along the Chao Phraya River at various designated piers. It's very easy to get to the various tourist spots in the old city since neither the BTS nor the MRT serve this area. To get into the system, take a ride to the BTS Saphan Taksin station which connects to the river express boat's Sathorn (Central) Pier. You can save some money by avoiding the blue tourist boat; instead take any of the orange, yellow, green/yellow or no flag boats. Do check out the piers map before going up any of them though. Tickets bought on board ranges from THB 10 - 32 (very far).

Can't avoid it !. The express boat is a cheap way to get to the Wats across the Chaopraya river. However, the boats we used were very poorly maintained. In the evening, it was so crowded we barely had a spot to stand. The boat station is not clearly marked in English, so it is hard to find if you are not familiar with the area. However, it is reasonably fast and somewhat frequent - it is the only way you can cross the river without burning a hole in your pocket via the taxi.

Great way to travel. A must-try when you are in Bangkok. If you have time, you should definitely travel through the Chao Phraya Express boat. It will not cost you much and it can bring you to several temples along the Chao Phraya River.

Chao Praya River. We took the express boat in order to visit The Grand Palace and the nearby Wat(s). It's a good experience to see the busy river with guided explanation of each stations in both Thai and English language.

Cheap, fast, easy route to the temples. For only 16 baht, you can take a ride anywhere on the line. Don't waste your money on the comparatively expensive tourist boat. This boat stops at Wat Pho and The Grand Palace. If you want to go to Wat Arun, you have to get off at the stop for Wat Pho (Tha Tien) and take a separate ferry with a separate fee to cross the river.
Its a boat ride!. Its a boat ride, so there isn't much to say... they ticket are sold after you get on board, so its better to have cash!
Water Taxi. This is what I call the Water Taxi. It's cheap - like 12THB. You can jump on/off any dock, or stay on and tour the river all the way up, and then come back again. Great fun!

Easy and Cheap to Ride. This is a great way to get into Old Bangkok to see Wat Pho, Grand Palace and Wat Arun. The cost is only 14 baht and the boat to go across to Wat Arun is 6 baht. People watching is great but you must be quick to enter and exit from the rear of the boat. The boats stop running at 7:00 p.m. so be mindful of the time.

easy and cheap. I took TripAdvisor's advice and skipped the Tourist Boat. THB14 to go up and down from Central to Grand Palace. Frequent and crowded but not uncomfortable. I made a mistake and got the wrong boat initially which just crosses the river, but it was a pleasant diversion and cost me all of THB6. Be aware that there is one pier for express (up and down the river) and one for across the river. The cross river ones you seemed to buy a ticket at the pier and the express, you paid the woman jangling her money tray.
Cruise Dinner experience was good. Indian veg food served on board was ok ok, see a need for improvement. However cruise experience was good, you get very nice view of bangkok city.

A great way to see BK. what an I say if you want an authentic Thai experience, you get to see some great views that most traveller would never see. if you like people watching then this is for you as well. there are several boat lines so if in dout ask. please give your seats up or at least offer them to Monks.

Fast Noisy and entertaining. A great way to see the River and to people watch. It passes many interesting buildings. It can be noisy with all the different whistles but is definitely a Thai experience .

Mostly efficient but can be confusing . We took the orange boat from central pier to Wat Pho. I will admit when we asked the information booth the best way to get there they suggested the blue tourist boat but the orange boat is cheaper and takes less stops to get there. We went around 9:30am and waited ten minutes for the boat to arrive. After being picked up we soon realized why they call it and express boat. At every stop people who are getting off walk towards the back before docking so they could scurry off while passengers waiting to board quickly jump on and off the boat goes towards the next stop. Unless you're on the side of the boat that docks or you're familiar with the route you won't know which pier they're stopping at because there's no signs or announcement of what pier they're stopped at. Even at some of the piers we weren't able to see a sign clearly displaying the name of the stop. When we got to Wat Pho we nearly missed getting off but I was able to hear the attendant standing on the dock announce our location and luckily we were already at the back so we were able to quickly jump off. Going back towards central pier was equally confusing. We went back to the dock but there weren't any signs telling us where to que so we walked down where we saw people waiting. After standing for a few minutes a man working there yelled for everyone to go back up to the pier and wait. It took another twenty minutes for a return boat to arrive and as we waited we saw a few more people who were as confused as we were waking down to the floating dock only to screamed at to go back up and wait. Once back on the boat it was the same story of us frantically looking at every stop to see where we are to get off. But there was a local we must've saw the lost looks on our faces because he asked us where we were getting off and let us know when we were arriving to our destination.

Know your color boat.... There is the BLUE, ORANGE, RED AND GREEN. Don't be shy to ask, more than once, if you are in the correct line. If you do get on the wrong boat by mistake, don't panic. You can always switch lines for only a few baht.

Best way to get around old town. While most of Bangkok is connected via the MTS and BTS, the old Bangkok which features the famous wats, some of the underground bars, and the popular backpackers area are cut away from these transport lines. Chao Phraya Express boat comes as a life saver in such a case ferrying you down various Old Bangkok ports and connecting you downtown to Saphan Taksin BTS station as well. It can be quite crowded but comfortable none the less. Great value and quick way to move around Old Bangkok.

Easy zip around choice. B40 for a single trip or B150 for a one day unlimited pass with an actually useful guide pamphlet, gets you from A to B easily. If you are in the business districts, get to the riverside ( Sathom Taksin Skytrain)? And grab one of the thirty minute interval boats. Stops for the Palace district, Chinatown and KSR all easily accessible and , of course, great river views

best and cheapest way to enjoy the view of Chao Phraya river.. If you have time I recommend you to take Express Boat from one end to another end. like taking a taxi to nonthaburi area from a one day trip and Koh kret ( a small island at the river bank ) and take the boat ride from there to sathorn pier and catch BTS to your destination in town.

Packed but fast. I bought a day pass that gives you unlimited ride of the express boat, meaning feel free to hop in and hop off along the piers to explore. Advise to avoid during the peak hours as the boat can be very jam packed and stuffy.

Cheap way around town. Took the express boat from pier 13, near Khao San Road to pier 8 for Wat Arun & Wat Po for only 14 Baht each. Nice experience and would use it again. Missed our stop so had to get off and double back, mostly our fault but could have been made more clear by staff.

Good way to avoid Bangkok's traffic. Chao Phraya Express Boat is not only for tourist or visitor. It is one kind of public transportation in Bangkok. In rush hour where road are fully occupied by cars. It will take you more than an hour by car from Sathon to Wat Pra Kaew. If you take boat, 30 minutes and you can enjoy the view along the riverside. There are many types of boat separated by the flag behind the boat. The local one which stops at all pier is the one with no flag. Green, yellow, and orange are an express boat which will stop at a major pier. You can check the board on the pier. Lastly, there is a big boat (blue flag), this is a tour boat. There will be a guide explaining along the way. Price differs according to boat type and distance.

Quick and very cheap way to many sights in Bangkok. For a quick and very cheap way to travel up and down sights located near to the river, this is the way to do it. Get the map, find a stop and buy either a single or one day ticket. The boats tend to be busy, have hard plastic seats if you get one, but are quick and stop close to key destinations for tourists.If you are less able, there is usually a crew member on hand to help you on and off the boat.
Great way to sightsee.. One of the biggest attractions of Bangkok when you are here. Great way to get a number of the most popular attractions and soak in some of the areas of Bangkok.

This is a great way to see Bangkok from the river. A new perspective of the city of Bangkok can be fascinating. You can reach the Chinatown, most Buddhist monuments, and some of the river markets. take is early in the morning or late in the evening.

beautiful ride, gets you everywhere with a traffic jam, cheap. I love it...I take it all the time when I am in Bangkok. It's cheap. you can go to other parts of the city without being in a traffic jam and if needed take a taxi to your final destination. It works very easy...just get on and buy your ticket on the boat. Be aware of the colour of the flags. It means which stops it will make. Not every boat stops everywhere....ask which flag you have to look for

Highly efficient way to get around Bangkok.. We got the day pass meaning you could get off and on for I think it worked out £4 per person. Stops at all the main piers while you also get to enjoy the views.

Interesting ride!!. Truly an experience to ride the Chao Phraya boat express!. Such a convenient way of transport and also well managed. Locals as well as the tourists travel by this to reach to various tourist destinations and is the fastest way to travel to those destinations!. A must do when in Bangkok!!

Easy and Fun Transportation - Travel like a local. Good way to get to some of the major attractions like Wat Po and the Grand Palace. I wouldn't recommend the day pass for the tourist boat unless you are planning to spend the day on the river visiting a lot. Take the regular boat with the locals and do a half day. It can be very hot at the attractions especially the Grand Palace so a half day of visiting might be enough and you would want to head somewhere air con unless your time is limited.
Cheap way to get around the OLD City. Cheap and fast way, not to worry about traffic jam. Can be crowded and be safe as the boat can travel at high speed. Convenient to "hop" around many temples.

Tourist Boat- Shame about the screeching commentary. It's a good way to get around the river precinct, and reasonably priced (though the regular boats are cheaper). The seats are not really designed for Western visitors though, I think my primary school chairs were of a similar size. As for the commentary, having the combination of recorded and live commentary in English and Thai sounds like a good idea in theory- in practice it's a constant assault on the ears, with the same messages being repeated 4-5 times each time. There is literally no respite to sit and enjoy the view.

Best value way of experiencing Bangkok .. Great value. No the standard 1,500 Baht hire long tail boat reserved for tourists. 15Baht single ticket to a number of diffrent piers. Suggest starting at the Shangri-La taxi point. Jump on there (get the right direction) and head up past various Bangkok landmarks including a host of temples. You will also share the experience with Thai residents and get the smells and noise which are memorable too!
Nice boat. You should visit the boat pier in Nonthaburi, where the thousands of sacred catfish roam free in the river. I suggest to sail during the sunset. It is really awesome.

Best Value for Money Tour.. For 15 baht, or whatever it is now, you can take an amazing tour of the Chao Phraya. Best if experienced from Sapan Taksin all the way to stop #13, which is Khaosan. Just sit back and enjoy Bangkok by river.
Best boat ride experience. The day was great and watched some beautiful scenery while travelling around by boat, a must thing to do by tourists.

Efficient transportation in Bangkok. Super easy and efficient way to transport yourself, if your hotel and selected attractions are along the river.
Travelled from Thaksin Bridge (BTS) to Grand Palace and back. Very cheap and fast. You are in good hands from the moment you purchase your ticket and until you leave the boat.
Some great city views!. You get some great views of bankgok on the boats and with stops all around bangkok its easy to travel up and down the river. Its also cheap and the service is regular.

Use the Orange Flag Boat. Our hotel is on the river, so we used the express boat to get to the Grand Palace. Here is what you need to know. The blue flag is the tourist one and runs the same route, but is more expensive according to locals. The orange one is the one to use. I noticed that their is a system where some stations are skipped at some times, so make sure you catch it and get off at the major stops or ask. It was convenient and inexpensive.

A great way to get to the top attractions in Bangkok.. Easily accessed from the BTS Skytrain (Sephan Takshin Station for the Central Pier), the Chao Praya Express boat is yet another fast transport in Bangkok. Buy a day-pass, and enjoy the HO-HO (hop-on, hop-off) - you can see a lot of places around Bangkok including some markets.

The most convenient way to get to your destination is it's close to the river. You have 2 kinds of boats, the ones for tourists and the ones pour the people who live there. After 2 days you know the stops and where you're going, so take the second kind that cost 28 bahts instead of 40. For a family of 3, doing it for a few days, it adds up.

Best way to get around. It is the best and essential way to get around for a foreigner but it comes with a relative cost. By our standards, it’s cheap but for your local money it isn’t cheap. However, if it is your first time, it’s a must to get a grasp on your bearings and figure out what you want to do. Then you can always use the local boats for 1/10 the price. My friend told me not to worry because the guides spoke English but as you can see with the videos I uploaded, they are quite extremely difficult to understand but it is still fun and a great experience nonetheless.
selling woman. It is very interesting to see the city from a boat. For me the most interesting woman who was in a small boat approached and selling their wares.

Nothing compares. This is the most wonderful way to travel in the world (have to test the Orient Express still).If you have a day off on your hands, please do yourself a favour and just hop on a boat, buy your ticket on board as you go, do not use the touristthing though, hop of at any stop, wander around, eat something you don't eat at home, hop on, repeat as many times as you can. Highlight are Wat Arun and Koh Kret for example, but every stop leads you somewhere great. And you WILL find your way back, just ask someone young on the boat, most students speak good English and are happy to help. Take a map. Cost: around 60baht for three stops I think.
Rude Rude Rude. Staff on boat just shout and are rude!!!Dirty river but able to get around quicker.Long queues but manage to get everyone on!!!
For 14 THB you can go all the way to the train station stop. Very friendly personnel. Very cheap unless you accidentally take the fancy boat (40 THB per person instead of 14 THB)

Excellent way to see life along the Chao Phraya river. We took the boat (orange flag) from one end to the other. The cost is minimal and you have a wonderful view of both sides of the river. Truly recommended.
Traveling the River by boat. Took the water taxi stopping at the many piers along the river way dropping off and picking up passengers. It's always enjoyable relaxing on the water.

cheap and cheerful. good way to travel through Bangkok and across the river. The ferry can link you to the BKS and then to land based attractions and also MTS so if you are staying near the river its a good way to travel.The ferry is quite cheap and all day tickets can be purchased but does not operate at night.

Fun!. a great way to get a quick tour of the river's edge in Bangkok! You see the city outline, can get out and tour some temples. Also you get to see life along the river - houses and floating marketers.

Tour Alternative. Most of the hotels or travel agencies will offer you a tour along the Chao Phraya River with high fees.This is a good alternative to that it opens at 8am and closes at 4pm or 5pm. One day unlimited pass is 150 THB and you can aboard and alight on all the terminals. it is a good way to see the other side of Bangkok and they also have an English Tour guide. The staffs are very helpful. One way pass costs 40 THB
Must see......... ....not because of the temples, because of the traffic on chao phraya.....express boats, the tugboats, the dinner criusing ships...

great way to get from BTS to Grand Palace. It might seem confusing at first but just research which boats stop at the pier you want to go to. We just hopped on the orange boat and paid once we got under way. Cheap and easy way to get around in the city. What fun!

Very rude staff!. I paid the staff member cash for my ticket and there was a lot of rush. I received a slip of paper and no ticket. When on the boat, lady comes to ask for my ticket and I said I never got one and she started to yell at me (she spoke no English). Earlier guy from the port comes up to ask what is going on (he spoke some English). I told him he never gave me a ticket when I paid him the cash and he completely refused to acknowledge that I had paid him! He told me I had to get off at the next stop and take a taxi or whatever else I pleased. They made me feel like a scheming cheat. Finally, I told him I did have the receipt (keep in mind it was hard to think while you had two Thai people screaming at you and demanding that you get off and other passengers staring at you) and the guy said, "yes, this is what we need". I understand that there will be people that try to cheat their way on to the boat, but it would be a lot better if they try to assess the situation before jumping to conclusions and creating a scene.
Easy travel. Best and cheapest way to travel in Bangkok, don't miss it, just jump on, pay a few baht and take in the city, fabulous

Beautiful night cruising along the river.. Beautiful night cruising along the river. Bring your camera and shades.
It was quite amazing on the boat; however with the warm weather in Bangkok, you may need to wear casual and comfortable shoes. It's worth time to spend.

Wang Lang Market - Ratchawong - Saphan Taksin - Asiatique. I use the orange flat boat to access to the Wang Lang Market, very very nice experience, definitely a MUST try in Bangkok and the BEST point is the fare is CHEAP. I think we pay 14Baht/pax.Reminder, if u stop at Ratchawong pier, please spend a few minutes to look around the water, I saw many many cat fish splashing water that day, u can buy food to feed them at 10baht. Nice experience. I use Ratchawong pier to access to China Town and Sampeng Lane.

Fun, Fun, Fun!. After fighting the traffic of Bangkok while breathing exhaust fumes, this was a pleasant way to travel. It is one of the most inexpensive ways to travel around Bangkok. We rode from Sathorn pier to Koh Kret Island while enjoying the breeze and admiring all of the temples on the banks of the Chao Phraya River. This is an excellent way to see the river and save money. A typical dinner cruise may cost about $70/ person and this cost less than $5.00.

A crowed but fun method of transport!. This is more convenient than a taxi if you want to avoid traffic. Goes into areas where the sky train and underground do not exist. It's cheap....never more than $1.00. if you have time, take it to the end of the line to the town of Nonthaburi and watch the landscape change from the cityscape of BKK to a more placid vision of banana trees and greenery until you reach Nonthaburi which is worth looking at. Actually, every stop has something worth seeing. Be careful when getting on the boat. Also, it can be very crowded, and women should be careful to avoid touching monks or their clothing. A real Bkk experience that should not be missed.

The best and quickest way to get up/down river.. The Chao Phraya Express boats are the fastest and least expensive ways of getting to certain areas that are otherwise only accessible by taxi or tuk-tuk. I don't have any complaints about the routes, the comfort or the boat travel. However, information about the stops or about which boat to get on can be difficult to find, and it can be confusing. Moreover, asking the dock workers for information can lead to some very rude behavior...they are not always very nice! I have had a dock worker actually yell at me to get on (or off) a boat, and give me the kind of glare that would (in a bar) provoke a fight. Roll with it, be patient, and ask someone that looks like they live there and speaks English.

Great ways to travel along the Chao Phraya. Using the express boat is the greatest way to travel to tourist destinations that located alongside the Chao Phraya river (like Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Asiatique).The boat comes every 5-10 minutes, and cost 14b per trip per person. Take the orange boat:- 'Tha Chang' pier located right behind the Grand Palace- 'Tha Tien' pier located right behind Wat Pho Temple- 'Wat Rajsingkorn' located right next to Asiatique. But per my visit, the boat did drop directly at the Asiatique's pier, which is great!!But I forgot to check if the Wat Rajsingkorn pier is the same pier as Asiatique's.

Great sightseeing. A special way to travel and see Bangkok without having to deal with the sometimes hectic city traffic. A nice breeze of wind whilst sitting on the boat and seeing all the wonders the city has to offer from the river. A unique and very delightful experience. Try to wear clothes that can become wet because we had some water splattering on us.

excellent way to get around. perfect for making your way up the river to view the tourist sites, i spotted some reviews here complaining about overcharging, the price is 150 baht for an all day ticket! If you pay more than that then you probably are not on the genuine chao phraya express.
Don't miss when you arrive to travel in Thailand. very nice trip and enjoyed with Chao phraya Express boat, good air and staffs very nice you can look around the river with nice view
Nice experience. Travelling by boat on the river is very common for people live in Bangkok, I am not sure if we need to pay but I think it would be very cheap as this is like the MRT on the City.

Good way to see Bangkok. This is a unique way to see Bangkok the way it was meant to be seen from the old days. Just make sure you are ready to get off by waiting at the back of the boat before your stop.

Cheap and efficient, a nice experience. We took the express boat from Tha Tien to Saphan Taksin, from where we took the BTS to Nana. Very cheap, efficient, and very nice to tour in the night when all the area around is lit up.

Cheap and good. Beware at Si Phaya pier the lady that sells tickets on the platform charges 3 times (44 baht) than the actual price (14 baht to anywhere). We never got cheated anywhere else. The best bet is to buy ON the boat where possible.

Affordable way to tour the river. Great way to see the tourist sites like Wat Pho (reclining Buddha) and the Grand Palace if your hotel is close to the river. Quite a bit cheaper than taking a taxi and is great if you don't mind waiting around 15 minutes for the boat to arrive or lots of people. Is a must-experience if it's your first time in Bangkok

Convenient and easy. Worth a try. But polluted.. The Chao Phraya Express boat is a very convenient, easy and cheap way to travel down the river to various locations in Bangkok. I rode it from Phra Arthit (near Khao San Road) several stops away to Rachawong (Chinatown).It's quite an experience, really. The boats are very long and the way they coordinate landing at docks is pretty impressive. You also get a unique view of various temples and buildings along the river. However, I made the mistake of standing at the back of the boat (it was pretty full) and was surprised at the amount of black smoke these boats produce, especially during the docking procedure. They only stay at a dock for a few minutes max and they need to keep the engined revving to keep the boat parallel to the dock as passengers load/unload. Do yourself a favor and sit inside towards the front of the boat unless you want to inhale huge amounts of black pollution!Overall, a great way to get up and down the river. Especially for the price!

Nice easy trip on River. Bought a day pass at the pier 5. You can hop on and off until 7pm at any pier you want. Rode it all the way to the end and saw the millions of catfish which you can feed off the wharf. A nice little street to stroll along selling many food delights. Good way to explore the river at your own pace. Got off at Chinatown and had a stroll through in the night

Relaxing way to travel. I stayed at Nonthaburi. I tried going to to the city by Chao Praya Express at 10am, and was not disappointed. It was so relaxing way to travel. Not sure where I started, but it was a big boat station, near a traditional market. So I bought some street food, bought the boat ticket (very very cheap compared to the taxi fare, no traffic too!), go aboard, and had nice breakfast while waiting for the boat to start. Really enjoyed the river trip. I went down at Santhorn, go into the city by BTS. A very nice way to travel! Not so nice while it rain, though.

Useful way to travel around.. We used the tourist boat the first day, the map was useful to decide where to hop on and off to visit attractions. Thereafter we used the 15 baht express boat, crowded but cheap and efficient.
Great way to see Bangkok. Aside from the fact that it's one of the best and easiest ways to access a lot of tourist spots (ie: Wat Pho, Wat Arun), the Chao Phraya was a really fun experience.

Cheap and effective. This is a great way to move up the river. From Sakhon Pier, we boarded the boat and paid only about 14 baht each to get all the way up to stop N8 (Wat Pho). The boat ride was pretty quick, but we actually stood waiting for about 30 minutes before we got on. This is supposed to be a fairly regular boat, though, so maybe we just got a bad day.

Nice way to travel. This is great way to see another side of Bangkok. The view is great, but the boat can sometimes get very crowded.You may have to sometimes push to get on and off. Make sure to bring a map so you know where to get off and prepare to stand by the exit so you don' t miss your stop.A great and cheap way to get around.

Quick and cool!. Fabulous way to travel in Bangkok. Boats are plentiful, although sometimes crowded. 15 baht gets you 5 or 6 stops along the river and it is a great way to visit the Grand Palace and other riverside attractions without having to battle the Bangkok traffic.
average. it is one of the activities which is only for tourists . i would say it is not really the main attraction out here

Cheap and time-saving. Okay, this can be difficult to figure out initially, so I have laid out the steps as clearly as possible:Things to expect:Nothing will be marked at the pier, probably. No timetables, no indication that the boat is coming. There were times listed for hours of operation, but they were wrong. Sometimes one side of the pier is for private long-tail boats, while the other is the regular ferry. Make sure you are on the right side.1) Just know the direction you are going and get on the appropriate boat. The boat doesn't really matter, provided that it stops at your location (there is a map on the wall showing which boats stop where). If you are going to the main tourist area, all boats will stop there.2) You are expected to hop on quickly and the boat guys will bark at you if you are dawdling or trying to wait for a friend. Don't be that person, just get on the boat. This is public transportation for Thais trying to get to work, not your personal shuttle.3) You pay onboard. There will be a lady shaking a can at you and you pay anywhere from 4-10 Baht. Have some change or small bills.4) The piers have clearly displayed signs. Be ready to disembark as the boat pulls up, as in be near the stairs or railing.It's a little hectic, but better than two train transfers or sitting in traffic in a taxi. Once you figure it out, it's a breeze, but we saw many tourists trying to ask the boat guys questions or dawdling or wandering the piers looking confused. Just get on, pay, and get off.
Thumb Up. Great service provided with friendly/helpful staffs will make your trip in Bangkok along the Chao Phraya River get disappointed.

Convenient!. We had a guide take us as we were going to a dinner cruise. It was fast and you had to be ready to get off as they don't stop for long. The express also doesn't run late and we were lucky to catch the last boat.
Difficult to identify the place. The express boat did not harbor one of the pier "Marine Department" which is stated in the official map.

Not WAT I expected.... See what I did there? This is what you use to get to the big tourist sites. You get off the BTS, walk down the steps and buy a 4? Baht ticket to go up the river. Coming back, I think you're supposed to pay the lady who shakes the can at people, but I never did. There are lots of various types of boats to use to get up and down the river. These are barge looking boats and you buy your tickets at a blue booth. Quick and easy... the problems come when you get back on land and have to deal with the constant "help" from locals who want you to "help their country" and save you time because something "is closed now due to Buddhist holiday." Going back, the boat only stops at major stops (i.e. not every one on the way up) but you'll know where to get off. Enjoy!

Great way to get around. If one is in Banglampu area which has Kho san road this and the canal are the best ways to get around. One can take the trip to teh end of the stations in both directions for 20B and have a great view of the city.

I liked better than the cruise :). I used to take this boat from the stop next to Khao San road until the last stop (Asiatique River Front) - the ride was amazing and also very cheap. Hardly takes 25 mins for the ride, which takes almost an hour on busy road. Enjoy the ride :).

A quick way to get about.. Relatively cheap and quick to get around the tourists areas.
You many get a little wet or even sea sick as its far from a smooth journey.

Good way to get around. we used the boats to get up and down the river from our hotel to the palace and major temple sites. it was cheap and easy to use and got us to where we needed to go quickly. Not every boat makes every stop so you have to pay attention. Language issues made asking questions of the ticket sellers challenging, but overall we would recommend this as a good way to get around.
Great way to visit places in Thailand!. Good to have this kind of service available with a very minimal fee. Hassle free to travel to most interesting place in thailand. <3

the fastest and cheapest way ....link it with the BTS and Tuk Tuk !. For an avg 20 bhat PP you can fly up the mighty Chao Phraya to anyone of a dozen stops and get around the city in a far more interesting and fun way that in a tiny taxi stuck in traffic. Each boat has a colored flag on its back. No flag is very local and much like a land taxi, no organized stops just jump in a go and yell when to stop, Blue flag is a "tourist boat" that costs more and makes many stops, Orange flag is the most popular express boat that stops at the major piers, pay the ticket master once you board.

Easy, quick, and cheap way to enjoy the city. I think it cost 15 baht to get on the ferry, they traverse the river stopping at many ports near many interesting places. Its fun to get a different view of the city from the river. Easy to use and the price is right!

Convenient and good service. We specially took tourist boat. Price 150Bhats for any no of travel.Passes through many important tourist attraction with 30 minutes time bound service.Cruising itself is fun on the river.Courteous staff at all piers.Must enjoy.

Easy travel on the river. Pleasant and relaxing way to get around some of the sights, able to get a day ticket so you can get on and off at whatever area you want to explore. There are different "tours" so its worth researching which colour boat flag to decide upon.

Heart og Bangkok. A trip to Bangkok without using Chao Praya boat services is unfinished. This is an excellent way to commute, travel and see things differently. Boats are used by locals as much as tourists and allow you to move around very easily.

Fast and Cheap. In my view the best way to go around in Bangkok if you are going to places within walking distance of the river. The boats are rather basic, but the journeys are much more pleasant than a road journey using taxis or tuck-tucks. The prices are very reasonable.

A Journey by Boat!. Very nice and cheap way to get to and from different sights in Bangkok. I took the boat from Central Pier (you can get there by skytrain). The boat takes you to all the major sights like the Grand Palace, Wat Arun & Wat Pho.

Can use this form of transportation. to and from the Golden Temple to Wat Arum..but the little boat does not take off until it is full to the brim with people..Heard it is not that expensive..but at least you won't have to pay a tuk tuk or a taxi who charge more..I asked for a meter from the taxi that brought me to the hotel, but he acted like he did not understand me..

unorganized and dirty but efficent way to get across the river. The lines could be long, you are also standing through some smelly market while waiting to get through the line. People are trying to sell anything possible, it has a terrible smell. But its pretty efficient and a cheap way to cross the river,

Best way to see the city from the river. Travel as the locals do - make sure you get the orange flagged boats which are the regular commuter boats. You will generally get a seat, and you get to see all the river based sights - we went as far as the Royal Palace. Avoid the blue flagged tourist boats which are more expensive, slower, and have a very annoying and loud tourist commentary the whole time.
Interesting ride. Unlimited ride whole day down the chao praya river. When we're tired from walking, we simply had a "joy ride" on the boat. It is an interesting ride itself.
Funtastic !. I been try this think during exploring this city, passed by the Wat Arun temple, specially at nigh that so colorful !

Best travel experience. I combined my travel on the BTS with this ferry ride to the Grand Palace. Unfortunately the rail system does not go to their #1 tourist spot but I was glad after riding the ferry. I needed to ask for some direction after leaving the train because you actually change to a second ferry to cross the river to the Palace side but it is not difficult. Students speak English and are eager to help! The ferry ride is cheap and scenic and I highly recommend using it.

For Transport or for Sightseeing take the boat.. I lived and worked in Bangkok for a couple of years. Like most large cities transportation is an art. By combining this means with that means a person can get just about anywhere.  Generally I accessed the Express Boat by taking the BTS SkyTrain Silom Line down to the Saphan Taksin Station. It is a short walk from the BTS to the Express Boat Terminal (just head towards the water).  The Express Boat is a good way to get across, up, or down the river without crossing the bridges. This gives you access to western Metro Bangkok Areas. There are also many temples on the banks of the Chao Phraya River worth seeing and this a very efficient way to do it.  There are actually several boat companies operating on the river. You can tell the difference by the color of flag they fly. I remember one is orange and one is blue. Each company has a different ticket and price. Take a little time to ready the boards and looking around before you buy the ticket or hop on a boat. After a couple of rides it become second nature.
Easy transprt. Cheap but best.Excellent service to go through Phao Chhaya river.Many attractive place in both side of the river and the most convenient way to go there is by Express Boat.

Great experience. This is a great way to spend a couple of hours sightseeing for just a few pennies, also a great travelling experience. There are many places to get on and off, some markets and sights such as the palace and wat pho are very close to some stops. Also go to the end of the line for a more local feel to Bangkok

Thai transport experience!. This was truly a Thailand transportation experience. The ferry boats are awesome--so much better than sitting in traffic! This one has the orange flag, and fyi, each pier where it stops also has an orange flag. That's important info no one told us and it took us a while to figure it out!

Take very, very good care of your belongings!! If possible, avoid weekends!. I made the mistake of taking the local 14 THB-boat from Saphan Taksin to Wat Pho on a Saturday afternoon. It was extremely crowded, there were no more empty seats, and so I had to stand in a very tight space. I was wearing an unzipped under-the-arm bag and later after the ride, I found that my wallet was missing. I suspect that the old - harmless-looking (!!) - man that was standing very close to me on the boat actually reached for it inside of my bag without me noticing. In summary: the boat ride is a very cheap and relatively fast way to commute in the areas that are not covered by the BTS and MRT, BUT accordingly it gets very busy on the weekends and utmost caution with your belongings (avoid carrying around valuables and large sums of cash) is more than advisable, especially since there are no cameras on the boat to identify thieves..
Another great transport option. Consider it an excellent other option for getting around Bangkok. Along with the BTS and subway, this provides a good scenic view and it is also very cheap.
must do enjoy the river. If you are in Bangkok, Please take out your time to have a river view of the city in evening which lits and give a marvelous view.

Ride the Orange Flag Boat. The Chao Phraya Express Boat with the orange flag is the way to go. It is 15 Baht for one trip - you can go to the end of the line. You can buy an all day pass for 40 Baht and get on and off as you please. This is not the Tourist Boat - there is no commentary. Just take your map or guide book and you can easily locate all the attractions. It is a great way to see and experience Bangkok. For something differentiIf you get off at Thewet you can walk down the street to market stalls selling potted plants and orchids, you can get some really lovely, very brightly coloured wind chimes and garden ornaments - they made unusual gifts.
real express boat. takes very less time for transport from one city end to other. connecting with city center. very nice view and experiance in limited money.

its real Bangkok. Spent 8 weeks in Bangkok in 1991 and returned recently on a business trip so thought i would give the CPE a try again .Its great but either boat will do , the tourist boat is only 40 baht from Saphan Taksin to Phra Arthit which is 13 stops if you pay on the boat its also well used by Thais based on the fact the ticket collector shouts out in Thai all day .If you are not aware in Bangkok you will get ripped off just be careful same as you would be anywhere else .If you are going to walk around with your selfie stick taking pictures all the time then you are going to get conned - simple !!

Fun river speed boat busses. This is a really good fun way to get along the length of the river it's cheap and run after dark they are basically speed boats the size of British canal boats with a turbo booster the river is fast but the boats are faster lots of different boats so do check at your departure dock for correct boats (colour coded) with flags again like the BTS sky train it's cheap and very efficient the ticket collectors come around with metal collection tins rattling them and you can tell them where you want to go and they give you single tickets only my advise is wear deck shoes or trainers as the boarding point at the back of the boat can get wet due to spray from engines speeding the boats along this is great way to other parts of the city and travelling up to the grand palace also the temple of the dawn

Very commercial and is not worth the cost. I have tried this and the local boat.the tourist boat is more comfortable and informative.The local boat is much cheaper ,gets you where need to go without commentator. I must admit I enjoyed the local one better
Chao Phraya Express Boat. Great to get the unlimited pass where we can get off at the different stops. One can spend a whole here

The real Bangkok. Join the locals in the most efficient en cheap way to travel across this town and avoid the legendary Bangkok traffic jams. Mingle with monks, schoolchildren and have a splendid view of the city, everything for 14 Baht.
water i love iot. the speed is one of the fastest but the fastest is the maccau to hongkong it is very comfortable and fast to all easy process nice experience
be careful about offers. be very careful of the offers and try to go early to make maximum usage as they close services by 7pm
Loved it.. This is a 2 in 1 activity. Get to see the sights along the river and get to where you are going for a decent price. Quite easy to use and tourest friendly. A lot of fun.

Inexpensive Excellent Travel. It is Thailand's version of hop on hop off, albeit its on the river. Really great way to travel, comfortable cruise and inexpensive. Highly recommended as most of their tourist spots are by the river

Cheap and fast but confusing at first. Flags
Whistles
Monks
School Children
Tour groups
No seats
Jump on
Pushed off
Great fun
20 Bht? if you avoid the tourist boat

A Must for First Time Tourist in Bangkok. The boat goes up and down the Chao Phraya River. The express boat has a blue flag on the top and is the only boat that stops at the Maharaj Pier which is the stop for the Grand Palace and the Reclining Buddha.
