There are a number of Express ferry piers and also more local piers, and four different lines of boats that stop at different places, more or less "local" stops. It's not as hard as it sounds, but there isn't much information or staff support at the actual piers either. If someone is trying to go to and from a main pier the worst case is that someone could get on a commuter version that doesn't stop often, and then might need to go back a couple stops on the more local boat.The boats cost either 15 or 20 baht per trip, which you typically pay on the boat, which seem to run relatively often, maybe every 10 or 15 minutes (but then again there are different boats). With even a little research it's a great way to get around and a great new perspective on the city (provided you want to travel to and from near the river, but there are a couple stops right beside BTS / skytrain line stops, and the main temples are near stops). If using Google Maps it's really easy because you just type in "pier" and it shows where they all are, and even on the boat you'll know where you are related to where you want to go.
Don' confuse with Tourist Boat. The express boats are normal river boats where you pay by ride. You buy the ticket onboard. Those selling the tickets at pier are for the tourist boat.

Very pleasant boat ride - highly recommended. A tour of Bangkok is incomplete without this attraction. We took this boat ride on a Sunday evening from Suthorn till Nonthaburi and back. It offered an amazing view of Bangkok we have not seen otherwise. Magnificent wats, several of them dotting the shoreline along with a peek to the grand King's Palace and other fine specimens of architecture kept us engrossed throughout the journey. A mild breeze made the ride highly enjoyable. Malls and cafes along the banks teeming with the holidaying crowd made for a pretty picture. The ride to Nonthaburi and back took a little more than an hour. We learnt that it is a cheap and easy way to travel from one place to another within the city. Dusk had drawn in on our way back and the shimmering reflection of hundreds of neons on the dark river from the adjacent buildings created a magical environment. The boat on our return journey was crisscrossing the river to stop at piers on both banks which was, in itself, an interesting experience.

Very Easy to Use. The Chao Phraya Express Boat is a very easy to use service for tourists. Tickets for a full day are 150 Baht and there is a timetable issued with your ticket. We have been to Bangkok many times and have seen all the regular temples etc a few times each. This time we just caught the boat to different points and wandered around.

Express. Cheap, fast and basic, unheard of low cost, fast and efficient! Can get a bit overloaded and wouldn't pass many countries safety inspections, but this is Bangkok, so join the crowds and enjoy! Great way to experience and explore the many riverside attractions.

was great way to get around. was a good way to get around Bangkok & see a lot of things you wouldn't see in a taxi and cheap. You can get off at different points and look around and then get on the next boat that came. highly recommend doing the boat trip up and down Chao Phraya river.

Use the Express Boats!. Cheaper, faster and more available than the blue tourist boats… Orange Green and Purple boats can get you where you need to go for just a few Baht. Great means of transportation!

Temples, palaces, Khao San and canal boats: Easy, round trip. Today I decided to squeeze as much in for as little as I could. It was surprisingly easy to find my way around. And I saw it all & ate in just 3 hours!The best station to go to is the SaphanTaksin BTS - you walk down the stairs and your at the Peir. Chao phraya express boats run up and down the river frequently and you can get tickets for 40 Baht one way or 120 Baht for an all day unlimited stops ticket. The ticket ladies and boat guide speaks good clear English and will tell you the age and location of the sights you pass along the river and also which piers are good to get off at to access other sights. (China town, wats etc) Ferries across the river are 3baht per person each way - some wats are on the other side of the river to the main piers.I got off at Maharaj for the Royal Palace and more. You need to be modestly dressed to enter the sights here - no thongs, shoulders covered and long pants - they do offer you free clothing to borrow if you forget. I walked from there easily to Khao San road - only about 10 min, along Thanon Ratchadamnoen Nai and e huge field in front of the university. Cross the major intersection and then verse left - you should see plenty of tourists heading I. That direction...you'll be at the head of Khao San road in about 1 minute.I had a great thai chicken and noodle lunch for 100 Bhat - so big I couldn't finish it! And a refreshing icy strawberry daiquiri (150baht). The Beer Garden close to the other end of the road - you can't miss the vibrant coloured flags in the massive tree centre of the beer garden. From there I walked to the end, turned right and then left onto the main road. Walk for about 10 min past the Democracy Monument (straight at the big roundabout), when you cross a canal cross the road (Thanon Ratchadamnoen Klang) and you will see the canal boats at Phanfa Lilat pier (look for it under manat thai Uthit Bridge) and for 9baht & less than 10min was taken to Saphan Hua Peir within 300m of national Stadium BTS & MBK Mall. (300m in the opposite direction from the pier takes you to the other BTS line - Rachathewi Station) This is how the locals travel and for 9baht you travel 1/3 of the way across townA wonderful day to get a taste for many different sides of Bangkok. Plenty of tourist stalls along Khao San road - not the cheapest - but a bit of fun.A must do
Fun trip. Fun to use for trip to China town and back. Cheap and colourful. Wouldn't pass occupational health and safety in most places in the world.

Overloaded and dangerous. Make sure you get on the bigger tourist boats as the company also run smaller yellow locals boats up and down the river whoch you can alos get on, but they are very overloaded and dangerous. Otherwise if on the bigger boats its a good view of the city without the hustle and bustle of the skytrain!

Cheap way to travel over the river but a bit crowded. The Express Boat is perfect to get from the BTS to the Grand Palace. It is very cheap, but the boat got very crowded during rush hour in the evening.

Great way to explore the temples of Bangkok. Very easy and convenient way to get around and explore the Grand Palace, temples and the hotels such as the Mandarin Oriental. We got a tourist ticket which was 150 Baht for all day unlimited trips on 8 or so of the piers (the main ones). We actually didn't even go on a tourist boat as they are once every 30 minutes but you can use your ticket on the other express boats (orange line). Be aware though, that they don't hang about or wait for you. You have to be very quick to get on before they are off again!

Easy and fast River transport. When using the BTS city train to the Taksin bridge river station it is very easy to connect and go to interesting places along the river by Chao Phya Express Boat, look out for the blue sign and the counter with official collecting the fare. Most lines travel along one side of the river going northward to Chinatown, Grand Palace area or all the way to Pakkred or southward to Asiatique entertainment area, some lines just cross the river so you need to get a good look at the map and schedule posted. One good place to go is the Tha Maharaj Pier which has been remodeled and modernized to included cafes and restaurants like S&P, Starbucks and many other - and a great area for taking photos of the river traffic !

Exciting way to view the City. It's an experience you shouldn't pass up. Seeing the sites from the river is a lot of fun and inexpensive. One thing to note is it is Bangkok, so there is a lot of garbage floating around, but that shouldn't be a deterrent.

A great way to see the city from the river.. If you take the orange flag boat from the Sathorn/Central Pier up the river to the end of the line the cost is only 15 Baht, and you get a great view of the city for over an hour. Of course you can get off at any of the stops to see such sights as the Palace and temples etc. there are maps showing sights near to the stopping points on the internet.

I Love the River. I have spent many hours on the river taxis, and I never grow tired of them. I usually take the Sky Train south to the Taksin bridge, and catch a boat there. You have many choices, such as getting off at Wat Arun on the West bank, the Grand Palace/Wat Pho, and lots of other stops. For a nice long ride with interesting handicrafts at the end, ride the boat all the way North to Koh Kret. It's a man made island formed by a canal dug to shorten the journey around the horse shoe in the river. The island is full of crafts people that make anything you can imagine. You can spend hours and hours here and never get bored. There is also plenty of food and drink to sustain life while you are exploring. Ride the river taxi and get off the streets!

Great way to see sights and get around Bangkok. Catch the skytrain (BTS) to Saphan Taksin Station.You have 3 choices of boatsYellow - which stops at every stopOrange - Express stops at main stopsTourist - same as orange but more expensive, although you can sit down.When you get to the station they will try to get you to buy a ticket for the Tourist Boat. As said you get more of a chance to sit down, but it costs more and doesn't run as late into the evening.The orange flag boats at 40 bhat and you get a feel of local life on these mixing in and much more worth it. With the breeze from the movement you get to cool down.

Skip the Tuk Tuks and cruise instead. In my opinion this is the best way to explore the "hits" of Bangkok in one day. Skip the infamously scammy tuk tuks and take the BTS to the Saphan Taksin Station.No traffic, cool breeze, and great views make traveling by boat a must in Bangkok.For one (super cheap) ticket, you can hop on and hop off as you please all day. We made stops at Chinatown, Wat Arun, Wat Pho, and the Grand Palace.
Great. This is a great way to get around the "Venice of the east." Between ferrying across from temple of the dawn to wat pho and all around, this is cheap and fun transportation.

Avoid the crowded streets and enjoy life on the river. Travel on the river is a wonderful way to visit some of the local temples and sights. The "Tourist Express" boat is 40 bht, while the local boat is 15bht. Once you know where you want to go, the local boat is absolutely fine and there are always people to ask for directions - the local ticket sellers speak some English, other tourists and other passengers are always happy to help. It does get crowded and you don't always get a seat, plus it stops at virtually every pier. There is another post that describes the different colour flags on the boats - I don't understand fully the different colours, but the local boat with an orange flag seems to stop at every location.Catch the BTS train to Saphan Taskin then follow signs to Central Pier. There are numerous signs advertising Tourist ferry, local ferry and long boat tours so just take your time and read all of the information. If you are not in a hurry just watch a few boats come and go and you will soon see how it all works.

Great experience. This is another attraction if you are in bangkok. This boat will cruise along the chao praya river and stop at several pier to pick up people. The fees is very cheap and the experience that you will get is priceless.

Never listen to a tout use this instead.. As you wonder around the GP Po and Arun you will notice a lot of overly friendly guys driving Tuk Tuks trying to help you out. Forget it they are not helping you. Go to the look for the public boat launch hop on this wonderful service that goes up and down the river from GP to SapianThaksin.

Recommended experience for only 40bhat. There are 2 type of boats: the first one is 15 bhat. You may find it very busy and have a few chances to find a seat and enjoy the views. The second one costs 40 bhat and is fair more spacious, with plenty of seats and live guide commentary. You can upgrade the second one to 150bhat and do a hop on/ hop off ride. They even allow you to sit on the front part of the boat and we got to capture some nice sights on the camera.

Convenient Transport. Just to be clear, this is about the Boat not the river.I took a ride from Spahan Taksin to the last pier - about 40 minutes. Great way to gain an insight to the way locals travel and it's so cheap. Good sights on the way. It's a convenient way to get to certain parts like Khao San or Chinatown.Each pier has its name and number printed clearly, and this is how you identify where you are. [You did pick up the very useful tourist map at the airport tourist counter, right? The piers' names and numbers are indicated on the map.] There is no announcement as the boat arrives at each pier. If you are lost, by all means, ask the locals.Tickets are bought from the counter at the pier or the ticket seller during the boat trip itself.The river water do very occasionally splash into the boat. So be careful if your boat is the type that have your bodies exposed, especially if you sit at the sides.

Convenient way to travel. Enjoy the river, surrounding view and roam through the Old bangkok using this river express. Very convenient way to travel to the Grand place and other historic temple. Water is not so good, but the view is amazing. We came here using the skytrain and hopped into the boat from Sapan Taksin. The English announcement is not so clear, hence there is no way of knowing which stop is what. Sometime the boat gets too crowded as well. A must do in Bangkok old city trip.

Great way to get to the palace. This is a great way to get from the modern city to the palace district whilst seeing some of the most important river in Thailand. The local boat is definitely the best choice as it gives you a true taste of what it is like to go down the river as a local. Highly recommended.

Best journey to see some important temples. Get the BTS to Saphan Taksin and take the boat from there, Epress boat, blue flag is a little more expensive than the local one, yellow flag which is 15 bahts. They are both good. You go along the river, feeling nice and cool wind, admiring the views of some old buildings and temples before reaching your destination.

15, 40 or 150 baht. The Chao Phraya boat is definitely a great way to get to many key tourist locations and in and of itself is also a great way to spend time, riding on the river that is the lifeline of Bangkok. The 15 baht ticket is for the local boat and can be used once you are familiar with the stops, as there is little warning of the upcoming stops. The 40 baht boat is more comfortable and comes with a guide who provides commentary along the way. Tourist destinations are clearly announced, though the PA system on some of the boats was difficult to hear. Having used the boat on 8 different occasions, I can testify that the quality of the commentary of the guides was highly variable. Some seemed more intent on emphasizing shopping opportunities, some went to great lengths to point out the 5-star hotels, and the best ones provided a very good commentary of the history and importance of the buildings we passed. The 150 baht ticket, on the same boat with guide, allows one to hop on and off. I never went with that option, simply because one spent a great deal of time at the "hop off" sites, making it less economically to "hop back on". However, if that fits into your plans, it is worth considering.

Convenient sightseeing option. This was a great way for us to take in a glimpse of Bangkok before digging into our list of places to see. it was a short hop by tuktuk to the closest ferry stop (sampan taksin) from our hotel. tickets were well priced and the ride was very comfortable with an informative tour guide pointing out the main sights and advising where best to hop off.

Avoid the traffic. Bangkok is well known for her notorious traffic. The river travel will allow you to get to all the sights all along the river in good time, and on both sides of the river without having to criss-cross the bridges and wasting time in the traffic jam.

Best way of travelling. For 15 bht you can use it as many times you want in a day.I recommend ir using it the first day in bangkok so you can get to know the city by boat.Main attractions in bangkok are at a reachable distance from the river.

Great way to get oriented cheaply. We used the express boat to travel around the city whenever it was convenient for us.We stayed in the Bab-glampho area near the Khao San road area and a boat dock was ten minutes walk away near the Phra Sumen fort. The boat was used to get home from China Town, to get to and from Siam Paragon shopping complex and Pratunam Market in conjunction with the Skytrain. We also took the boat to the end of the line upstream which was a pleasant, non-strenuous experience.

Bargain. But more expensive than the local boat!. About 3 pounds but you can get on and off all day. Nice convenience, never overcrowded and there is some notification in english. Although it is also good to give the local boat a go too and travel with the monks and other locals. just that it gets a bit more crowded and makes more stops. Also as a very hot and humid place it's better to pay for a bit more space and comfort with all the sweat and stuff. Also links up close to the Skytrain which is also a good mode of transport, but if you are staying north of the Grand Palace the boat is easily the best mode of transportation.

The Hop On Hop OFF boat ride of Bangkok- the best way to enjoy the river and see the sights.. The Chao Phraya River Express boat is the Hop on Hop off boat ride of Bangkok. It is also probably the best and least expensive way to see the historic sites while enjoying the cool breeze. Of course you have to deal with the crowds and learn how to purchase the tickets and get on line, but it is definitely worth the wait . If it is crowded, do not worry - wait for the next boat so you can get a good seat. You can take great photos if you are sitting at the rear of the boat or the front. It is best if you are not in a rush so you can enjoy the river traffic, people watch and take in the scenic views. This was one of the best rides we had in Bangkok and is a great way to avoid the horrendous traffic. There are also ferries that take you from one side of the river to the other for a nominal fee. Just follow the traffic and you will do fine. Enjoy !
Fantastic way of getting around. get a one day ticket for £3 and jump on and off as many times as you like at all the different stops. Easier than than walking especially in the heat.

Great way of transportation!. Took us a day or 2 to figure out the system, but once we got it, loved it. We stayed in the old part of Bangkok so had to use it to visit the new / busy part of BKK. Very cheap! Do not take the more expensive blue boat, just ask directions to people on the boat or who sell the tickets.

Cheap, Scenic, great way to travel around the city!. The express boat is a great way to see the city, at 15 baht each way its a bargain. Good views of some of the cities landmarks can be seen throughout your journey and stop offs throughout the journey make it a great, cheap form of transport.

Single ticket is enough. A single ticket is 40baht vs the all day pass was 150baht. I guess it depends on how many places you are going but we only went to Wat Po and on the way back we were able to take a different boat. Which turned out to be quicker because if you buy the all day pass, you are limited to only use one kind of boat.

Really cheap and scenic. BTS and shuttle boats are the fastest way to the central pier. Once at the pier, it might seem rather chaotic as people keep shouting but just follow where most tourists go as they are probably going to the same place as you Ex. Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Chinatown. The fare is paid onboard and is very cheap for only 15baht per person. The boat gives scenic views of Bangkok as it moves through the river. Very recommended way to explore Bangkok.

Easy better than tour boats. We went blue flag. For 40baht you get English speaking directions. An easy civilised way to get around the city. Better than by road. Wish we had discovered this earlier in our stay rather than the last day.

A good way to get around . This is the best way to get around the river area.You get of the bts and can get directly on the boat .You can get of snywhere you want all the highlights have a port.Chinatown Royal palace little India asiatic (whitch is awesome) and so on.I love the river area it is super

Great way to see the sights. We caught the BTS to Saphan Taksin and Central Pier is nearby. You can buy a ticket on the pier or on board. Very cheap, 15bt and u can ride all the way til the end or at any of the piers leading to the temples. Move quick, the boat stops very briefly!

Avoid the traffic. Very handy for getting around without the traffic. Different boats stop at different stops, some just a few stops others most stops so make sure you get the right one designated by the coloured flag it is flying. Cheaper and quicker way to get some of those river photos without doing an overpriced and overlong cruise.

best transport with view. looking for unique transport around bangkok? choose this kind of transport. avoid the blue flag one because more expensive with 40 baht. choose orange flag with 15 baht or yellow one for 20baht. dont queue on blue flag.

Fast and Fabulous. This is a well run boat service for tourists and locals. The Orange flag boat will get you anywhere on the Chao Phraya River for only THB 15. Crossing from one side of the river to the other costs THB 3.

More Thai mass-tourism jamming, chaos and unpleasantness.. After researching and learning the routes/flag colors/how to get around using the river-taxi service beforehand, I found NONE the effort spent very useful. In general, the floating piers on the right as you enter the Pier buildings are for upriver boats and the ones on the left are for downriver, but this is NOT a given at all piers. Some stops have NO information in English and although I also memorized the stops by their numbers/what sights were at what number pier, the numbers were not always posted or visible from whatever position you found yourself jammed into on these massively overcrowded, chaotic boats. I never did get on a boat where finding a seat was possible and was invariably pressed up against some other poor tourist just trying not to fall as these boats banged into each other and the piers. I saw many confused visitors being yelled at very rudely by the staff who seem to take their authority as absolute. Tourists are loudly commanded-around getting on, positioned, and off these boats and the stops are not announced in any discernable way AT ALL. The first time I took the boat from Sathon Central Pier off the Saphan-Taksin BTS stop was kind of a nightmare and there were NO FLAGS indicating what stops the particular boat served. This absence of a flag can mean that it's a local, many-stop boat, but in this case, it was not a local boat at all but seemingly one drafted into general service and stopping arbitrarily. The staff were simply yelling at all of the confused people on the Pier to get on and ignoring people's questions about stops. All of Thailand's tourism is set up to process mass non-westerner tour groups, which are NOT the travelers who use this River Boat service. These boats were filled with a mix of locals, Asian independent travelers, and large amounts of western independent travelers. Even after many days of using these boats, I found them fairly unuseful both because of the wait times, but because of the complete absence of any information at the Piers themselves and the ambiguity/inconsistency of the "flag color" system. To get on a boat, it was often useful to approach a staff (if you could find one) and specifically ask "Bpai __________?" If that particular pier weren't crowded, sometimes you would be directed to a boat that would work for you when it arrived or you might receive a gesture for you to NOT get on it, so sometimes if you actively pursue the staff, they'll help you. In general, people onboard seemed surprisingly good-natured (possibly because they were only using the boats for one or two sights) and those TOURISTS closer to the approaching piers would try to help, in many different languages, the other tourists onboard trying to figure out where to get off. Even at non-peak times, these boats seem to operate at maximum-capacity and if you have a large backpack or luggage, GOOD LUCK! There's an area in the back of the boats where the staff might direct you to place your backpack/luggage, but you may or may not end up anywhere near your items once all the pushing and shoving is over. I stayed at the Phranakorn-Nornlen Guesthouse a ways off Thewet Pier N.15 and very difficult to reach by any other transport, so relied on these boats quite a bit over 5 days. I often ended up just walked long distances through the vendor-filled, uneven sidewalks and traffic to avoid using this river-transport. Please don't count on any English being spoken or printed at any of these piers or on any of these boats even though alot of the English internet sites seem to be saying that in Thailand there is lots of English understood and spoken.....this may be true for the high-end hotels, but definitely not anywhere else.

Not that organized and know your fares. We took this boat 3 times. The first was the "tourist" boat which is 40 baht and has an english speaking person on it. We couldn't really hear the english that the guide was speaking, but I'm pretty sure she was saying something in english. We bought tickets at Saphan Taksin for the return as well, but I'm not sure we could have used them in the end as they had an entry point designated. In the end we decided to walk to our next destination rather than find our way back as we were confused by the hectic dock with very little signage. We did make it to Wat Pho with no problem as we did hear when the staff person on the boat said it was the right dock to exit.In contrast, when we stayed at W Home, we used the "Orange Flag" boat. The fare on that boat is only 15 baht which is paid on board. It was cheaper and felt easier as well. I'm still a bit confused about whether they stop at every dock and whether you need to tell them or not for them to stop, but again, we made it okay and even found our way back on the boat despite the lack of signs.Be careful as there is definitely more splashing on the orange flag boat whereas the tourist boat had seats in the middle that were mostly protected from splashing. However, I still think the cheap easy fare makes the orange flag boat the better choice.

You don't want to fall in. At 150 baht all day ticket it sounded like a good option. But crowded boat and only few genuine spots to stop makes it less of a bargain compared to 40 baht single ticket ride. All in all, ok way to spend some time seeing Bangkok from a different angle....but water is disgustingly dirty!

An excellent trip to cover the major tourist attractions through the river boat.. The best way to cover important temples and view of the river front of bangkok through a one day unlimited pass. A nice trip and a must-do on the list.

Cheap way to cruise and see life along the river. Buy a ticket of 15-20 baht and get on the boat from Tha Phra Atit and cruise till you get to Sathorn (Taksin BTS station). This is a good cheap way to see life along Chao Phraya River. It can be crowded so wait till the next boat to get good seats.

Visit Bangkok's Biggest Attractions On The Cheap. The express boat is a cheap and quick way to hit the major tourist attractions and neighborhoods along the river while avoiding the crazy traffic. Get an all day pass for 150 baht and ride to Asiatique, then the Grand Palace, then hit Khao San Road and keep on going. One time I got lost but it was a great experience because I explored the neighborhood before coming back to the boat.
Cheap ride down the river. A cheap way to travel around the city, without any of the traffic, and also a nice way to relax and site see. You can access many areas of the city by catching the ferry.

Transport. Orange boat is my favorite since charge is always 15 Baht.You can see nice Rama 8 bridge in the evening with glowing lights if you plan your trip.Boat service opens path to Many attractions.

express tour by the boat. express way to tour bangkok, almost cover bangkok river and reasonable price as you can hop on hop off along the river bit crowded with local and tourist and the explanation from the lady guide is hard to understand

Good transport and also fun. A nice way of getting around the part of Bangkok that is close to the Chao Phraya river. 15 baht to go all the way from Taksin bride to the end station in Nonthaburi. More than one hours sightseeing from the boat. Very nice

Buy the Day Pass for unlimited boat rides- value for money at only 150 baht!. 150 baht buys you a full day of rides on the Chro Phraya express boat. Stop wherever you wish and visit the local markets and temples. Waiting times for the next boat is seldom longer than 15 mins. In the evenings, the boat service runs to Asiatique from the Sathorn pier. Take the sky train BTS to Saphan Taksin station and look for the Sathorn Pier exit. Try to ignore the boatmen trying to sell the private charter long tail boats unless you have a wish for privacy and lots of baht to spend.

An Experience. There were 13 of us ranging from 4yo to 70yo. Initially thought of getting the normal ferry which costs 20-40baht but decided that we should just take the one-day Chao Praya Tourist Boat. 150 baht per person & kids are free. Alternatively, you can buy one trip ticket at a flat rate if 40 baht. You can get this on the Tourist Ferry itself. A conductor will check and sell you tickets on board.With the day ticket, you get a small booklet that tells you the sights for each stop. The Tourist Ferry doesn't stop at every stop though but if you are a tourist, you will not need more than these stops. Glad that we took the Tourist Boats as it was a public holiday and the normal public ferry was jammed pack and wasn't as safe for kids and seniors. The guards/conductors on board were all really helpful and caring as they helped hold the kids & seniors during embarkation & disembarkation.The Tourist Ferry also has an English speaking 'tour guide' who explains the sights along the Chao Praya.The N5 (Chinatown stop), on the way out from the ferry terminal, the 1st steal on your left, they serve really really yummy flat noodle soup! The lady is teochew so most Malaysians and Singaporeans should be able to communicate pretty easily!

Efficient transportation . One of the cheap and enjoyable experience for us is tiding the boat at chao phraya river. It was amazing view to sime od the temples soecially the temple of dawn. We did enjoy the chief ride specially the blue tourist boat with a tourist guide who explain all important places in our way up and down thw chao phraya river. It was fun seeing highly skilled boat operator navigating a fast boat along the river. We did use these mode of transportation. Its cheap and no traffic. Easy ti visit all areas in bankok. From rama bridge khao san areas to the temples ( emerald palace wat pho king palace temple of dawn and aseatique resort. We spend the whole day using boat rides in chao phraya river.

Low cost way to explore Bangkok. The Orange Boat (orange flag on stern) is the best way to explore sights along the Chao Praya. Avoid the pressure sales from the private tour companies where you will pay 40 Baht vs 15 Baht and due to the far longer route will be able to see a far greater portion of Bangkok from the river while being able to stop at all the same piers and enjoy the top sites. Since seating may be hard to get at times, if you wish to have a best views and take some great photos ride boat beyond stop15 and then catch another boat in opposite direction. A trip from Sathorn Pier to last stop (25) will take about 80 minutes but is a relaxing way to orient yourself it sites while enjoy cool breeze as boat moves down river.

Do your research, choose your boat.. There are a selection of boats available on the Chao Praya - best to check out their website and pick which one is best for your needs. We jumped on the orange flag boat as we only needed to do one trip and it was an experience, as well as getting us where we needed to go for just 15B. These are no Thames Clippers! The guy at the back uses whistles to the pilot at he front to manoeuvre the boat, people hoard on and off at each jetty, and I will admit to keeping my eye on the shortest route to shore...Pay on the boat - there'll be someone obviously dressed rattling a ticket tin. There is the option of the 150B all day tourist ticket which I believe allows you to use all boats, not just the blue flag tourist express. If you have reason to make a lot of trips, or need / want to use the blue flag express boat then this will be the ticket for you. It's a shame really they aren't all a bit more frequent.

Crowded, but neat and cheap. There are a lot of other boat companies who try to steer you away from this boat line so beware. The orange line is the cheapest and also has the most stops. 15 baht every time you get back on the boat (that's 50 cents!) The ride is not enjoyable if you are standing and cannot see the water. Once people get off, you can filter towards a seat or to the edge of the boat and look over. We almost took our huge travel backpacks but are glad we didn't. Even our purses were in the way of people getting off! You are filtered on and off like cattle, but who cares because it's cheap and you can visit many places off the river.

Different view of Bangkok, a must do!. Had some time to kill with wife and 3 children. Travel to Temple of the Dawn. Getting there from Koh San Rd half the fun. Caught the orange flag boat from pier 13. Tickets bought at pier 3 x 15 baht, kids not full price, get off at pier 8. Next bait to cross river 3 baht each, eachway. In return to pier 13 buy tickets once on boat. Overall good trip and good photos.

Recommend Orange Flag Boat. No traffic jam, that is the big advantage. Furthermore, you get to see the great Chao Phraya River, the mother river of Thailand. I would certainly recommend The Chao Phraya Express Boat to you if you wish to have a good look at Bangkok, the Venice of the East.How to? First, take the BTS and alight at Saphan Taksin Station, Exit 2, follow the sign to Sathorn Pier, the central pier for the express boat. However, be aware of the friendly staff at the pier. They will guide you to the tourist boat booth which I think is not necessary. You can take the Orange Flag boat that serves the same purpose but you save. Imagine 15 baths vs 150 baths. Both will take you to places except that the tourist boat is not that crowded. I recommend you visit Wat Pho, Grand Palace and Wat Arun along the way at one go. At Sathorn Pier, just ask for Orange Flag boat, the queue is to the right of the tourist boat. You don't have to buy ticket at the booth. You can pay onboard or the conductor will come to the queue. Alight at N8, Tha Tien Pier. Get out of the boat, walk straight to the road and you will see Wat Pho right in front of you. After visiting Wat Pho, I will recommend that you come back to Tha Tien Pier N8, take the cross river ferry to Wat Arun and then take the same ferry back to Tha Tien N8. From here, take a tok tok to the Grand Palace. Costs about 100 baths. You may just end you tour at the Grand Palace after a tiring day but please be reminded that you are to dress up in proper attire. Otherwise, you may be refused entry into the temple or the palace.

Fun cruise through Bangkok. A very enjoyable cruise with scenic views of the city's buildings, bridges and monasteries. The ticket was about 15 baht per ride, I guess. It usually comes as a part of 7- landmarks in Bangkok guided tour. Halfway through the ride, they let you feed bread crumbs to fish, which come very close to the boat to grab the food. The cruise ended with a sumptuous lunch in a floating restaurant on a boat. Very enjoyable if you go in groups. Must see in Bangkok !!

Take the boat with the orange flag instead!. There is a special tourst boat, which is more than double the price of a normal boat. Yet the service doesn't differ!So go local and take the local boat (the one with the orange flag takes you to Wat Pho, Wat Arun, Palace etc).For 15 bath per ride you're in. Buy a ticket either on shore or once you're on the boat.

Avoid the tourist boat get local boat. The big mistake is before you get on - I got ushered to the tourist boat which say 'express boat'. As a result I paid 10 times price (still not a lot but....) for a trip which goes third distance and for which we had a guide who I did not understand a word of and would not shut up ! Get the local boat but you have to look to find it.That said the cruise is interesting - I'm suprised how run down the river is - is Bangkok half built or half decayed ? Still seem to be buildings half finished from the 90's financial crisis, a lot f decay in old buildings and a few new skyscrapers and of course glimpses of the gorgeous temples. But try and enjoy it in peace without the guide rabbiting on

Great affordable cruise along a river with many sights. Buy a full-day ticket for the tourist boat and hop on for a leisurely river taxi ride up or down the Chao Phraya river. It's very affordable and allows you unlimited rides.The tourist boat doesn't ply as extensive a stretch of river as the other non-tourist boats that you can get on for a cheaper one-way trip, but it stops at all the places a tourist would want to go.Great way to travel around in Bangkok while avoiding the frequently jammed up road traffic.

Fun for a few Baht!. Just beware about some tourist traps at some places like Thaksin Bridge, Tha Chang, Nonthaburi or other piers. Just ignore all this touristy things and take the boat with the orange flag. Check the internet about the timetable and then let's go. If you are active and creative you can discover many great places by yourself. Without a tour guide, cheaper and you can do what you want. For example there are many real floating markets in Bangkok, just find out were there are and when is the best time to visit theme. Good luck.

Blue Flag boat for Tourists. For the price, I found it quite affordable. We had a really good guide on board, and his English was immaculate! He was explaining the buildings and landmarks which you can see along the way in between the stops which the boat makes. However, on our way back, the guide on board was less than helpful and his English was quite hard to understand. A group of older westerners even missed their stop. If it is your first time, yes I would recommend this particular boat. If you have a specific stop you want to go to, please do use the orange flag boat.

Good views, transport, on the river.. We took off from the Khoa San area and went to the Central Station (supposed to be the last stop). Along the way we hit many different stops and got to sit down after a couple since it seemed to be predominantly locals (plenty of tourists there too). Took some good pics and got off at Central Station. Supposedly a short walk to the Asiatique Mall (most of those tourist maps aren't CLOSE to scale though LOL). But it was so cheap, and worth it.

Must use this service if you stay around Khaosan road.. Chao Phraya Express Boat service is one the excellent services being provided to the people no matter Thai or tourists. If you want to save time and go to many places in just a one day, this is it! very safe and comfortable way to move around by boats. And if you are staying around Khaosan road and you want to go to Siam square or Silom, you don't need to take a taxi or a bus, just take a boat from Phra Artith pier and drop at Sathorn Peir ( Central Pier) and take the BTS (sky train) to your desired place and reach there in within no time, if you take a bus or taxi, it would take your hours, keeping the busy traffic of Bangkok. And you can go to airport from BTS Saphan Taksin. just drop at BTS Phaya Thai and from there, take the " Airport Link Train," which will take you to Suvernabhumi Airport" ( Bangkok International Airport.)

Cheap, cheerful commuter service for pennies.... Tuk-tuk drivers are sponsored to take you to massively marked up tourist boats along the Chao Phraya. They start the haggling at 20,000 baht (70 US dollars.) This express boat (orange flag) operates along the river and took us from the Royal Orchid Sheraton to the temples ( Grand Palace, Wat Pho and War Arun) for 15 baht (50 cents) each way. You probably won't get a seat on board though...

cheapest attraction in Bangkok. Want to get away from the heat of the city ? Then take the sky train to Saphan Taksin and board one of the express ferry's. Determine beforehand from which direction the sun comes and sit at the opposite side. For about half a US dollar you can stay on this boat till the end and enjoy the sights of Bangkok from the river and you will cool of. If you do not want to sit out the whole trip, get off at an interim stop. But make sure that you get the express version back because otherwise you will be making a lot of stops

Use the Tourist Boat at least once if you're a tourist. I think my title is worth saying. If you're a budget traveller and figured out that the normal Chao Praya lines cost only 12-20 baht while the Tourist line costs 45 baht, I'd like to beg you to reconsider. The Tourist line is decked out in chairs and there is a conductor announcing the piers and nearby tourist attractions. With the normal lines, there is hardly an announcement regarding the upcoming pier, it's hard to see outside especially if there are a lot of people and there are almost no seats. I don't know about everyone out there, but my (inadvertently) taking the Tourist line instead of the normal boat helped me get an understanding of the locations of things along the Chao Praya River. Oh, the stops at piers are also much smoother on the tourist line. On the regular line, the boats *crash* into the pier platform as people get on/off.

Tourist trap. Chao phraya express boat for 150 baht is a tourist trap.Use the orange flag boat insted.U can pay directly on the boat - U have to pay 15 baht.U should now where you want to get off though.The piers are well marked in english.You can get a map at suvarnabhumi airport for boat routes or see on the net.
Easy way to get around.. Easy, fast and very cheap way to get around to a lot of attractions in Bangkok. You allso get a very good sight of the city from the riverside. Very recommendable.

only worth if if you're not in a time crunch. we got the full day pass. it could have been worth it if you are guaranteed getting on a boat. the crowd is ridiculous and boats dont stick to their time table schedule. it takes 1 hour to just get on and get down from one end to another.

Excellent transport on the river, and a good view to Bangkok. Quick and efficient way to get around, if you are visiting sights close to the Chao Phray River.Cost only 15 baht per person.Always crowded with people - thais and tourists from everywhere.Better than taxi or tuk-tuk!

The River Route – Best Way to See Bangkok. When I visit Bangkok I stay in the Khao San Road area. The place is fascinating due to its outrageous energy level. Just the ambiance in invigorating. And when at Khao San Road I have one way I prefer to travel, by the Chao Phraya Express River Boats. There’s a dock, Phra Athit, about two lanes from Khao San Road. The river boats that I’ve seen are the cheapo Orange Flag boats that cost around 50 cents, and the touristy Green Flag boats that run around a dollar. My experience is that the grassroots vessels are more crowded and sitting isn’t quite as comfortable. Other than those minor differences it’s an “apples” or “oranges” choice. The river boats are a fantastic way to sightsee Bangkok: Wat Arun, Wat Pko, Grand Palace, the Flower Mart, and Sky Train are all on the route. Most of the sightseeing destinations have docks nearby for those that want an up close and personal view of the Wats or Palace. Sure beats the heck outta the overpriced taxis and tuk-tuks. The best way by far to see Bangkok.

Orange boat goes one way. End to end. I took the orange boat from Rahchawong Pier, 15baht one way ticket. I told the ticket person i wanted to go saphan thaksin but the boat goes one way. Which meant i took from rahchawong pier to the end and had to get off the boat, buy another 15baht ticket from there to go all the way back to saphan taksin. Orange boat costs only 30baht which is cheap but more stops and more time spent on boat. (Sleepy&Sunny)I recommend tourists to take the tourist boat to save time. Its more pricey but you save time with less stops too.

Best way to get to main sights (Wat Arun, Wat Pho, Grand Palace, Khao San Road). Definitely the easiest (and cheapest) way by far to get to the main sites. There are a few options: you can buy a regular Chao Phraya Express Boat ticket and hop on hop off (quickly!!) with the locals, or you can pay a bit more and take the less regular (every 30 mins) but more "tourist-friendly" Tourist Boat. Get on at Central Pier (Saphan Taksin Sky Train stop) and then get on and off as you want at China town, Wat Pho, Wat Arun (get a 20 baht "shuttle" boat across the river), Grand Palace and Khao San Road. Later in the day the return trip also takes you to the Asiatique Centre.Just check if the regular express boat runs both ways because I'm not sure (and have a feeling it doesn't..). The tourist boat definitely does and has an English speaking guide.

Great way to get around Bangkok. The Chao Phraya Express Boats are by far one of the best ways to get around Bangkok. You haven't really seen Bangkok until you've seen it from the river. There are convenient docks such as near the Grand Palace (Tha Thien), Khao San (Phra Athit), and the SkyTrain connection (Sathorn).The downside of the boats are the touts that hang out on the piers telling you need to buy expensive tickets. They're lying; just ignore them. When the boat comes, jump on the boat with the orange flag for a ฿15 local commuter ride or the boat with the blue flag for the ฿40 tourist ride (which is slightly more comfortable).More than a mode of transportation, a ferry ride takes you past sights such as Wat Arun and under Bangkok's iconic bridges; you also get to experience life on the Chao Phraya River, full of longtail boats, barges, and tons of other watercraft!

Convenient/cheap way to see the big sights. This was a super-cheap and convenient way to see the sights. In November 2013 it was 150 bhat. It's a hop-on/hop-off boat tour. We went to Chinatown, and Wat Pho, and then the amulet market. Chinatown was amazing and crowded and bustling markets. Wat Pho (lying Buddha) was cool, too. There's a lot to see there in that area, as well. The amulet market was just a street of street vendors. They were all really pushy and had mostly the same stuff. The only issue we had was getting stuck at one of the stops: Tha Chang Pier N9. There were three spots where the boats could dock, and they kept going to different spots. But it was so busy we couldn't get from one place to another in the crowd before the boat left. Staff kept telling us to wait different places. Finally we gave up (because it was a torrential downpour) and just went on the boat in the opposite direction until it turned around and then we came back. Otherwise we could have been there for weeks.

Nice view boat ride. Took these express boats while going to Asiatique which was complimentary and the following day the express boats catered for tourists. The one for tourists has blue flag on it and the fee is 40 baht per person. It has a guide speaking in English seated in front giving some brief descriptions of the surroundings of the river as we cruise along. The guides will also announce the next pier stop and also attractions name associated to that pier stop. Be mindful though that the boat conductor selling the tickets on board and the guy who stands by the side of the boat to tie it down when approaching each pier can be a bit pushy asking to disembark immediately like what you have read in previous review that tourists are being herd in and out like cattle. If you want to cut cost on the boat travelling, you can choose to hop into the express boat with orange flag, which costs 15 baht. Tickets are sold on board though not sure how the conductor can recognize who has paid and who has not judging from the always packed people on board. Locals with some other tourists will board this boat but be mindful, there is no tour guide on board.

Scariest ride. I am not sure if I ride the right boat the Grand Palace. The experience of other travelers are different than mine. First I paid 500 baht one way not 15 or 30 baht as other travelers mentioned. I didn't even experience sigh seeing as I was scared to death while riding. The boat is so narrow and too low almost just like you are riding a skate board. It goes so fast and it lift you up and whack you down due to huge waves. It tilts left and right and screamed every time. The ride was non stop and seemed forever, maybe about 30 min. The worst, I looked around didn't see life jackets or floaters..what kind a boat ride offered a ride and get paid for 500 baht one way and does not have basic safety precautions. That was a suicide. Hell..I guess i got scammed. If you go, be careful make sure you get in the right boat to go Grand Palace.

Many stops along the river. It can be very full at times but you cannot fault the price or convenience of the experience. It stops at many destinations along the river making it a great way to get around (and faster than the congested and comparatively expensive alternative of taking a tuk-tuk or taxi).

Awesome and cheap way to get around. We accidentally stumbled on to the B15 local boat with our twin 2 year olds at Sathorn. What luck! We also stumbled off near Khaosan Road. Again - great luck. Great views. Silly cheap. Best way to get around Bangkok.

Chao Phraya River Boat. The Chao phraya river boat is an exciting experience. Infact the boat is Free for all after 4 pm. We made a free ferry went shopping in the Asiatic, again boarded the boat got down at Howthorn to get a train just few minutes walk. Went to phaya thai n then to our hotel Nasa vegas .

Cool way to get around. Cool way to get around Bangkok.
I would recommend the (orange) flag or the noflag boats since they are cheap and stop at (almost) every pier and cost 14-15baht.
Make sure you check what pier number you want to hop off at before and be ready when they shout your number!

Day ticket. If you plan to be on river all day or even half day its worth buying a full day pass for 130tb as you dont have to queue for change hen buy ticket. Its so much easier. sometimes you can get onto other boats if its not busy.

Easy and cheap way to move around. The boat is an easy and cheap way to move around to parts of the city where the BTS does not cover. Is good fun being on the river and you get to see some sights as you cruise along. Can be a bit of a free for all when getting on so just watch your footing.
Fast transportation . On first sight it looks much more exspansive then the normal boat, but a ticket is only 40 baht. And this boat goes till 22:00 and the normal boat stop running 19:30.

Best way to see Bangkok, Nonthaburi, and Pakkret!. Ride the boat. Pay only 15 baht and ride ALL the way up the river. Go to Nonthaburi and visit a local market or if you catch the boat Mon-Fri after 4:00pm you can go all the way to Pakkret (32baht). Once in Pakkret - join in with the aerobics or eat from the plethora of carts lining the road. Take the ferry across to Koh Kret, hang out with the locals.

It's not the price it's the principle!. So, you go to the ticket booth and buy a ticket 40bht each, each way to any destination along the river what they don't tell you or even give you the option of is that there 2 different boats the tourist boat or the local boat. The tourist boat is pretty much exactly the same as the local one the only difference is a man on a microphone stating the obvious.With the ticket they put you in a different line that you are waiting 3 times as long for the boat. If you don't buy a ticket and line up with the locals a boat will come along near enough every 5 minutes. You hop on that one and pay 15bht each! I know how cheap i must sound but its not about the money, its the principle! I just found it very sneaky as there was no advisement for this and felt as if we were " just foreigners "All in all its a very convenient and gets you places you need to go quickly! Be careful there is not such thing as health and safety on this service and you are herded on like cattle!

cheap way to see the river sights. It was mothers day, our first day in the city and manically busy. We bought our tourist ticket and went to explore! It's a great way to see the sights - hop on and hop off. And made extra special for us as the canons were set off a 12 - relief when the tour guide explained what is was for (I don't think we were the only ones who thought the city was being bombed!). The following day we got a cab - this was no quicker than going along the river! Be warned though - there is no hanging around - we were herded on and off like cattle!

A good way to get around. We purchased a one day pass and gives you unlimited use on their ferries for only 150 baht. At some of the piers there are many private ferry companies so make sure you ask for this one or we look for their logo. The ferry's stop close to many of the major attractions. Just make sure you know which pier to get off as they do not stop for long. So get ready and near to exits when they pull in to the piers.

Its convenient and cheap. It is so convenient to go from city to khaosan need only 20 minites but if you want to go by bus it take more than 2 hour because of huge traffic jam in BKK.The boat is big with lots of seat option for convenient journey. Ticket collect from the river station.

Fast, cool, and convenient.. Excellent way to get around in overly busy Bangkok. Taxi may take forever to get our of downtown due to the high volume of traffic.The air on the river is also cooler and less polluted. Definitely worth a try - I loved it.

Cheap and convenient. We were advised initially to take the private boat which will charge about 2500 baht per boat. We changed our minds, and took the public boat instead. It costs only 15 baht per person. Took us to the Temple of Emerald Buddha. Then we walked to Wat Pho, about 10 mins away. Then we took the tourist boat back (by accident coz it looks just like the public boat) which charged 45 baht per head. Still cheap. The only setback is, the seats are limited so if it's full then you've gotta stand. But it's pretty safe, so yes it's worth a try...

Don't buy tourist ticket - jump on orange flag boat. From the way the piers are set up most folk end up buying the Thb150 tourist ticket - don't bother just jump on any boat with a orange flag (yellow and red too that stop at different stops) and for - few baht you can go as far as you want. You'd have to an awful lot of trips in a day to clock up thb150 on the orange flag boat. The trip from Sapan Thaksin to Phra Athit is very pleas met and you'll see all the major sites on the way. You can also hire a long-tail boat from the guys at Sapan Thaksin for a private tour of the Klongs. Be brave - go with the local option and give the tourist 'express' boat a wide berth!

Fast, good views, great connections. Bought the 150 baht ticket for the tourist boat which gives all day access. It came with a drink and a guide, which was good. Accidentally ended up on the express boat and thoroughly enjoyed the day. 40 baht each way is what you would pay. I read that some others had worries about being hurried up to disembark, but I managed it ok with a funny knee and bad back. I really enjoyed the opportunity to cruise up and down the whole river from central to N30..... The last stop on the line. Great views if the temples and Grand Palace too.

Cheap and Efficient. I found out only after I got on the Express boat that there is a cheaper public ferry boat that the locals use, but considering I was pressed for time this actually worked out for the best. We took it for 40 baht per person each way up to the Grand Palace and got there pretty quickly. On the boat they announce each stop with plenty of time for you to get to the back of the boat to disembark and there are plenty of seats. We were able to get to see other sites along the way like the Temple of the Dawn, and the next time I'm in Bangkok I'll be visiting that for sure as it looks amazing! Easy to get to from the BTS train and a cheap way to get around up the river and shoot some great photos. Next time I will try the hop on hop off for 150 baht if i don't like the public ferry for whatever reason.

Convenient River Ferry. For 3 Baht a person this is possibly the cheapest form of transport you will find in Bangkok, particularly one that doesnt require you to haggle with the drivers unlike the Bangkok taxis.While the approach from the Wat Pho temple to the jetty is laced with the pungent smells of dry fish sellers shops, once you get on to the boat and are on your way its actually not too bad. The boats as such are pretty clean.I would definitely recommend this for anyone looking to visit the Wat Arun temple after seeing the Wat Pho temple.

Best River Transport Anywhere... Great value..... Bangkok roads are crowded - just about anytime, Between the Skytrain (BTS System), and the MRT underground - and the River Bus System - you can cover a great deal of the city for relatively low cost.The Chao Phraya Express River Express is a system of river boats that run every 15 - 20 minutes, and cover Bangkok with 30 plus stations - starting with Wat Raisingkorn in the South, up to Bang Po in the North. The river express system connects with the Skytrain - BTS Silom Line - at the Saphan Taksin stop, with Central Pier. From Central Pier it is a 15 - 20 minute boat ride to the Grand Palace, and many hours of touring some of the most beautiful parts of Bangkok. The best part of the Chao Phrya Express - 15 TBT price, and no river traffic.If you have the time, take a ride all the way to end of the line. It is interesting to see the variety of barges, speed boats - and if you go in the evening and catch the sunset, the colors and views are stunning. The boats use color flags. The yellow flag stops at all stops and covers most of the route. Blue flag is an Express, and costs 45 TBT - still a great value. So, if you go and take the boat, be sure you know which one you are taking, and look at the map to make sure the one you are taking stops where you want to go.Great transport system, great value and just plain fun!The boat route is shown on most tourist maps, and on the city BTS (train system) map. Check it out.

Great way to get around, cheap and efficiant.. "Tha Phra Athat Pier" is the closest embarkation point for Khao San Rd and depending where you are staying would be a maximum 15 minute walk. Be aware the entry point is a narrow alleyway. At 15 Baht per person to the "Grand Palace" (Tha Chang Pier) it is very cheap. You can pay on the ferry although they seem to prefer it if you paid at the ticket office. Look for the ferry with the Orange flag as that has the best coverage.The flags indicate the service.There are other company's but they seem to have very limited coverage plying their trade between 1 to 2 points on the river. Note:Tha Phra Athat Pier seems to be cheaper (1500 Baht) if you wish to privately hire a Longtail Boat to do the Thornburi canals. I highly recommend a 1.5 hour tour.Further down the river appears to be a lot more expensive.

Good way to see Bangkok. We caught the Express Ferry up to the Grad Palace for 40baht. It sure does beat brig stuck in traffic. The staff are helpful & on the boat have a microphone & tell you fun facts about sights along the river and where to get off to see particular things to do etc. it's a lovely way to start your day & see Bangkok.

Don't buy the Daily pass. Found the boats great and fun way to travel, but first day I bought the "tourist" unlimited pass for 150 baht. The express boats (which only come every half hour) charge40 baht a ride and the regular boats (a slightly slower but more fun trip) come every 10 minutes or so and charge only 15 baht a ride. As such you would have to be hopping from attraction to attraction all day to justify the pass. Just get on the boat and pay the lady when she comes around to collect.

Easy and cheap way to travel. We never used a taxi apart from when going to the airport...we used the express boat to get closer to the key attractions. The prices are really low, boats come frequently. All in all it was safe, fun an quick to get on / offthe boat.

Untrained and rude staff!!. I always prefer the normal Chao Phraya boat used by the locals as well as the tourists with cheap prices compare to the "Express Boats"! I didn't have good experiences on the express boats. Once when using the express boat, the boat ticket issuer threaten a tourist couple and used a very bad language over a small issue.. You can really enjoy if using the normal boat. Good luck!

Fast, Efficient, Affordable. The Chao Phraya Express boat is a simple and convenient way to explore some of the older temples. We managed to see Wat Arun and Wat Pho in a pretty short time and got back to our hotel on Sukhumvit via Central Pier and the BTS.We took this boat from Central Pier which is at the end of the Silom line of the BTS Skytrain (Saphan Taksin station). Getting here would have been easier, but we were duped by a Tuk Tuk who took us to one of the private boat piers and refused to go to the public ferry pier.Do not trust Tuk Tuk drivers, ask any local commuter for directions, they are very helpful.

A must. People along my travels always ask me what to do in Bangkok. I told them to just take the Chao Phraya Express and whiz up and down the river the whole day. Its a cheap and fun way to take it most "must-see" sights of Bangkok such as Chinatown, Wat Arun, Wat Po, the Golden Palace, Kao san road etc. For 150 baht you can just hop on and off anytime for the whole day. Honestly, the different colored flags confused the hell out of me so i just got on any boats that come otherwise you have to wait for quite a while. One time i took the local boat at rush hour - it was fun, crowded and raining

Like a bus. Easy, breezy, comfortable way to get around to some of the sites. Also nice for just riding the line to the north and to the south to take in sights of the city. Enjoyed getting to see how people go about their daily lives.

Extremely usefull. As you know some of the main tourist sites are located near the Chao Phraya river. This means that the express boat is a positive distraction from every day traffic jams. I used this express boat several times and you never have the impression the be cropped. An additional pro is that its price is very low compared with taxis and tuk-tuks. There is only one real "line" and there are a lot of boats stopping at the piers.

much faster than taxis. the express boat is a perfect option for moving arround in bangkok. we were far awya from the typical city noises and the air was easier to breath than in the streets. a skytrain station is very close and it no problem to go further. also interessting is the express boat for a boattrip, because the whole boatline is very long and shows a lot of extraordinary views about the typical asian and mostly poor river life in bangkok

A little confusing. First off, it a great way to expereince Bangkok, you see a mix of modern hotel building, temples and old shacks. It can be a little confusing.which is weird considering that you just go up and down the river...but somehow, knowing which pier to wait is a little challenging. Then add the boat that just crosses the river...Also, its not like there are english speaking Thai by the pier. Just be prepared to do lot's of asking and hand signaling and you would be fine, We didn't buy the whole day pass...really think the per ride payment is enough. Just be aware, this is a boat ride...so if you get sea sick easily, just make sure you are prepared.

Great Transportation. We traveled on the Chao Express to visit the Grand Palace and then took it on the way back to go to Chinatown which can be a bit hard to reach via public transportation. It was a fun way to travel and my husband and I really didn't like taking taxis in Bangkok due to some problems we have. Public transportation is the way to go. I thought it was a fun way to spend the day. We got the day pass and hopped off and on at a few stops.

best way to get to the main attractions. This is the best transportation to get to the main attractions in Bangkok - at least to Wat Arun, Wat Pho, Wat Phra Keao and Grand Palace. It is cheap, faster, no traffic jam and you get a new experience - traveling by express boat. To get to to the pier - simply take the sky train (BTS) to Saphan Thaksin station. Ticket - there are two main type of boat, one for tourist and one for normal ticket. I prefer to buy one day pass and with this ticket (pass) you will be allowed to hop on and off at any of the pier stops. So you don't need to worry if you get into boat that go to the wrong direction and also with this pass you can either wait for the tourist boat or you can also hop on to the normal boat (in case the tourist boat is late). I saw one review said the tourist boat not as frequent as the normal boat - well yes it is. But with the one day pass, you can actually hop on the normal boat too - only disadvantage is there will be too many peoples in this type of boat a no tour guide to tell what's attraction at the following stations. Anyway, with the one day pass, you will get a booklet on the attractions with the pier name - so use this as a guide.I would say one day pass is worth the price as you will definitely spend the whole day at all the main attractions which is all along the river. Also, in case you get into the wrong boat that goes to the opposite direction as you would want to go - it happens to me once (haha..)
Perfect sightseeing - 15 baht. For the incredible low amount of 15 baht you can travel on Chao Phraya as long as you want one way for 15 baht. A very nice way to explore Bangkok. Easy and fast.

An express way by the river. If you like boat trip or travelling, here is one of the best provider in the Chaopraya river.There are many piers that you can go to visit along the riverside especially for the temple tours or river cruise viewing.

Great way to see the river and sights along the way.. We bought all day pass for convenience and thought it was very reasonaable as we had commentary and could get on and off. You also got an information booklet and pass was good on other boats operated by same company once tourist boat stopped running.

No Traffic on the boat. It's another interesting transportation. If you want to avoid the crazy traffic on the road, the boat is highly recommended. It's fast without a dount. Furthermore, you can the nice view both both sides of the river. The admosphere is more relaxing than staying amongs high building in the city. The fare is reasonable to pay. It's worth it to take the Chao Praya Express boat

A Little Gem. My travel buddy and I got lost wandering the streets of Bangkok and stumbled upon the main dock for this operation. We had a day to kill, and we also wanted to see the other side of the river so it was a perfect fit. You are given a booklet in various language to tell you about each stop, but that is about as tourist friendly as this company gets. This boat is used by locals, so I thought it was awesome to get a little taste of the real, present day Bangkok. It is rather cheap, and it stops at all the local tourist stops (temples, etc). It does get crowded, so if you want to just enjoy the boat ride, be there early to load the boat.

Quintessential Bangkok...must do!. The Chao Phraya Express boats are simply the best way to get to the Kings Barge Museum, Sirriraj, and to get good daytime photos of Wat Arun. No need for the all-day pass, unless you have too little change for the single trip fare. You can make five or six trips at the trip fare before the all-day pass breaks even. Do try to avoid during shift changes, as you'll stand the whole trip..

Cheap Ride!. Cheap ride, but it would be more cheaper if we choose not to buy the whole trip ticket and chose the single trip ticket for every tour, hehehe because we did not consumed it all. Aww too bad, I wanted to come back for more!

An excellent way to travel around Bangkok. I love taking a Chao Phraya Express Boat - its a very nice way to get to some of the major sights in Bangkok (Wat Arun, Wat Po, The Grand Palace) and to some neighborhoods (Chinatown, Banglampuu, Thewet). And also, its cheap, with a breeze, without traffic jams, and with a lot on the river and the river edges to watch. Sometimes I take a boat just for the journey, and not because I want to go somewhere. A nice trip is to take the express boat up to Nonthaburi, the final stop "up north". There you might wander around the local market, and its also a good place to hop on a longtail boat going into the klongs around Nonthaburi.

Great, cheap, fast, efficient way of travelling between all the main temples.. The river express bot is an excellent way of travelling around. All routes are colour coded with flags. Our route was orange which was 15 Bhatt per person one way (no matter if it's 1 or 10 stops down the line). Used by locals and tourists. About every ten minutes, get on, pay the fare on board by conductor who comes round, enjoy the scenery, get off. A lot of the stops eg at grand palace and Wat po have really great market you have to walk through to get out. Great photo and bargain opportunities. A much cheaper and more authentic way to see the river than the expensive, embarrassing touristy dinner booze cruises. We loved it

Great way to travel. So with that, we took the Chao Phraya express boat to the stop closest to the Grand Palace.The Chao Phraya Express boat ride over was great. After boarding the Orange line public transit boat at the Oriental dock and finding our seats, the metal cylinder lady came by to collect fares in her metal cylinder which she would shake in order for the passengers to know she was ready to take their fares. The fare for any travel on the 17-stop line would cost 14 baht or 50 cents US, and we only used six stops to reach the Tha Tien dock which was the exit for the Grand palace. The boat itself was a handsome looking wooden craft about 90 feet in length and 15 feet wide and holding approximately 100 passengers. http://www.transitbangkok.com/Chao_Phraya_Express.htmlIf you enjoyed this story then please visit my blog; [--]

Okay way to see the sites.. One of the best ways to get photos of Wat Arun, which is partly why we took it and partly because it feels like you haven't been in Bangkok unless you've travelled the waterways. As usual, we didn't read reviews first and so paid the 150 baht per person for the all day pass, and probably didn't "need" it. But given we didn't really know what we were doing, having the all day pass was a comfort - we went the whole route and came around and got off where we wanted to on the way back. It's an additional three baht per person to use the river taxi to get across the river one way. We hoped for a nice quiet ride - ha ha. We GOT a very loud explanation of what was along the river in Thai and English, and couldn't understand either one. But first boat out in the morning (10:00am) was nice. Coming back after visiting Wat Arun, it was standing room mob scene, but at least there was no longer a loudspeaker giving us the sights.

Efficient way to travel along the river. This is one of the most efficient ways to move up and down the Chao Phraya river to the various sights and markets situated along the river – Temple of the Dawn. Grand Palace, Royal Barges Museum and Chinatown, to name a few. The great thing is that the Chao Phraya Express is linked to the entire transport network in Bangkok with a direct link to the Skytrain at the main Chao Phraya Express station, making it an easy and cheap way of getting to and from the sights along the river.The river stations and express boats (including the various boats used to cross the river) are clean and well managed, and have the necessary safety equipment, with staff always visible and friendly. The boats are open so it allows for cool breeze – we experienced minimal water splashing up, but it did depend on the wind. Overall it was a dry and comfortable way to travel.Inside the boats there are no announcements so you need to have a map and now where you want to get off – all the station names are in English and in Thai and the maps provided as well as the maps at each station are also well detailed and also in English and Thai. The public information available is excellent including there very informative website – once again in English, and the main ticket office’s staff speak good English and are very helpful.There are different boats, which are colour coded, depending on where you want to go – all are once again well marked. Certain boats operate only at certain times and only stop at certain stations, so you have to make sure that you get on the right boat – the good public information maps and ever present staff are always there to help. There is a dedicated tourist boat which provided more information for tourists and stops at all the major tourist sights stations – you also get an information booklet – the cost for a day pass on this boat was 150 Baht per person. We decided to rather use the normal boats as it worked out a lot cheaper as you only pay the trip fee – for the two of us for the entire days travelling up and then back down the river was only 60 Baht with a further 12 Baht for two river crossings, a lot cheaper than the 300 Baht excluding the river crossings. You can also use the day pass n the normal boats, not only the tourist boat. Depending on how many trips and stops you are going to make, think carefully before you purchase the day pass ticket as it might well work out a lot more expensive.

Do not buy the all day pass. Went on the spur of the moment and didn't read the reviews. Got told that the all day pass was 150bht & didn't realize that you can buy a one way ticket for 40bht or even cheaper on the local boats. I didnt think 150 was a bad price if the boats actually stopped to let you on & let you off safety. They seemed very rushed and one lady couldn't get off on time while her husband managed to jump off!!They also rushed off after letting passengers off but didn't let us on even though we were waiting right next to the boat!!! Awful service & long wait times! Go on the local boats!

Bangkok scenery by boat. This round trip on the boat was cheap and really interesting WE did miss our stop and ended up doing two or three stops twice didn't mind though it is a great way to see Bangkok from the boatWe enjoyed talking to some of the locals it may have been better on the tourists boat but any thing we wanted to know for instance what building is that there were plenty of people only to willing to tell usWe were told not to buy the tourist pass so just paid the fare for the 1 hour round trip

Don't buy the $150 baht ripoff!. Do not make same mistake I did! No need to buy the all day pass. Just get on a boat and pay the individual fare. Also, make sure the boat is going in the direction you want to go. I ended up on the boat for 2 extra hours. Long story short - don't buy the tourist pass.

Fantastic way of getting around. We took the orange from Taksin Bridge and all the way to Nonthaburi, around 1 hour ride - 15 Bath pr. person! The trip it self is quite interessting. It's a very efficient way to get around Bangkok, and combined with the Skytrain, it can't be much better. A lot more convenient than sitting in a Taxi stuck in the traffic!

Make sure to take the orange flag boat. As other reviews say, the blue flag tourist boat is a ripoff. It follows a shorter route for about 5-10 times as much money. Get on a boat with an orange flag, buy the tickets on board for 15 baht per person. The only major difference is the blue flag tourist boat provides bad English narration. Be sure you know where to get off to see what attractions you are interested in. All piers are marked clearly with English signs. Ta Chang is where the Grand Palace and Wat Po are. This is absolutely my favorite thing to do in Bangkok. Sometimes I just ride to the end, and ride back. Great way to see the city and kill time for $1 round trip.

Spent an hour on the river for less than ONE dollar. Taking the express boat on the busy chaoprya river in bangkok is like taking a bus just a lot more charming with amazing views. Don't miss this very simple yet amazing way to see many famous sights while taking in REAL bangkok river life. Got to one of the best value excursions in bangkok - but try to avoid morning and evening rush hours as it becomes really crowded with commuters.

Cheap way to explore a different side of Bangkok. As long as you do not care about narration, avoid buying the tourist boat pass at the dock, and just get on any of the non-tourist express boats (you can identify the boat from the color of the flags, the tourist has a big blue flag that says 'tourist boat', and it is a different style boat from the others). You buy the ticket for the non-tourist boats on board after departure, usually 10-20 baht. The orange flagged boat stops at all of the tourist locations, and charges a flat fee of 15 baht, so they are the best option for most visitors. The other boats do not stop as often, but you can see where they stop and what the fare is on the big sign in front of the pier, which has the route map. You would have to go on 10 trips on the river to make the 150 baht tourist pass pay off, which is very unlikely for anyone.The express boats are the best way to reach the Grand Palace, Wat Pho, and Wat Arun (you need to take a 3 baht ferry from the Wat Pho ferry landing to get to Wat Arun). Just take the BTS Silom Line, to Saphan Taksin, go down the stairs and walk towards the river. Personally, I like to go up north during the day, and come back south after sunset, to get a day and night view (just make sure you do not miss the last boat back). If you have the time, I highly recommend going all the way to Nonthaburi (stop #30). You will get to see the whole route, and Nonthaburi is a very nice area to walk around. There is a large cluster of shops, bakeries, etc right outside the ferry landing. A few blocks away is one of the most interesting outdoor food markets I have seen in Thailand, much better than Chinatown or any other I have been to in Bangkok.
